reviews.review: magical. Seeing her one and marvels at his arquitectura.Es a must place to visit. It gives the seal to the city of Cuzco.

Impressive. The mere size of the Cathedral is already impressive, however the paintings and decoration leave you in awe.
A beautiful church built to try to mask the greatness of the Inca place.

Interesting audio guide. The Cathedral is amazing inside and is made more interesting by the audio guide which explains the history of it. For me the highlight is the Last Supper with guinea pig on the table to eat

Interesting and beautiful. The church is near the Cusco Panoramic Tour bus stop and I had a few minutes waiting time.It looks common on the outside that is why I hesitated for a moment to check it out. But then I was proven wrong when I look into the details. Be mindful though: No photography allowed inside. I was pretty delighted that day to witness the start of the wedding ceremony --- from the moment the bride get out of her vintage wedding car.

Well worth the price of admission . It is 25 sols per adult to enter but that includes an audio head set tour which was all you need. It takes you step by step around the Cathedral in about 45 minutes. The interior is spectacular including a painting of the "Last supper" which had a very Peruvian looking Christ, and guinea pig as part of the meal! You will need photo ID like your passport or a driving license which is your deposit for the audio guide.
Great location. Located next to the main plaza. But it was also close to a night club that had blaring music till past 3 am.Clean rooms, good service.

A major site in Cuzco. Our guide for this visit had studied the cathedral for some years as his training; he was excellent. The church is interesting as a study of the amalgamation of Spanish Catholicism and native Peruvian belief. I was also fascinated by the paintings of The Cuzco School of artists, native Peruvians who were trained in the European Renaissance style of painting. There's an immense difference in the Quechuan approach to the figure and the classical approach of the Western Europeans. The former is much closer to a Modernist sensibility with its abstraction. The Cuzco School's work shows the incredible adaptation of the Qetchua painters to the Western European approach.

last Eucharist with the cavy. We wanted to see the painting "last Eucharist with the cavy". When you go in before 8 am you don't have to pay the entrance fee! It's a dark cathedral with much paintings.
Really Ornate. I was surprised at how ornate and big this place is. The artwork is astounding. It's definitely worth a peak inside to see the Spanish influence in this city.
Amazing. Cuzco is an amazing colonial town and its Cathedral and the square where is placed a must see location

Great audio info. Liked that the ticket price included an audio guide which gives great value for money ... always a key consideration. Anyway, sumptuous interiors, a silver altarpiece which would make Pizzaro bite through his hat rim in envious greed, and of course the Guinea pig last supper, which alone justifies the entry price.
beautiful. great interiors, unique paintings including the last supper with a guinea pig feast. i recommend you take a guide as this place needs a bit of explanation.

Gorgeous and very well preserved. Well you have to go see this amazing Cathedral. Do buy the packaged ticket so you can get into all of them, its a better buy. Takes some time and it was chilly inside so take a wrap if you chill easily, for you really do have to see it all. Very worthwhile and gorgeous.

Culturally important Basilicca. There is much to see at the basilica that shows how the Spanish worked to bring the indigenous people into the Catholic religion. Beautiful and varied architecture (to be expected with a church that took almost 100 years to complete. The Basilica is really three churches in one.
Interesting interrior. Well worth a visit to see the paintings and silver altars inside a very plain building. Quite a unique experience.

Very nice Saturday morning mass. My boyfriend and I attended Saturday morning mass and it was very nice. I speak Spanish so I enjoyed it greatly. We walked around the cathedral after mass and since we attended mass we did not have to pay an admission fee.

Worth it. If you get a ticket, you get access to the cathedral and the two churches built on both sides. The size and level of (golden and silver) decoration are impressive. And there is the Peruvian version of the 'Last Supper' including Papaya and Chinchilla. It definitely worth a visit!
Wonderful architecture. Cathedral split into 3 different parts of different ages, interesting to see contrast in architecture through 3 sections, photography not allowed unfortunately
Beautiful Cathedral. This was a beautiful cathedral with lots of history. The audio tour was great and explained all about the cathedral.

Really good audio guide. I got the audioguide (you need to take your passport for this) for the cathedral and was glad I did, it's a very well-done one on tablets with extra video. Takes about an hour. The cathedral complex is definitely worth a visit, the interior is stunning and there's a lot of history involved. The combi ticket, which is only a small amount more than the standard entry, is worth getting for the other attractions involved although the cathedral is the stand-out.

Visited Cusco, Machu Picchu, Puno, & Lake Titicaca from Sept 28 - Oct 7, 2016. I took the City of Cusco Day Tour as well as the Sacred Valley Tour. One of the stops was to the Catedral del Cusco. Nothing short of spectacular.!! The outside belies the splendor on the inside. The tour rep mentioned that something like 3 tons of gold is still in the church in various displays and in storage, not to mention all the pure silver as well. Ornate artwork from various metal work, tapestry, paintings and carvings from the 1600's abound (completed in 1654). It is huge inside with perhaps 12 - 15 alcoves, foyers and rooms. It seems to be the little brother of the Basilica in Rome with its sweeping Gothic Renaissance Archways (14 main pillars according to what I read). I enjoyed it.

Guided Tour of the Cathedral . Built in the 1500's the Cathedral is not unlike the cathedrals of Spain and Europe. The people here however add several adornments like the garments on the statues and the gold leaf and silver work. The church was built on an Inca palace which was knocked down by the invading spaniards. Take a guided tour through to see the many canvasses and carvings, chapels and statutes and to place these in the context of lives past and those practicing Catholicism today. This is a Cathedral if the world with a special unique South American touch. A must see in Cuzco. No photography is allowed and you must have a ticket to enter.
Impressive archeology. Contemplate this enormous church, It is really fascinating , It has a high content of culture and art

Amazing city.. We got to Cusco and right away we walked into town. We were overwhelmed with people wanting to sell us something. Some have paintings and they are mass produced as severeal hae the same image, unsigned. Women selling gourds carved with designs they'e done by hand. The city has a lot of historical significance and everyone should read up on it before you they go. You won't be able to miss this monument.

Not great. Maybe I have been spoilt by european cathedrals but this just isn't that impressive. The statues are poorly made and laughable, the design and style is questionable, very over the top and taccy, whoever designed it was very fond of shiny things. It's interesting to see that a cathedral in such a poor country has so much gold when the money could go to much more useful things. I did like some of the paintings though.
Nice pice of culutre. surprising architecture, nice interior, dominated by an amazing picture of van Dycke, worth to be seen

Take the Audio Guide. Incredibly beautiful. Historically significant. Leave your guide outside and rent the audio guide. Has the best balance of info and pace I have experienced. It is relatively cheap so don't miss the opportunity.
Beautiful Catherdral inside and out. Be sure to go inside - there is a fee, but it's well worth it. It might be good to have a guide - there is a lot of history to take in.

Very garish cathedral. I'll preface this review by pointing out that I am not religious so some of the awe is lost on me in these places. The cathedral is nice to visit and there are many alters. Overall, I find the style of the churches in Peru a little garish, everything is covered in gold, silver and sequins. Stunning woodwork in the choral stalls.

Well worth a visit. We really enjoyed our trip round this cathedral ,which we were told was the largest in South America.The various paintings were fantastic and the main alter and side alters were stunning.It was a shame that photographs or videos were not allowed.

Astounding History. This is another one of those Incan religious sites that the Spanish destroyed and in a show of power and dominance built their own Cathedral. In the process of converting the locals to the Catholic religion they allowed local artisans to provide the paintings and icons. Taken as a whole, it makes one wonder who influenced whom. I would recommend hiring one of the local guides rather than using the audio guide. It is a better use of time and a guide can make the story come alive.

Another Old church with nothing great except...... Near the exit is a very distressing statue of Christ carrying a wooden cross -- the ends of the cross have hands sticking out -- no real reason. Felt is was too commercial. Better to spend your time sitting outside people watching and/or enjoying a beer next store!
Overwhelming cathedral. The Cuzco Cathedral is quite overwhelming. A range of wonderful altars and a lot of old sculptures. One of the must-sees in Cuzco.

Worth your time. We spent over an hour touring the 3 connected churches. If you have ID (passport/driver's license) an audio guide for two is available for free. Only one of you needs to provide ID. If you visit only one church in Cusco, this is worth it. Beautiful wood work and gold leaf altars, and the self-guided tour is well done.

Fasinating. This is a church that opens your mind. Make sure you see the Last Supper painting. Dinner was clearly Peruvian. There or many catholic churches on South America but this may be my favorite. It is well worth the entrance fee.

La più bella in Perù . La più bella cattedrale del Perù, all'esterno non lascia intravedere lo splendore che invece si trova all'interno. Tutta da scoprire. Audio guide disponibili all'ingresso. L'ingresso è a pagamento, ma sono soldi ben spesi e meritati. Non è possibile fare foto all'interno.The most beautiful cathedral of Peru, outside leaves glimpse the splendor that instead lies within. To be discovered anywhere. Audio guides available at the entrance. Admission is not free, but the money spent are justified and well spent. You can not take pictures inside.
Well worth a visit.. Quote a vast cathedral with many interesting features. Including of course the Last Supper painting with the roasted guinea pig on the table giving it a very local touch.

Beautiful inside and out. This is a great Cathedral to see while in Cusco. One large chapel with two smaller on each end. Lots of history here. Be sure to take good look at The Last Super painting. There is a little Inca influence in it. Unfortunately no pictures allowed on the inside.

Better than i was expecting. I didn't realise the importance of this cathedral until I visited. I did the free audio guide and it was most interesting. The cathedral itself is massive, and there are some truly amazing artifacts inside it

One Of The World's Greatest Cathedrals. If you are into Cathedrals then this is a must visit. Unlike most other historical Cathedrals that focus on a single religion, this one features Inca and Catholic with a Spanish interpretation. 100 years to build, the place is huge. Many areas feature gold and silver religious artifacts like you have never seen. Very ornate and yet features much of the Spanish influence of baroque style. Also impressive are the amount of paintings, almost like a museum.Open daily in the morning for mass.
Amazing architecture, but you may not like the propaganda. This is an amazing building, but it highlights the subjugation of the indigenous population in the 1500s.

Black Jesus & a cut last supper. I am not a religious person but I appreciate the art and architecture of these old churches. However, the highlights of this tour were the black Jesus and its history and the painting of the last supper with the cuy! Our guide was big on sharing how the church leaders made concessions to Andean life to assimilate the native peoples.
Easy to follow audio tour. In the price of your ticket you get an audio tour, with easy to follow steps. Lots of amazing things to see, shame they won't let you take pictures

Interesting. The entrance fee includes the free audio guide which lasts around 45 minutes. No photo is allowed in the church and there are lots of personnel around to enforce this policy. The church itself is interesting with the blending of native elements with Catholicism in some of the art works.

Worth the entranace Fee. This cathedral rivaled those we visited in Italy and Spain. We took a guided tour and I am grateful. It has plenty of traditional ornate standard Catholic items but it was amazing to see how they incorporated the traditional Inca items into the cathedral. This is actually a cathedral and 2 small churches. This was the only "church" we visited in Peru and I am happy we decided to visit this one. Photos are prohibited.
Just like any other cathedral. Nothing exceptional. No photography allowed inside the church. But the window on the first floor is a great place to get pics of plaza de aramas.

Beautiful artwork. The artwork and wood carvings in this place are just unreal, you don't see stuff like that anymore...I highly recommend taking a guided tour, you can do it by urself but a lot of the history and simple details will be missed, plus the tour guides are very knowledgeable and move through at a good pace w/o rushing you

Peruvian details on Biblical stories. I was not going to taking a guided tour of the cathedral but am glad I did because various aspects of Peruvian elaborations in art and architecture were explained and this information made the experience richer. I was astounded to see the altar in silver which made its appearance heavy, dark, beautiful and imposing as contrasted with most altar pieces I have seen in the Americas. The guinea pig on the Last Supper painting really makes one feel this is Peru!
Nice paintings and view on the square . Worth the 10 soles to visit. The have nice painting and ladies walk around to give you more information.

Not free, but positively surprised. Normally, I don't pay to visit a church, but for the cathedral (and two other churches) we made an exception. It was well worth it! The cathedral is lovely, and you get an audioguide (included in the price) that guides you around, and explains the different parts of the building.We purchased the combined ticket that includes another 2 churches and the biscopal palace. It was money well invested
Gracious Church. Right on the main plaza sits this beautiful church dating back to 1500's and still in use today. You must go inside and see the beautiful small chapels on the perimeter.

Beauty. I ve been to Cusco many times
Love la plaza de armas, It has two big churches on it
Great place to walk and visit

Lots to see here. Regardless of how much time you spend here the ticket is worth the price. There's an incredible amount of interior treasures houses in this cathedral. The exterior is also very picturesque. There are electronic audio guides available as well for free if you're willing to deposit an ID or passport.

Impressive. Three sections of the building were built at different times. It is sad that the conquistadors basically destroyed Inca holy sites to erect their own. Inside, no picture taking is allowed.

Lucky Enough To See a Wedding. We visited this in the early evening. The chandeliers were beautiful inside and made for nice photos. Remember no flash and be respectful of those worshipping. We actually saw a wedding take place. It was small but sweet. A nice church to visit.

Hidden Gem. The Cathedral's admission covers the service fee for headphones. It is not necessary to hire a tour specialist. Plan to spend thirty minutes to one hour visiting the Cathedral. At the exit point of the Cathedral, there is a small window glass stand, which is a hidden gem, where you can buy Machu Picchu books for a bargain price of 50 Sol ($15 USD). Inexpensive compared to other places. I could not pass up the pricing.

Landmark in Center of City. This Cathedral is one if the focal points of the Plaza ..centrally located surrounded by shops and restaurants . There are many park benches available to relax around the plaza and the Cathedral . It costs around 8 us dollars to enter , inside there is a large collection of art work. It is an ornate & beautiful inside .. but the outside steps is a great location for group photos .

Beatiful inside. Much more impressive inside that the outside would indicate. No photos, but I disabled my flash and just had to take one of the gold altar and crucifix - stunning. There's a great view of the square and the interior of the church if you walk up in to the balcony. Well worth a visit.

400 paintings in one Cathedral. One of the biggest Cathedral I've ever been, I think. It is incredibly decorated and has four hundred paintings on its walls. The history and the story of the church is also really interesting.

A central fixture in Cusco!. The Cathedral is a huge portion of the Plaza and is so worth touring! There is artwork and history throughout and you'll be amazed at its grandness and history!!! I'm so glad one of our tours included this!!! Simply stunning!!!

Fascinating Cathedral. Was surprised at the entree fee, as I have visited churches and cathedrals around the world...be sure to look for the painting of the Last Supper, with the Guinea pig on the table!

Wow so much to see. This is such a wonderful Cathedral. ..... with so much to see. It cost 25 sol but you do get an iPad as an audio guide and there are approx 24 station to stop and listern to the guide. Stunning Cathedral would definitely recommended. .... unfortunately no photos allowed.

Beautiful and a lot of history . This cathedral and adjoining church is fantastic and beautiful. Get a guide. There are many Inca symbols interspersed into the art and carvings in this place. A lot of history depicted and just beauty all around. Very lovely

very large, ornate gilt laden, but NO photos allowed. this Cathedral is very large, and made up of many parts, attached directly is the old cathedral. THere are many paintings and statues to see, but they are very strict on NO photos. you can go underground and see some burial tombs too.

Beautiful Cathedral right on our doorstep. We walked out of Palacio Del Inka and into the Cathedral, simple outside, stunning inside, and very welcoming people. It was Sunday morning and the services welcomed tourists.
Very Nice Sunday Review. We saw the Catedral when we first made it to Cusco. Very nice and majestic setting. You could feel the history just oozing from the Catedral.
Beautiful Cathedral. I went to the 7am mass on Sunday morning at the Cathedral. Get there 10 mins early to get a seat as the church is packed. A great experience.

This a one of the shining jewel in the crown of Peru. Visiting the cathedrals, monasteries and other non-Christian religious sites are well worth the price of the tours. Eat lots of the street food and definitely visit the Mercado San Pedro. Go hungry, leave fulfilled.
Impressive. Being a catholic I was impressed with the cathedral You must tour with a guide to learn all the history and how it was built.Something not to be missed in Cuzco.

Impressive Audioguide. I don't really like touring churches that much as they seem mostly all the same. However, this one is different. The church was filled with tons of statues and artistry. What really made this worthwhile was the audiotour that was included in the entrance fee. It was about 45 min long but really hit on the history, fusion of Andean/Spanish, and artistry. You also have the choice of using a real human guide, which is probably about he same. Kudos to them for giving you the option. The entrance fee was 25 sol per person which was a bit steep, but not bad. Well worth the trip though.
Highlight of the city tour in Cusco. Most enjoyable tour - soaked in the fascinating mixed culture of Inca + Spaniards. A great way to start learning about the city.

It's fine... but.... There's nothing wrong with the Cathedral. It's a perfectly decent structure, with a great deal of historical significance. Personally, I find it hard to get past how it's basically the physical manifestation of one culture literally obliterating another, destroying their sacred spaces and using the materials to literally build their version of the truth on top of another. It's not a particularly badly done cultural obliteration, and it was certainly successful and significant, but to me it's just sad and not particularly enjoyable in terms of an experience.
Impressive. It was impressive what the Spanish were able to construct so long ago. The details, the paintings (with many ancient images translated into South America, e.g., tunics, llamas, etc.).

Wonderful examples of Cusco art. Useful to have a guide to ensure you appreciate the ways the Cusco artists interpreted the Catholic faith to include some of the ancient beliefs, although guinea pig at the Last Supper doesn't need much explaining!

Worth a visit. Worth a visit in cusco. An audio guide is included in your entry fee which is great. Useful to be guided around with extra information. Impressive building with fascinating history. Very different to churches in Europe and lots of gold and silver to see. The last supper painting is the highlight of course.
Beautiful!. Went to a Catholic service in the church. Both the church and the service were very nice. Decore was very ornate. It was amazing that the local police were attending the service.

make sure to use the audio guide. Enjoy the visit to this beautiful and ineteresting church that has a lot to see. But you do need to take the audiotour (incl in the entrance fee) to get the most out of it. This church shluld be part of your must-see's in town

la catedral es hermosa . The cathedral houses three churches, multiple catacombs and perhaps the greatest repository of art that I have seen in Cusco. I recommend a guide, and taking your time after the guided tour.

A great treasure. First off no photos are allowed anywhere. That being said, your eyes will feast on some amazing works and treasures that this church can offer. We took our time reading the plaques around the church, a must see, after you are done seeing the church you will understand why no photos are allowed.

Definitely one cathedral worth exploring.. Definitely one cathedral worth exploring. It's a shame the admission price has increased so much, but it is well Maintained. The works of art are incredible.

Heavenly . This cathedral is beautiful. You can hire a guide or they offer a FREE Audio Guide in many different languages which can be shared between two people. We did the audio guide and it was very informative. No video or pictures allowed. This is worth seeing. Photos are from the outside.

I recommended the Cathedral Tour!. This place is mind-blowing! We got the audio guide, which was very well designed and put together!. I have been in the cathedral during mass, however the tour is highly recommended if you could spare little money! I love this place so much!

Huge!. The cathedral is huge!
They have extra information on the Catholic holidays and how they are celebrated here vs traditionally in other places in the world.
It also has an interesting version of the last supper painting with a Guinea pig, on the right side of the main altar if I remember it correctly.
25 soles per adult.

Nice, but no photos allowed . We live to travel and love churches because of their history, but was not happy to be chased around and reminded several times not to take photos with or without flash. It would have been a much better memory to have some photos.

Wow! This is a gorgeous Cathedral.. The art and architecture will take your breath away, just as intended. It is hard to fathom all of the history that added up to everything that you can see in this one building. Great visit!

Fine Spanish cathedral. I'm not a great fan of Spanish architecture (I prefer French and Italian), but there is a lot to recommend this cathedral. You really get a feel for the "flexible" nature of the religion brought to the region through the attempt of the artwork to influence the indigenous population. It's amusing to listen to the tour guides give entirely different interpretations of the contents of the church. I was fortunate to be in town for the festival of the ascension, which brought the commitment of the community into full display.

Nice centrally located Basilica. Wonderful basilica and the adjoining chapel. You can see the influence of Spanish artists. Church has some unique items to view and not too busy despite being in high season.

The most impressive gorgeous lavishly decorated church. This is a truly impressive Catholic Church with a ton to see. I wish they let me take pictures because words do not do it justice. We unfortunately couldn't do the audio tour because no headsets were available, but we still enjoyed it. I imagine you would learn slot more with the included audio tour.

Not impressed! . I had visited so many beautiful churches in LatinAmerica and I was not impressed by this cathedral. I was surprised by the high ticket price to enter and no photos allowed. The audio and video tour is good but, you have to leave your passport or driver license, kind of scary. So many places to go in Cuzco if it's a must see on your list be ready, if not I would skip.

"MAGNIFICENT SPANISH COLONIAL ARCHITECTURE AND ART". The Cusco Cathedral is an overwhelming sensory experience because of its enormous size, historical significance, incredible Spanish colonial architecture and beautiful religious art. It is a feast for the eyes, spirit and soul.

Great site but bring money. At a recent visit to Cusco, I visited the Cathedral. I was surprised about the steep ticket price as well as the fact that photographs were not allowed. Overall, an interesting visit. Beware the many vendors all around the Cathedral.

History old church. This is a must if you like churches remember there is a lot of Spanish history in Peru/Cusco . So expect to see a lot of churches ,a lot of the churches no pictures the altar is beautiful and the statues .some work is being done inside repair wise but it does not take away from the beauty. About 1hour if on tour.watch the design of the statues you will see a lot of them with wide skirt/cloth this is representing Mother Nature so it is the same shape as a mountain.
Incredible art. Well worth including in a visit to Cusco. Interesting facts about Catholic adoption of local customs
so much gold. very impressive and extensive religious buildings and artefacts. Makes you glad the church has changed (a bit ) towards helping the poor.

Must See Cathedral . We arrived mid morning after shopping locally for gifts. Queued and bought tickets. 25 sola each and included an audio guide. Explanation in English did not highlight that one had to hand over a passport or a drivers licence when collecting the audio guide. Caused stress as we were not carrying passports. Luckily I had a drivers licence. Audio tour was good and explained things well. No photos was the policy. Shame as I think a no flash policy would be better as some things were really worthy of a photo. Interesting blend of Spanish and Peruvian influence. Worth a visit however it was a bit of a hassle. Took about 2 hours. Beggars inhabit the exit area.

Beautiful Cathedral. Catedral del Cuzco is gorgeous, and has three parts to it (the Catedral and then two other iglesias). There were breathtaking paintings and wonderful Boroque style architecture. It was only 30 soles to get in, and the ticket you get includes 6 other sites to go and visit in Cusco. The ticket is valid for 30 days so you have plenty of time to use it.

It can be compared with any major cathedral in Europe . Amazing church with unique decoration, you can see the symbiosis of European and native cultures. There are several crucifixions showing Jesus like a native or even darker! Lots of gold and art. It is not free but well worth it. Too bad you cannot take pictures inside...

this is amazing. this is not to be missed. If you have a tour or guide that is the best! there are several paintings not seen anywhere else in the world because the Virgin Mary is pregnant: this is a blending of Inca Culture and Spanish Catholics. Mary is with Joseph and Jesus, she is Inca Mother Earth. there are several paintings like this. Also, the stone representing Inca religion is in the back of the church and still honored today. Not to be missed is in Cuzco. On the square and central to all religions

Beautiful Cathedral, Immoral Pricing. The cathedral itself was gorgeous! The craftsmanship inside and out was awe inspiring and of a quality that you simply do not see anymore. Inside, the artwork is magnificent and leaves you almost speechless. You truly feel like you are in a special place when you are inside.My problem is with their immoral management. For starters, they charge about $25 USD to get in - this is not only over priced but somewhat disgusting considering this his a holy place of worship and a sanctuary. They also ask for no photography, videography, or talking UNLESS you pay $100USD for a tour. If you are part of a tour they nearly shout to their tour group and a allow everyone to take pictures. It is sad they have pimped out this revered ground for profit.
Beautiful Cathedral. Visited while in Cuzco with family. Amazing Art with the Spanish Influence. Very old statues. Loved it.

Happy Land. Cuzco is a marvaleus place to experiment a city of Happiness...if you take the enough time to observe you will see a lot of people smailing and doing their lives in harmonie. The center is beautiful place and the cathedral is an example of the rich past of the city. Dont get wrong still rich, a sqr meter of land in cuzco downtown cost 5000 usd...a couple of blocks from the plaza de armas you will find the market and in the other way you can climb to the San Blas section where the artesanos offer nice works...Take at least 5 five days to be in this wonderful place and dont wait until the altitude sickness catch you...as soon as you get off the plane take a mate of coca and buy some coca candies to help your body to adapt, dont take at night because you may not sleep...

Take a photo of the Cuy last supper. This is an amazing Cathedral, across about 3 sections. You can get headphones when you go in.The first section is like a huge chapel. The second is massive with amazing features, statues and paintings. You are not allowed to take photos of the inside and there are lots of security folks. So it is a good challenge to sneak a photo of the Last Supper with is Guinea Pig! I managed to hide behind a tourist a take a sneaky one!
Catedral del Cuzco of Catedral Basilica de la Virgen de la Asuncion. It is a great sight , you can see a lots of cathedral paintings and status and the black virgin. It is worth to visit.
Cusco Vacation. This is a very nice tour. There is a lot to see and study. The only problem was no pictures were allowed inside the church.

Very expensive and no photos allowed!. Although this cathedral was quite beautiful, it was not worth the S/.25 per person, especially considering that no photos are allowed! I can understand flash photography in certain instances, but not even photos without a flash... Thing is, they don't tell you that when you buy that expensive ticket - only once you're inside is there a huge sign and a stern faced security guard making sure no one breaks the rules. It was just a great disappointment...We've travelled through Europe where the most amazing cathedrals were free and photos were allowed. I guess if they allow photos, no one will buy their postcards...
Wonderful place - in particular during the fiestas. We went to the cathedral on the Corpus Cristi day, and the cathedral offered a spectacle of parading statues, incense, chanting an praying.

Holy Cow! That's a Big Ornate Church. The Cathedral of Cusco was completed in 1654 and took a hundred years to complete, it's huge. They don't let take pictures and they are very serious about it. I wonder if it's a flash thing? Why not no flashes? The labor and pilfered stone was provided by the Inca. An interesting fact that is that much of the beautiful and sometimes large artwork was also done by Incas that were trained at The Cusco Art School. The Cathedral also houses much of Cusco's surviving colonial art which is amazing. The church has 3 separate sections with altars and the main one is all silver, I think because I don't pictures. On the sides of the church there are elaborate rooms with displays of certain Saints or scenes which all worthy of a look. I don't think I've ever see a Cathedral this large and this decked out, it's impressive and worth a look.
Astonish views. A tiny city plenty of history and mixed cultures.You can meet native people in their original costumes.Landscspes are astonishing. As of you were standing at the top of the continent.

Yes, take this tour. This is an excellent tour. I see there is a picture of the "Last Supper" with the guinea pig. I would have given my left arm to have a photo of that painting. You are not allowed to take pictures in this area so do not expect to do so. There is a picture of hell at the beginning of the tour and I was able to take pictures of it. Believe me it will make a lasting impression on you. It truly is a picture of a very disturbing hell. Not one my imagination could have conjured.

If you want to see 25% of the gold and silver looted by the Spanish conquistadors!. Dozens of gold retables, at least a few silver retables. Lots and lots of statues (as opposed to say, paintings) in retable niches - almost all clad in elaborately embroidered clothing, The clothing is usually puffed out to resemble mountains - natives considered mountains sacred - so, this mechanism was helpful to convert them. It is said that 25% of the gold looted by Pizzarro enterprises went to these churches, the other 75% to Spain. This is really a complex of 3 churches, and the free audio-guide is quite good. I'd allow about 90 minutes for the visit. No photos allowed, which is a minus. By the way, don't miss the resemblance of Judas to Pizzarro in the last supper painting. Also don't miss the original cross carried around by Vicente Valverde (a priest who accompanied Pizzarro around the country and sold Christianity to the people while Pizzarro looted them) - Valverde went on to become the first bishop in South America. Check out mirrors in the church - usually treated as a sign of vanity, but used here to convert the locals. Finally, don't miss the choir stalls - very elaborately carved cedar wood - and very good.

Impressive interior but photography not allowed inside. Impressive interior. I have visited many cathedrals in Europe. This one was similar but with local Peruvian artists touch. We had a tour guide with us who was very knowledgeable and took the time to explains various unique paintings and statues and their historical perspective such as dark skinned Jesus, pregnant Marry. lot of gold work around the alters.

Breathtaking!!!. One of our favorite stops in Cusco. The audio headphones were a great way to learn about this magnificent church. It was simply breathtaking. Only downfall was that we couldn't take pictures.

Impressive Interior but No Photography Allowed. I was very impressed by the interior. Unfortunately, photography is not allowed inside. Entry was 25 soles and an audioguide was provided. I had to leave my passport in exchange for the use of the audioguide. My passport was returned once I had returned the audioguide. The audioguide was very informative and the tour lasted about 45 minutes.

Well worth visiting. We visited the Cathedral as part of our city tour and it was very interesting. Lots of silver and gold work especially on the alters and lots of nice artwork. Interesting painting of the last supper with a guinea pig on the table. The car made out of silver was amazing and the basilica is beautiful.

Awesome + different. I have seen/visited many cathedrals throughout the world, this cathedral was pretty awesome. The entrance includes a headset but be warned that you will not be allowed to check out the headset unless you have a passport. The Cathedral is simply awesome, lovely paintings, statues that have lovely capes, ornate carvings, numerous chapels. This is simply a beautiful and different cathedral.

Beautiful Cathedral in Cusco!. I loved the churches in Peru, many of them reminded me of Cathedral's you see in Europe. The two in Cusco at the Historic Center were gorgeous! I toured both, and they were very different. Catedral del Cuzco was well worth the tour. You can get a guide or walk around yourself. I opted to just walk around and see it on my own. The cathedral is huge, and very beautiful inside. It was crowded when I went, so I recommend going on an off time. The outside of the cathedral is stunning as well, I recommend viewing it both during the day and night. The surrounding area is beautiful as well. I loved Cusco!
Wow! A church in South America!. If you are traveling in South America, you are going to see churches everywhere. Did not consider this church to be anything special, but perhaps I missed something.

Worth seeing. We had a pleasure to visit the Cathedral with a great guide Ms Christina. The way she explained the art and history was truly remarkable. To see the last super painting with apostles eating Guinea pig was truly fun. Plus the Holy Mary in a shape of the mountain and Jesus looking down and very sad... Lots of interesting exhibits. Definitely place to go in Cusco - especially with a knowledgeable guide

Great Spanish era art. Well worth seeing as you walk around the main square. Artwork is wonderful as well as some of the silver and gold work. great to get out of the crowds or the weather if not perfect outside.
Stunning artwork. The basilica is visually beautiful, and the artwork is astounding. Each alter has a story, and are uniquely beautiful.

Interesting. Not as impressive as european churches but interesting paimtings as they are all done by incas who have never been to europe but are painting based on copying parts of other painters paintings.look for the last supper with jesus eating guinea pig and drinking the peruvisn purple vorn beer. Also the painting of mary and joseph staring at the ground instesf of baby jesus.no photos allowed inchurch.

Typical cathedral. We were lucky to be present for a religious ceremony which included a large procession in the plaza, the bishop and his staff, and the opening of the large door of the cathedral for mass. Apparently the door is open only this one day of the year.

Beautiful . The cathedral was absolutely beautiful and you did get a nice history with the included audio tour on an iPad. It had a lot of interesting facts about the Spanish invasion of Peru. We felt we learned a lot. The reason I gave it four stars was because the price was high compared to other churches/cathedrals we visited in Peru and parts of it were closed for renovations. They offered nothing off the price and asked us to just skip 10 numbers on the tour (of about 30). I was pretty disappointed with that. On a different note you are not allowed to take photos inside, so heads up on that.

Worth visiting . You will learn so much about the religious art imposed by the Spanish conquistadores. Pay attention to the Last Supper painting depicting blue corn and Guinea pig on the table. Very interesting!
Beautiful! Don't miss it when in Cusco!. The inside of the Cathedral is best experienced with a gipuide who will explain it. It is just so beautiful!

Very interesting Cusco School artwork. The Cathedral in Cusco, located directly on the Plaza de Armas, is definitely a must see attraction. The cathedral contains numerous paintings of the famed "Cusco School"- a marriage of Spanish and indigenous artistic traditions. For example, there is an interesting painting of the last supper including cuy and local fruits, and various representations of the Virgin Mary which evoke Pachamama, an Inca goddess of the earth. Well worth the cost of admission.

Mass at 8 am was inspiring. You may attend mass at 8 am weekdays. There was an amazing tenor and organist singing during the mass. Make sure you also take the tour. Lonely Planet has a very good guide to the Cathedral (started 1559) including the churches of Iglesia del Triumpo (1536) and Iglesia de Jesus Maria (1733)
Walking around the city . Gorgeous place! It is amazing to see it standing there, it is has a great view! Inside is as gorgeous as the outside!!!!!!

If churches are your thing, then come on in. Not one but three churches in one with interconnecting doors. All very highly decorated, but in different architectural styles. You may come for the black Jesus or the Last Supper of Cuy (Guinea pig) but there is also a lot of gold leaf and silver, costumed saints and deities and other artistic treasures to view.

Iglesia "BELLA". Its no wonder they call this the most beautiful church in south america! After a tour you will see why. Absolutely amazing! If you like history and architecture its well worth your time.

Simply lovely. It's a cool church; if you're into this kind of thing, you'll love it. I've mainly visited Catholic cathedrals in Europe, so it was interesting to see the Peruvian twist this one included (e.g. the Last Supper painting featuring cuy and chicha morada). It's huge and there's a lot to see; definitely recommended for a tourist in the city.

Dramatic but probably not worth the fee. Visited the cathedral as part of a city tour. As an expression of Roman Catholicism on steroids the place is hard to beat. A very impressive building with more silver and gold than you can shake a stick at. Interesting that many figures of the virgin Mary show her with a triangular dress rather than the usual robe, combining her with Pacha Mama, the earth mother.

Outstanding architecture in Plaza de Armas. This Catholic Cathredal built in competition with the nearby Jesuit cathedral is a wonderful example of extreme Andean Baroque. The main alter background is massive and extensively decorated with several tons of gold leaf as also other parts: there are also Renaissance and Gothic influences particularly in the side chapels. The picture of the last supper is unique in its prominent display of a roast Guinea pig - a Peruvian speciality. Judas has the face of Pizarro. A must visit
CATEDRAL OF CUZCO. It was a fantastic experence know The Cuzco´s Catedral . It´s a very old buiding. You should visit with friens, family and couple.

Amazing cathedral.. Built on Incan land and it was built in 1668. Lots of gold and silver altars. Amazing art work. One of my favorites is the last supper with a Guinea pig served on the dinner table. Cost us about 25 sols for the ticket to see it. Worth every cent
Very beautiful. The inside of the Cathedral is gorgeous. No pics or video allowed. There are lots of beautiful paintings, gorgeous solid silver & gold altars.

Interesting enough but would skip on hindsight. If you've visited churches and cathedrals in Europe then this would not be eye-opening or remarkable. What's interesting is perhaps the indigenous influences as depicted in the paintings - a guinea pig served at the Last Supper.

Very beautiful historic church with unique angles. It is worth seeing even though we spent maybe less than an hour. Still glad we took the time as it's arches and unique angles and history are stunning.The woodwork alone is worth the visit - beautiful.

Sunday Mass a must!. Attend Sunday Mass....hourly from 6:00, 7:00, 8:00 and 9:00 a.m. in Spanish. Tours do not start till after the masses at 10:00 a.m. through the Chapel of the Holy Family on the left side. Absolutely beautiful!

So worth seeing. This church was actually built over the time frame of three centuries. It has three very distinct parts and you can feel the time almost change as you visit the three different parts!!
Historic Church. Take a guided tour of this place. You will not regret it. Too much historic details to figure out on your own.
Visit. What a fantastic place. A guide is needed to get the best about the history. No flash photography and remember to take your hat off.
The artwork and silver work were amazing. This cathedral is massive and the artwork coupled with an altar of silver and gold throughout is awe inspiring. Well worth spending some time here.

Nice Cathedral with Lots of History. I recommend seeing the cathedral as a matter of cultural interest. A good guide kept me from getting bogged down with all the written information. Beautiful paintings!

So much history!!!. The Cathedral is located in the Plaza de Armas which is the main square of Cusco. It costs 25 soles which includes a free audio guide. I highly recommend visiting in the afternoon as it is not crowded. The audio guide takes about 45 minutes and is very detailed in explaining the history of the Cathedral as well as the city of Cusco. There's so much history and beauty to see inside the Cathedral from the paintings, to the sculptures of the Virgin Mary. I really enjoyed learning about Cusco and the Peruvian religious traditions.

Architectural jewel in Cusco - not to be missed. The most important religious place of the town, a mix of strong traditional local and influencers architecture.The place is a full museum holding paintings, sculptures, wood carving pieces.
Impressive but unfortunately no photos allowed. It is certainly an impressive building with an interesting history, just a shame you can't take photos.

Beautiful Cathedral. The Cathedral over looks the main Plaza de Armas in the centre of Cusco and is easy to find - we went with a guide, but you can easily pay the entrance fee and then have an audio tour (we saw people doing this) - Inside the Cathedral is beautiful, some of it breath taking - even if you are not religious, the sheer size of the architecture would be of interest to most visitors. If you have visited St Peter's in Rome, then this is one for you!
very interesting. I went into the church to look around and to reflect. it is an amazing place with so many things to look at.

A must-see while visiting Cusco!. Although a little bit expensive (25Soles/person) it is included a great audio tour (available in several languages). You will learn a lot of History and Art. Save at least 1h30 to visit it.

Great audio tour. There are three churches inside the cusco cathedral. I enjoyed the free audio tour in English. It was pretty easy to follow. I also enjoyed seeing the last supper painting where they are eating cuy. Many pretty things to see but no photos. Buy the religious ticket for only 30 soles and you will gain entry into this church and three others! Highly recommend.

Thsi is a great church and a must visit if in Cusco. Very beautiful church and a must visit in Cusco. You can't miss this because it's at the Plaza de Armas. Picturees inside are not allowed. the art and architecture is classic and a history buff would totally trip on this!

Beautiful church!. You have to pay the entrance, i think it was 25 soles (around $7.50), its worthy!. If you take a city tour some of them include the entrance and guide. I went by myself and I didn't need a guide because with entrance its include an audio guide. beautiful art work, amazing, if you appreciate art, this is a place for you. Very recommend it.

A huge church. The old Catholic churches have a tendency to remind me of the majesty and holiness of God and how finite we humans are, but yet, for most of them, a warm and welcoming refuge from the busyness outside. I find the 3 sanctuaries that I visited (the Cathedral, San Blas and the Convent) did not do that for me. The Cathedral, in particular, while being a huge place, and very ornately decorated, with lots of paintings and gold leaf covered sculptures, seemed to be a mish-mash of styles, and to me, a lower quality of workmanship as compared to the ones in Europe. I find it hard to place my finger on exactly why and what it is, but I came away from this visit uninspired in spirit but intellectually piqued at the contrast between the european cathedrals and this cathedral.Perhaps it is not fair to compare it against their European peers, and perhaps it is this difference that makes the visit interesting, if only to understand the differences across the ocean. At the end of the day, if you are short of time, but still want to drop by to see the churches, I would suggest to pick one - don't think you need to visit both the churches although the ticket gets you into both of them. Btw, there are free audio guides just after the entrance in the Cathedral - just remember to bring your passport as id/collateral (I used my DL instead as I did not bring my passport with me then).
Wish I could have taken pictures. This was the first church I have visited where you can not take pictures. It was a great site and I recommend the audio tour option.

Beautiful.. Such a beautiful cathedral. The tour went very quick, I feel like I missed a lot - but, the few things we stopped for, we learned a lot about. This is worth a tour on its own (we took a Cuzco city tour, so it was one of 5 stops). Be aware, all the inside venues in Peru (in our experience) were cold! Take a sweater.

A locus of regional-style religious art. Recommended for seeing how local Peruvian customs and Spanish influence of Catholocism melded. I enjoyed seeing the various paintings around the cathedral the most. The Last Supper with cuy on the table is so great!

Impressive even if you're not into churches. Construction began in 1559 and took more than 100 years to complete. The main altar, made of silver, weighs 400 kilograms. There are hundreds of paintings from, the Cusco School, which combines European and Andean subject matter and style. The most interesting (and perhaps amusing) example of this is The Last Supper by Marcos Zapata, which shows the apostles eating guinea pig. The Cathedral is interesting even if you're not into churches.

Nice if you're into Churches. Firstly I have to admit I'm not that into churches but if you are this one is worth seeing with some great paintings, lavish alters and the like.It's part of the Cusco City tour where you'll see 5 other sites for around 25 Sol not including entrance fees to the 2 churches and the Boleto Touristico that you'll need for the other 4 sites.

Cathedral of Cusco. Of the Cathedrals I visited in Lima, Arequipa, Cusco, the Cusco Cathedral was most highly decorated with statues of the Saints adorned in the most colorfull attire, with different colored allaborate arrangements of gladiolas thoughout the already fabulous stucture. We just so happened up during the Corpus Cristy festival and it was a very special sight. Cathedrals are one of my favorite places to visit anywhere in the world
Basilica Interesting. The Center of Cusco is the Plaza de Armas crowned by the Basilica. Typical architecture of the time, but still an interesting visit.
impressive. it's ornate and well preserved. Not tippy top by Spanish standards, but very nice. Free before 9am so that's when to go.

Beautiful church. This church really is beautiful, and I'm sure it plays a major part in the local community's spiritual life. However, it is unlike any Catholic Church I have ever been in, since the hierarchy has allowed the Inca cultured to be incorporated into the religion, some of which seems contrary to Catholicism overall. However, it IS worth seeing, and don't miss the last supper painting Inca style!

unique. Three major churches connected to each other is unusual if not unique. The colonial and baroque styles take one back to this period in history when missionaries were promoting a foretaste of heaven. At the same time the famous painting of the Last Supper incorporates guinea pig and other local food elements. Commentators suggest Judas has a likeness to Pizarro, a provocative interpretation. . .

Cool cathedral, lots of gold but cost 25 sol just to see . We visited the cathedral as part of the city tour. While it was an beautiful cathedral I didn't think it was a better part of the city tour. I liked the other sites much more and found then to be more fascinating..

Beautiful. Very different from European churches. Worth a visit just to see the different artwork and how they treat their subjects. For example the picture of the last supper has a dish of Guinea pig not fish.
Must Be Seen. The contrasting artwork, architecture and cultures of the South American peoples and Spanish Catholic Church make for a unique fusion that should be seen first hand

Cusco Peru Tour. We took the tour with Cusco-Peru.com, which included a walking guided tour of Cusco historical sites and among them the Catedral del Cuzco. We were able to visit all the important sites with the tour guide explaining the history of every place.
Great cathedral. Not only the outside, the inside is very beautiful too. A lot of paintings and sculptures are exhibited.

Beautiful . This cathedral is divided into 3 different churches. It's a little expensive to get in but an audio tour is included in the price. If recommend doing the audio tour (even though I never do those!) because it's only 45 mins and it is quite informative. Plus you already paid for it so you might as well!
Three churches in one. This was an interesting cathedral. It is not expensive to enter and the architecture and iconography is very impressive. You should really check it out if you're in Cusco.

Impressive that it was build so long ago in a remote area. Well, you seen one cathedral you've seen them all so to speak; at least that's my opinion. I guess the one impressive thing is the fact that the area was so remote when construction started and was completed centuries ago.
Very nice. It's a beautful cathedral with lots of interesting paintings and architecture...assuming you are in the city anyway, it's pretty much a must-do.
amazing interior a must see. veru unusual deisgn. never seen catherdral as this anywhere else. painting tecnique is unreal super beautiful and rich
Churches. Very much enjoyed the tour of 5 churches(package deal) but wish we had a tour guide to explain more about the church's... A few had iPads that u could use to learn about the church.

Interesting to walk through.. The doors were open before a service and we spent a few minutes walking around inside. The architecture is interesting, though the entire place is technically a testament to the destruction of the Inca Empire. We should have used our Boleta Touristica to actually tour the churches and learn a little more of Cusco's post-conquest history.
Beautiful Cathedral. This cathedral has a rich history and is lovely. It is truly worth a visit, even though I am sure you have visited at least 100 cathedrals on your South American adventure.

Very Impressive. We visited the Cathedral as part of our tour with Alexander and Roberts. Our tour guide was born and raised in the Cusco area and was very familiar with the history of the church. The main Cathedral and the smaller Chapels are amazing. Everything is very large with the altars and side rooms decorated with a lot of gold and silver. The craftsmanship is beautiful. This a very peaceful and moving place that is well worth the stop. There are no photographs allowed inside the church.

WOW!!. This is a must see. Inside photos are not allowed. Beautiful altars. One made of gold, One made of silver. We had gone in as part of a tour group but then went in the next morning on our own and attended mass.

Very impressive inside. We visited this today and the inside of the cathedral was very impressive. Inside it looks larger than what is appears from the outside. The entrance fee was S30 each (appx US$9.09).
Amazing!. A must on your sightseeing stops in Cuzco. Of course it's going to be better if you have a guide that can explain things to you.

Beautiful artwork and historic site. I visited the cathedral as part of the tour but you can visit on your own as it has audio guides.
It is huge with lots of beautiful paintings, sculptures. Lots to see and take your time exploring the various sections and domes. Memorable visit.

Fascinating Cathedial in Cusco historical area.. A huge Cathedral that will interest Catholic and non-Catholic alike. The highlight for me was seeing a painting of The Last Supper with a Guinea Pig as the main course.

A huge colonial building filled with magnificent art. The Cathedral is of very large dimensions. You can visit on your own since the audio guide in several languages is of very good quality. The church is filled with magnificent paintings, sculptures and precious metal decorations anywhere. You must pay a entrance fee, which you could buy in the form of a ticket that includes entrance to other very interesting religious and artistic buildings administered by the archdiocese,
absolutely beautiful. We went with a guide and it was beautiful. Great history, interesting art and the area was fun to hang out.

Lots to see inside. You are not suppose to take pictures. Since I went there for Mass, I missed seeing the sign and took pics and didn't see the "no photos" sign until I was about to leave. Mass has good music but lack of worshipping community feel. Too bad priest didn't even come meet the people and only a few went up to receive Eucharist.

The art work is AMAZING. The Inca artists were impressive of blending their beliefs with Catholicism. The last supper with Guinea pig and fruits and vegetables of Peru. The best was Francisco Piszro face on Judas. Also the choir loft carvings were a treat.

Truly stunning!. This is a really stunning cathedral. The side altars are awesome. The paintings are amazing...a fabulous "Last Supper" painting, with a roasted Guinea Pig shown as the main course! Really, even if you are not a cathedral goer, see this one. It is really worth the visit.

A nice bit of history . A little expensive at 25 Sol but it is a must visit as the audio tour only takes 45 minutes but gives you a good overview. Take your passport as deposit for the audio equipment.

Staff was terrible and disgusting. Structure and Interior is good but staff was disgusting and terrible. One woman staff was really irritating and rude.This was not a singleness experience like this in Cusco. I guess this is one of basic characteristic of Cusco. I don't like Cusco's such characteristic.

One of the most interesting churches I've ever visited.. I did the audio tour here and it was very well done and very informative. It took about 45 minute to an hour. There are 3 distinctly different sections in here and each one has a very different style. The largest church, the one with the beautiful fronting on the plaza, is breathtaking. I think the most interesting thing is seeing all the different influences and the ways that the religious artwork and stories were "localized". Very memorable sight to see!

Beautiful and detailed historical place.. Would really liked to have taken pictures. So much to see. Excellent work. I understand their need to protect and raise money, but maybe we could make a contribution. Not many choices for remember antes at gift shop. Enjoyed the tour.

Stunning. You shouldn't miss a visit to this exquisite cathedral. They offer headsets for a fee, but I recommend hiring a tour guide so you can have an interactive discussion. There are so many things to see inside this massive church, so leave yourself time or plan a second visit.
Cuzco Catedral. The Catedral was beautiful and the history was interesting. Helped to learn about the culture of Cuzco. Well worth the visit.
Architectural beauty. Enjoy this wonderful cathedral and the history of its construction. It is fully operational with daily masses.
Plaza De Armes. in the center of Cusco, at the Plaza De Armes, is the Basillica Cathedral and cretainly a look in; a visit, will be woth your time
Stunning!. Awe-inspiring. Made me cry. Such history and beauty. Can not be passed up. This is only one of many to see. Good way to pass the time while scrolling through this lovely city.

Amazing Cathedral. This is a truly grand cathedral. There is no hint from the outside about the grandeur that lies within. While it is a spiritual place, it's artworks make you feel like you're in a world class museum.
On a plaza. Visited this church with a tour group. There are many rooms and altars, a gift shop and a catacomb that can be visited.

the most beautiful place. It was amazing. All altars, paintings and history behind them was a fantastic lesson. The most intriguing was the Last Supper by local painter Marcos Zapata. The Cathedral is enormous in size with golden and silver altars.
Gorgeous. Well worth having a guide or renting head phones to understand the amazing paintings, etc. One of the most beautiful cathedrals we've seen in our travels.

Its 25 soles now. Its 25 soles now to visit on its own or via the boleta religioso. They covered the whole inside so you cannot peak in so that you are required to get a ticket to see inside. You will notice cusco plaza de armas alone has probably 6+ churches. Some are free to go inside or at least peak in. We didnt buy a ticket but i bet its cool looking inside. Its nice to see at night! The plaza and everything around it is lighted.
Beautiful. Classic colonial Spanish architecture with a beautiful altar and magnificent artwork. We were lucky enough to be there on a Sunday and were able to attend mass, a very moving experience.
Wonderful. Unfortunately, the mine workers were occupying the square, but the door to the Catedral was open - what a nice offset to the workers outside

Must see while in Cusco. Plan to attend mass before 9am to avoid the visitor charge and the crazy crowds. We had the opportunity to also see the Cathedral as part of a tour group but the crowds made it difficult to enjoy the beauty of the Basilica and the amazing paintings and alters.

Nice cathedral . Overall this cathedral is quite nice there is plenty to see and experience. However, the policy of "no pictures or video " is a bit much. Having traveled the world this was a first for me and the signage reminding visitors was of poor taste and qualify. As another reviewer stated, don't fret if you miss this cathedral.
Pretty. Very pretty, but you can see equally lovely cathedrals in other cities. This isn't where I'd spend my time in Peru, with all the fantastic ruins.

Good for rainy day . We joined a City Tour that included the cathedral so had a guide providing history of various features of it - really interesting - includes a car made of silver that is still taken out for Corpus Christi day parade

Beautiful Cathedral. This is a beautiful cathedral that is worth a visit. It is a church with several gold plated altars. It was very interesting to see the Black Christ and we were lucky to be there when there was a procession to change the flowers at the altar of the Black Christ.

Beautiful and well preserved. After visiting many churches across Europe, I was blown away by the Cathedral in Cusco. It is gorgeous and so well taken care of. The audio guide gives great information.

too expensive. will be like other big churhces but very expensive no one peruvian cant visist wiht 9 dollars just for one hour, i think have to be a special price for the local people even for the tourist is expensive

Overpriced. Don't be upset if you miss it. Anyone that has traveled will know that the cathedral is a standard tourist draw card.
If you have seen a few, you will not be blown away by this.
The price is ridiculous compared to everything else you can do for the same money.
If you do it, do it as part of a guided tour

Breathtsking. This is the absolute highlight of the historic center of Cusco. I went with a guide who offered so many interesting stories of how the the Catholics integrated some Incan ideas and symbolism to offer an olive branch to the locals. It's all incredibly beautiful. Be warned, no photos inside.
Impressive. This is a must if you go to Cuzco, it is a really impressive construction with list of painting inside. They have mass everyday at 7 or 8 am and before 9 am the entrance is free.
Amazing metalwork & craftmanship. Highly recommend you get the audio guide - this is a bit of a labyrinth, so having some guidance really helps. Incredible craftmanship throughout.

Very interesting, a lot of art and history. It is a beautiful cathedral, there is a lot to see and if you take the time to read about it there is a lot of interesting facts and history within its walls. There are plenty of guides available as you enter but many of them tell you just the basics or even nonsense. Audio guides are available for free, maybe, when we went there were none left. Even without a guide one can still get a lot out of the visit if you take your time and go through the various areas within the church.You can get the multi pass and see several other churches as well as various museums around town.
Beautiful cathedral made all the better by a guide. We has a guide for one of our days in Cusco. This was very helpful especially at this cathedral that has so much history and story.

Wow, what a bling bling!. Gold, gold, gold. Odd Mixture of pre-Inca, Inca and Catholicism. It hurt my eyes. Our guide told us you never know if the valley people come here to worship the catholic god, coz the Spanish ruined all the Inca-temples and build their churches on the fundaments you can still see. So maybe they come here coz the places are still sacred. There were Indian women singing in old Inca language. So...how catholic are the people really here? I wonder. I think there's an old Inca hiding in almost everyone here. I found it very interesting!
Three Cathedrals in one. Had a look. The entry fee includes a headphone tour which is pretty interesting. Plenty to see and reflect on with a Peruvian take on Crists journey.

Excellent inside with great paintings and historic artifacts. Very nice inside. Can spend a lot of time inside as the paintings and statues are well laid out and lots of interesting history. A guide helps if you only speak english. Very nice.

Picturesquely positioned big Catolic Cathedral in Cusco. Impressively decorated Catolic Cathedral within heart of Cusco. Best to visit with a guide and spent some time admiring frescoes and services. Mixture of traditional and local painting with Guinea pig for a Last Supper and Black Christ are very original and memorable

Three Cathedrals in one. This is actually three Cathedrals, side by side.I strongly recommend getting a guide. We had a very pleasant woman who spoke fluent English and was very knowledgable both about the Cathedral and the overall history of Cusco. She made all the difference - we spent several hors.You must see the famous painting of the Last Supper with a cooked guinea-pig on the table instead of bread!

Larger inside than it looks outside. This church is very similar to the way cool churches that we find in our European travels. Can't say that I have seen any other paintings of the Final Supper with Jesus eating a Guinea Pig anywhere else but here.........

Beautiful, mix of two cultures, good audio guide. This is a must! There is a free audio guide which walks you through the three churches. It is clear, intetersting, and to the point. I would definitely recommend it.Additionally, this is a great place to see how the two cultures came together. From the mirrors, to the saints, to some of the paintings.
Inspiring mass. We went to mass in this beautiful cathedral. It was mostly locals. It was very inspiring to be so welcomed.

Huge, Beautiful Cathedral. The main cathedral, already huge in itself, is flanked by two other altars which are bigger than most churched. The altars glisten with gold and silver taken from Inka temples by the Spaniards. They are marvels of metal work as well. There is a middle section to the middle church which contains wood carvings for the niches along the walls which rival the best european cathedrals.There is even one silver altar mounted on motorized wheels do that it can be used in processions.There is significant art work throughout the cathedral as well.A must see in Cuzco.No photography allowed. Wheelchair friendly. Kids might just like the glitter snd gold.
Cathedral . Should visit since it is the first cathedral in the Americas in spite of the 25 soles. It is actually three churches in one.

A beautiful example of Colonial Architecture. A must see edifice on the Plaza de Armas in the very heart of Cusco. There is an entrance fee, but free guides offer their services once inside the cathedral - and their advice, as well as the cathedral's collections of Incan and colonial art, are utterly worth it.

Breathtaking!. I'm not exaggerating. When I entered the cathedral, I actually lost my breath it was so beautiful. Everything here is intricately carved in wood then overlaid with either gold or silver. The place is also filled with mirrors and everything sparkles. Be sure to have a tour guide to explain everything (like the reason for the mirrors or the story about the black Jesus and his significance to earthquakes). I also noticed that if you didn't have a guide, you could get a headset and I'm guessing you can get all the information that way also. No pictures are allowed inside.

Stunning Cathedral on Par with the Best in Europe. We were really surprised by the stunning beauty of this Cathedral. Very different than others we've seen around the world. Our Gate 1 guide Gary did an excellent job bringing the art work alive. The Last Supper painting with the guinea pig main course was great.

Catedral del Cuzco is a must for all visitors. On entry we were approached by a young lady offering her services as a guide. She was excellent and we learnt so much more about the cathedral. Her charge was 30 sol and well worth it. Beautiful church and so much history. Paintings and carvings very skilfully produced all those years ago. Such a pleasure to visit this wonderful church.

Don't miss it!. The Cuzco Cathedral is one of the prettiest cathedrals we have in Peru, on my last trip to Cuzco I decided to visit it again.This time I was really surprised by it.The ticket is 25 soles per person, around 7 dollars.After paying the ticket go to look for you audio guide, it is free and they will give you and iPad , look for your language and just visit the cathedral.There are many art works that are explain in the iPad and it is good to learn more this easy way.There are many attractions in Cuzco and this was my favorite on my last trip.Really don't miss it, it looks like many cathedrals I have visited around the world.

A sight so beautiful in all its glory!. I have never seen a Catedral so beautiful! The murals, the depictions of Jesus in painting, on the wall and hanging on the cross, are just breath-taking. The gold features add to its beauty. However, the best part about the Catedral, appearance put aside, is the feeling I experienced when I entered through its doors. You can see by its details, the love that was put into the making of the Catedral. You can tell by the manner in which they talk about its history that it is well-respected, cherished and loved and you can feel from being in the church a spiritual presence. Just like the Salkantay trek to Machu Picchu, it is a beautiful site, a worthy place to entertain and a humbling experience in its own nature.

Such a nice cathedral. South America is filled with nice buildings, churches and cathedrals. This one is one but not just anyone. It was created in 1559 and it's still standing. It is possible ti visit the place and if you do you will notice a lot of things that do not have anything to do with religion. Things like why it was built that way, the kind of technique they used and many more. It also is right in the Plaza de Armas sector which gives it a particular look. I am not so much into churches and cathedrals but seeing those wonders throughout the countries I have visited makes me think some people had a «vision» of what could be done. Please treat yourself and take a tour around the Catedral del Cuzco or also named Catedral Basilica de la Virgen de la Asuncion. Enjoy my friends !

Nice church. The church is really nice and the 25 soles for the entrance is ok. It's just bad that it's not allowed to take pictures. Why you have something so beautiful but you can't share it?Therefore only 4 stars.

Good examples of Cusco style of art. It would probably take a week to see and look at every piece of art in the cathedral: about 1 hour is enough to understand the basic foundations of the Cusco style. A good local guide is a must as they can point out the main points of interest and really bring the paintings to life.
very nice very golden. This is a nice old church, a must see in cusco, located in the heart of the old City. surrounded by other ancient bulidings.
Stunning. Beautiful cathedral that is right in the centre of town. A real insight into the Spanish occupation, but very impressive none the less.
Luxury. The Basilica truly shows the opulence of the Spanish. Intricate gold and silver works coupled with religious artifacts.

Beautiful Choir. Overall I was gravely disappoint with the Cathedral, but it had one redeeming feature, the magnificent choir section. Intrinsically carved out of wood, it is a masterpiece and dominated the nave of the church. It made up for the disappointment of the rest of the church. Also included in the joint ticket with San Blas and Museo Arzobispal.

Grand ol cathedral. Very large, immense even, open Cathedral filled with many artifacts from the last 300 years. You need to go with a guide or pick up the recorded Tour to hear and see everything. There are several paintings and statues which show a mix of both Inca and Catholic religion's. There are three large areas not including the small crypt under the main altar and the huge organ and the large woodcarved choir area. The day we went, the cathedral was somewhat crowded. So we came back in the evening and there was a wedding going on. We walked in and were allowed to sit and watch as the ceremony proceeded sometimes in Spanish and some times in Kichwas. I think I might have heard Latin also. Gorgeous affair

Gold and art-filled Spanish-Peruvian catholic Basilica. The Spanish stole the Incan gold. They left 2 tons in this cathedral. It is amazing and reminded me of the cathedral in Seville. It is filled with Catholic religious art and the Cuquena school (mixed between Incan and Spanish). Go there with a guide. It was great to see the "last supper" with cuy (guinea pig) and Mary interpreted as Pachamama. What makes this different from Europe is that is a living, breathing church filled with practicing parishioners. It is truly a special place.
Peaseful. Very charming place, get to see much in a short while. There are guides and also time for yourselve.Cool plase to see.

Awe inspiring. The cathedral was amazing. I went on a Sunday so there was a full church service. It was all in Spanish but I stayed and listened and the choir boys sounded beautiful. The service and singing moved me and I am not a religious person. It looks like they spent millions on silver in their decorating and there are no words to describe it, you need to see it. My only negative is that I bought candles out the front to light for loved ones but when inside the only candle lighting was by coins for electric candles.

Grand remnant of Catholic indoctrination. Spanish colonial heritage of introducing Catholic Churches in Inca region of Peru. Local culture incorporated into Roman Catholic religion for early indoctrination of Peruvians in 15th Century !
Stunning!. If you have even a few free minutes in Cuzco, the Catedral del Cuzco is a must see! Three churches in one - absolutely unbelievable.
You should see all the silver!. This is a beautiful cathedral with a main alter that will knock your socks off. The alter is covered in over a ton of silver!
Very nice cathedral. This place is in main square. The paintings and the architecture was breath taking. Just the amount of gold that was used in this building validates the myth of el dorado...
Fascinating cathedral. Don't miss the painting of the last supper with new world foods, including guinea pig (cuy), corn, etc. Beautiful.

The biggest church in Cusco. The Cathedral is a complex which has three churches in one. It has a valuable collection of Escuela Cusqueña paintings. You must see "The Last Supper": instead of a lamb, Jesus and his Apostles ate Cuy (Guinea pig)

Amazing but would not do it with Viator. Cusco is one of the jewels of the World Heritage list. We just recently made the trip but our itineraries were with others that Viatron; glad we did not use Viatron because this outfit outsources to different travel companies in Peru, and have NO IDEA what those Peruvian companies are doing. Regardless of my experience Cusco is Great, but one must handle high altitude well. Take some local remedies, like coca leaves at the airport, and drink coca tea. It will help. You will need 3 to 4 days to acclimate even when you go first to Sacred Valley. High Altitude sickness will come back upon your return to Cusco. The Catedral is amazing. Somebody knew how to get money to build it. You will not be allowed to take any pictures or movies as there will be swarms of security folks in plain clothes to watch you, so do not do it. There are half a dozen of other churches in Cusco for those with religious interest but no mosques, and no synagogues (at least not on the map). And, pork is a staple food with excellent potatoes and veggies. Beer is local.. This is a old city. The streets are mostly one way and so narrow that a person with large hips can stop the traffic (no kidding, I saw it..lol).The city is full of excellent restaurant but you may need reservations to get it, especial to the ones around Plaza de Armas. Take a trip to Sacsayhuaman. The bird's eye view of Cusco is great. You will survive a stopover at a local sweater from alpaca shop..:0
Cathedral del Cuzco. The Cathedral is worth visiting just to see the architectural work both inside and out. Make sure you check out the ceilings and the Lord's Last Supper painting.

Absolutely amazing!!. I have visited many churches and cathedrals around the world, including those in Rome and the Holy Land and this isn't just any cathedral as one reviewer indicated. The cathedral "complex" includes the Holy Family Church, the Basilica, and the Triumphs Church. For 50 soles pp (includes audio tour), you can tour the entire cathedral which is BEAUTIFUL.
