There is so much history and artwork in this complex!! Altar pieces of gold and silver, beautiful statues and paintings...VERY worth the ticket price!! The audio tour is like a little iPad so you can replay any site if you want and go at your own pace. It also includes a video as you listen to the commentary which gives you a better closeup of artwork and additional information. My husband and I shared one audio tour and had individual headsets. Beware!! As we entered the cathedral, a tour guide was offering his services -- luckily we realized our ticket included a complimentary audio tour. Very, very interesting. I would say it's a must do in Cusco...you will learn a lot about the Spanish conquest in Peru and how the Incan heritage has influenced the Catholic traditions in this region.
Peru. A beautiful church with so much history! Very ornate and detailed with beautiful art. The car is especially interesting!

Beautiful. Stunning architecture and history. You can take a tour inside, which my father did and he said the audio-guided experience was excellent. Located in the plaza de armas right in the centre of Cusco, it is easy to get to and surrounded by lots of shops and restaurants.

Beautiful cathedral. The Catedral del Cuzco o Catedral Basilica de la Virgen de la Asuncion is a very beautiful and interesting. We have visited many cathedrals in Europe and the Cusco Cathedral is interesting for many cultural reasons. Obviously the cathedral is built on a former Inca sight and the Inca's were virtually forced to accept Catholicism. Our guide in the cathedral told the story of how the Priests used mirrors to convince the Inca's that their soul was now in the cathedral and they must return to avoid losing their souls. Still a lot of Inca culture is mixed into the Catholic religion of today.
Incredible Cathedral. Excellent artwork and other items. well worth a visit. The amazing feeling inside was not at all expected from outside - large and imposing, but full of surprises inside!
Very nice Kathedral. This is a very nice Kathedral in the middle of cusco. If you go in one of the Kathedral you have seen them all ! But just to walk through its very pleasant

Amazing Cathedrals!!! . I was amazed. Huge pieces of art, hand worked wooden structures. I'm not a religious nut, but it's nice to observe even if your not religious. You can get a ticket to visit others the same day. I made a day of it :)
Worth it. Very imposing amazing artwork and internal decor. Outside doesn't look like but inside is simply amazing don't miss it!
This is a Must. If you were in Cusco and did not go to see this Catheral you missed out big time. In side it has a great display of paiting and its awesome how they depict history so well.

High On The "Wow" List. Photography is not allowed inside but do not put you off from visiting this Cathedral. It is high on the ‘wow’ list with all the gold and silver objects and altar. Don't miss the painting of the Last Supper that has a guinea pig on the table center.

Amazing church. The beauty of this place is stunning.!! If you need to visit only one in cusco, definitely do this one. The audioguide is included in the price of the tickets. The architecturte and the details of the art are fabulous. Dont miss this one! Its totally worth it and you can have a nice student discount if you are under 26 with your student card.

Half Church Half Museum - must see in Cusco. The Cathedral in Cusco is by far one of the, if not the, most impressive of all of Peru. Not only the sheer size, three churches in one, but one of the largest collections of Escuela Cusquena paintings, that rival El Greco, Velasquez and Zurbaran, to be found in a public place in Peru. The audio guide system is also one of the best i have seen in any museum in the world, and really allows you to see all there is to see and then you can still see more on your own, even though they ask to limit the visit to 1.5 hours. Only during this last visit I also learned that the cathedral houses the original cross brought to Peru by the friar accompanying Pizarro during the conquest of Peru. Definitely the history of christianization in Peru is not without questioning and doubtlessly the Spaniards committed horrible crimes in the name of civilization vs. savages, but even as a non-believer, I am most times in awe when visiting the cathedral in Cusco, a feeling only few churches in the world can cause with me.

All that is wrong with the Catholic Church…. Basically this is a Catholic show piece and I came away not impressed, simply because it was so over the top in terms of design and execution. In many ways this show of glitz does nothing to support Christianity, more akin to Disney. So sorry, have to mark this place down because I came away sick. Not because of the altitude, but because the money would be better spent helping the people outside who were begging.

Beautiful Altar, great view from the top. This Cathedral is lovely and has a beautiful alter gilded in gold. Once you enter, behind the altar on the left there is a ladder that you can climb to the top and look out onto the Plaza. A good view and worth the climb,

A Magnificent Cathedral. This cathedral is located right on the main plaza and is a richly appointed and magnificent church that is well worth a visit. Photos are not allowed, so be prepared. The melding of christianity and Incan culture and beliefs are melded and can be found here.
Wow. There is really no point in writing anything about this Cathedral. It does not matter if you are religious or atheist... It's just an amazing piece of many items that make this truly amazing.,
This is a must see!. The cathedral was a definite highlight of our trip. It is very beautiful and the artistry is beyond belief. If you go to Cusco do not miss this.
tourist. Beautiful walk in the main square where tourists and locals can sit and enjoy the scenery, some local artists selling their works but not too pushy and always friendly
Get a good tour guide. Was feeling a bit saturated with churches but had a wonderful guide who explained history and links to Quechuan background. Loved it!

Great place to visit - do the audio tour!. The Cathedral is beautiful- and yes, it does cost 30 soles to enter, but they include a really wonderful audio guide, and you get entrance to the two churches surrounding the Cathedral as well as four other beautiful churches in the area. Definitely recommend- especially if its hot out, its a nice hour break in exchange for a ton of art/cultural information.

Beautiful Inside. What a beautiful church inside with its 3 main sections. Takes a little over an hour to walk through with a guide to explain everything. We were there for Easter and it was beautifully decorated. Just love all the flowers. Amazing to see how well preserved it is and to see all its beauty!

Nice but nothing to rave about. We should probably have taken a guide for this visit. We only found out after the visit that there was an audio guide available. It was definitely not worth the 25 PEN admission.

Very Opulent. Obviously this is the main historical building in Cusco as nothing is left of the Inca civilization. It has many sculptures, statues and art work made by local artists for the church over the centuries. It's quite beautiful and opulent. If you don't have a guide they offer a free audio guide.
One of Favs. The Cathedral is one of my favorites in the world. Unfortunately, you now have to pay to get in. But it's worth it once inside.
Can visit if you have time. It was very close to out hotel.You have to do the visit with guide, otherwise will feel totally lost.

Go alone or even with a guided tour. This place was so beautiful full of artworks and the famous black jesus. I was truly moved by the history explained to us by our tour guide so I do suggest that option. I went back on my own a couple of times during my stay in cusco to admire this place some more
Beautiful, but No Photo's Allowed :(. Gorgeous inside. Great mix of European and Incan art. Sad that you can't take photos, even without flash.

Three Churches in One. On our tour of Cuzco we were taken to this magnificent cathedral. We were taken in a small door on the side of the cathedral to the first church within the church! It was breathtaking & as we progressed through the cathedral, it became more and more breathtaking with its opulence. The cathedral is closed between 6am -10 am to tourists for services, but it is must see!

¡Spectacular Cathedral!. Spectacular cathedral with a great style, the art, sculpture and architecture have amazing beautiful aspects from the gold relics. You must taking your time so you can enjoy the detail if you like architecture.
History lovers must see.. Beautiful Cathedral. So much history. Audio tour with admission. Great value. A "don't miss" opportunity!
Beautiful. Beautiful views and history. I admit that the Incas should have never let the Spaniards this close to Cusco but you can't revert history. This Basilica is pretty to look at.

Ok if you're Catholic . The entrance fee includes an audio guide which I am sure is as good as paying for a personal guide. The cathedral and adjoining 2 churches are included. It was supposed to open at 10am but was over 15 mins late. However, the inside is quite impressive if overly ornate in the usual Catholic manner. Shame no photos allowed.
Views are incredible!!!. The history is phenomenal and photographers would love this area. The churches and they're architecture where beautiful. and incredibly large
Dark cathedral. OK to visit, but you can't wear shorts! Apparently God is offended by exposed knees. Very dark interior. It's an average cathedral but if you haven't seen many then it's ok

Incredible beauty, breath taking!. The beautiful artwork and architecture are not to be missed. The audio tour was very good and a wonderful asset to understanding the magnificent beauty in the cathedral. This was one of my favorites! We bought a multi ticket including several tour sights, it was a cost savings and we were not disappointed.

Outstanding historical collection of fine art. This is a must see in Cusco! The free audio guides are available and very useful. Otherwise, you can hire a guide ( usually one waiting just at entrance) . The explanations on the audio guide were very helpful and necessary to truly appreciate the scope of the collection.

Worth it to hire a guide. Bought the religious ticket for 4 churches/museums for $20 and hired a guide for 30 sols. Well worth it to hear the history of the oldest cathedral in South America and the link to the Incas, as mentioned no photos inside and the ticket did not include the other church in the plaza

Incredible paintings. The famous painting of the last supper with cuy (Guinea pig) is in the cathedral, along with a host of other paintings from the Cusco school (style of painting). Fascinating, even if you aren't an art buff.

Worth A Look. It was worth the look, there are english speaking attendants if needed. Steep stairs to the higher level so be careful, they are very old. Great view of the Town Square from the top. Enjoy
Church visit. Beautiful church be ready to pay if you want to know the history, no English literature available so hire a guide if you must.

Beautiful cathedral. We visited the cathedral on a Sunday. The cathedral was packed with worshippers. It was fascinating to see the devotion that was on display in the cathedral. A very spiritual experience.
Very nice. I was here during a festival and didnt get to see the inside as I would have liked. The architecture is great. Located on the main square.
The Best. One of the best cathedrals in the world I have ever visited even beats the Vatican.The history and architecture is just amazing we had a great tour giude from View Peru.

Speechless Beauty. As a Catholic living in the United States, touring some of these sights that have such significant Spiritual Beauty as well and having been Lovingly Preserved for much longer then my country has even been able to call itself a country is absolutely amazing. Even if you are not a religious person, I would highly recommend touring and hearing the history that goes with such a beautiful place that is still being actively used today.

You can't miss this national treasure!. The cathedral is stunning in itself, but inside marvel and treasure await with some of the most magnificent art work you will ever see - and especially inside a religious building. Set aside some time because you will need it to soak in this amazing historical experience.

Church charged admission!. Beautiful church that has i pads for you to use when you pay the entrance fee. Quite tech savvy! Great program on the i pad but difficult to rush through it when some of my group did not wish to pay therefore missed seeing the church! I did not want to keep the group waiting and we ended up walking part way then taxi to the hotel.

Spectacular Cathedral!. The Cathedral in Central Cusco is a prime example of the opulence of the conquering Spanish missionaries. Gold, sliver and beautiful artistic works of local craftsmen. The recommendations to hire a guide for the Cathedral are spot on. There is so much to see and appreciate. No pictures are allowed inside the church. At the end of your tour there is a small gift kiosk where you can purchase excellent books on the history and memorable photographs of the cathedral. Take several hours to absorb the site.

Wow! Wow! and Wow!. The outside of this cathedral is incredible and the history behind the many different architectural styles it was build with over a 100 year period are just as impressive, but what is extremely impressive are the artifacts and architecture and history on the inside of the cathedral. Although there are no photos allowed inside, your mouth will drop when you enter this amazing cathedral. Well worth the visit!

Highlight of my trip to Cusco. The cathedral is one of the most over the top of all the over the top South American Catholic cathedrals. Gold, silver, elaborate carvings, and art abound. Definitely hire a guide to explain the place to you. Otherwise you might miss the Last Supper with the Guinea pig as the main dish and Francisco Pizarro as Judas, or the black Earthquake Jesus that occasionally wears the colors of the local soccer team, or the silver altar that can be driven around. You can't take pictures, but the church ladies sell post cards and calendars that are reasonably priced, and have pictures of the things you're likely to want to show your friends when you get home.

So much to see. There are so much to see, digest and understand in the Catedral del Cuzco. No photos are allow so it's worth taking your time to enjoy the ornate decor, all the religious icon and the styles. It's worthwhile to join a tour or hire a guide so you will appreciate the background and history.

Beautiful. I got engaged here so this place holds a very special place in my heart. It's beautiful and offers a really nice recorded tour to inform you on all the beautiful architecture and historical significance.
Magnificent cathedral. Cuzco is a beautiful city and the Cathedral well worth a visit. Photography is not allowed inside. It has been well looked after and is in excellent condition.

Wonderful History. It was well worth the visit but I really don't understand why they don't allow photos. How can you show others what is so good about the place without any evidence. Taking photos without a flash would not hurt the art work anymore than the natural light that is there. So you will just have to go and see for yourself.

Amazingly interior. No photographs allowed but just take everything in. Interesting use of mirrors and hidden pre conquistadors religious symbols. The decor is lavish but some how peaceful. There are toilets and gift shops close by.

Amazing altars and art work. Miguel our guide took us through the Cathedral and it was amazing. The altars flanking the 3 parts of the Cathedral are works of art. There are more than 1000 paintings on the Cathedral walls. Having a guide gave us more to appreciate!

Beautiful old Church. The cathedral is several hundred years old. The exterior architecture and interior furnishings and artwork are exquisite. Don't miss the painting of the Last Supper that has a guinea pig in the table center as the last meal.

Gorgeous Church Teaming with History. Unfortunately, pictures aren't permitted, but that might be a benefit if it forces you look more with your eyes. If possible, have a tour guide explain the history and significance of the rich symbolism and exquisite architecture. If that's not an option, the Cathedral's beauty speaks for itself.
Another Catedral. Nice ..think I'm a bit jaded from so many!Lovely building in the main square was lucky to catch the Cusco municipal band playing on the steps!
Impressive. The most spectacular Cathedral I have seen in the Americas-specially the inside. The altar, the choir, the pulpit-all very impressive.

Good view of the PLaza. One of the most obvious landmarks in Plaza dr Armas. Sure after spending some time in Peru/Cusco u may think this is just another old church which is trueHowever u get to walk up 2 the towers on the side through some very small stair cases to get a good view of the plazaGood spot if ur a photographer

Stunning surprise. We paid 15 soles for a student ticket giving access to the Cathedral, but also 3 or 4 other historical buildings including a small palace, which we found to be good value. The cathedral is massive, stunning and very elaborate. Coupled with the audio tour included, this was a perfect part of our time in Cusco; worth doing even if you only have a day in the city.

Once inside you will be amazed.. Once inside you will be amazed by the size of this church. The paintings by local artist hold a fascinating part of the relationship between the locals and the church.

Very interesting church and artwork. Admission to this church was included in a package, so I can't speak to the cost, but this was a highlight of my visit to Cusco. First, I had a great guide - Alberto Chara - and he really made the visit worthwhile, especially explaining the artwork. Most of the paintings were created in the 1700's and were supervised by the Spanish but were executed by the local Inca natives. Either on purpose or by accident, there are several paintings with Inca symbols inserted. For example, the large painting of the Last Supper has a guinea pig as the centerpiece on the table in front of Jesus. The guinea pig is a Peruvian delicacy and of course, was not present at the time of the actual Last Supper. Items like that are scattered throughout the cathedral and you'd miss them without a good tour guide or book.The only reason this doesn't receive five stars is they prohibit photography, something the main cathedral in Lima doesn't prohibit.

Impressive church. A rather imposing church filled with artwork, shrines and statues. The intricate stonework of the building was extraordinary. We went during a service; the atmosphere as the priest was giving his sermon in the cavernous surroundings was impressive.

Good place to visit but Pricy!. Cuzco is unreasonably pricy. Cathedral is one of the example. We bought the tourist package (expansive already!) as most visitors do--only to find that many must-sees are not included. The Cathedral itself is great to visit but 20 euro is ridiculous.

Beautiful Church and Art. If possible have a tour guide take you to the church. The church has so much history and the art work is amazing. I am not one to like tour guides but on this occasion it was great to have someone explain the art and the differing features of an American Catholic Church/religion and a Peruvian Catholic Church/religion. Really amazing history!

Stunning. At the entry point we decided to hire a tour guide (in the end we asked another couple if they wanted to join us, so that we could split the cost). Very worthwhile, otherwise we would have missed out on a lot of information, the best example of which was the main plate in the painting of the last supper! You have to see it to believe it!! As with many spanish cathedrals, the place is dripping in gold and other precious metals. Beautiful.
Beautiful architecture. This was a beautiful church, but is always difficult to believe the grandeur of the old churches. Worth a visit if you're interested in architecture.

Peculiar. Interesting church that tells a lot about how religion and priests played a significant role in the conquest of LatAm. Look at the painting with the holy Mary pregnant (with Jesus already born) and to the dark skinned Christ. Not to be kissed the local version of the Last Supper where a modest dinner is turning into a king's banquet with a Guinea pig in the middle of the table.

Overwhelming art. The cathedral is amazing. Other than art museums, I have never been in a building with so much art and architectural features to look at! We paid 30 soles for a tour, which was helpful. We could hear other tour guides were more knowledgeable than ours, so be aware the quality may vary. Having said that, I didn't feel cheated and the guide was very friendly. After that, we were free to stay as long as we liked. The biggest problem for me was the lack of wheelchair access. Inside was fine - it was getting in that was difficult. You are not permitted to take photos, a rule I kept to. I bought a set of postcards for 20 soles in the shop on the way out.

Interesting group of churches. Three churches in one. The main cathedral is flanked by two churches to make a cross shape. The art inside is very interesting as you can see how local artists incorporated Inca themes into traditional Christian images - the last supper featuring a roast guinea pig for example!We paid 30 sols to one of the local guides to show as around - worth it as we would have missed much of the symbolism.

Amazing. Simply the best and most gold laden Cathedral that there is. The beauty of this place surpasses your expectations. The more paintings and altars you see the more flabbergasted you become. This is a must see attraction, no photos allowed and that makes it all the more special. Don't miss it while in Cuscoperu.
Fascinating!. Three different churches. The mirrors which attracted the local people and brought them into the church are interesting. The decor and detail are amazing. Great artwork.

So That's Where All the Gold Went. Whether you love or hate Catholicism, one thing can be said about them. They built awesome churches. This is no exception. At times a little overwhelming, but worth the visit to see the indigenous carved choir box.
Church trip. Great place for a visit could easily spend half day looking around. On evening if lucky may catch the choir singing and holding mass awesome if you get involved and stay throughout.

Stunning. Like in the rest of churches and museums - absolutely no photography. Great shame. We got the tickets as part of 4 churches for 30 sol. This is the only one in which we were asked to leave our passport or drivers license in order to obtain audio guide. We protested and at the end they took our mobile as a security. Personally I think that is very poor but at the end of the day it does not make this wonderful cathedral any less splendid. We actually visited the place a day before with a guide as a part of an organized trip but felt it needed more time. Absolutely wonderful. It is huge, walls covered in great paintings. There is a long room covered in cedar carvings - I think called the music room, fantastic . this is really a special place.

Must visit when in Cusco. This Cathedral is just amazing. Ther is so much to see and with the electronic guide it will take you about 45 minutes to go through. Amazing paintings, statues, carvings and the gold and silver just WOW. Yes this Cathedral like so many here was build on a religious site of the local people but the Spanish destroyed these sites took all the gold and silver an then build these Cathedrals. The entrance ticket for 4 sites is only 30 Soles. Bring a ID to get the electronic guide or your mobile might do.
We even attanded a wedding. During our visit to Cusco we were seeing churches and during our visit to Catedral Del Cusco, we stumped upon the wedding ceremony: what a treat

Another cathedral. Interesting church built with Incan influences.
Would recommend having a local guide. With so many other interesting sites nearby I would have chosen to spend less time here.

Fabulous cathedral. Loved the main alter made from carved teak and finished in silver leaf
Fabulous dome and plenty of art to see around the walls.

Magnificent Spanish-imposed Cathedral. Yes, OK, it's magnificent as an example of how the Spanish imposed their religion and architecture on the Inca capital. Personally I find it rather gaudy and somewhat overwhelming, but well worth a visit.
Impressive but too much for us mortals. The ability of the Catholic Church to be massively over ornate never ceases to amaze me, this cathedral is a good example,of historic "over the top"

Great Tour!. Beautiful Cathedral - really nice guided tour. You can climb stairs that to an open window that overlooks the plaza for some stunning views. Wish you could take photos inside the church, but the rules do not allow. Admission fee for the tour is standard for the churches in the region.

Spectacular!. The most amazing collection of churches ever.. .3 if not four in one.The grandest collection of gilt, silver,Madonnas , paintings etcThe lighting is superb!The place is very well maintained...flowers everywhere,....There is a lot to see so allow plenty of time.The choir stalls are particularly superb.When you have finished inside check out the outside architecture... Equally awe inspiring.

Excellent . We spend most of our traveling in Europe and we never pass up a Cathedral. This was of particular interest because of its unique use of space. There are multiple large areas and chapels rather than one. We really enjoy the last supper painting with the Guinea pig, fish, and corn beer on the table. Great experience.

Spectacular. We have visited many cathedrals throughout the world. The Central Cathedral is outstanding. We were with a tour group and spent about an hour. I could have visited a lot longer. The only negative comment I have is no picture taking. I'd understand no flash, but it'd be nice to have pictures. We highly recommend and a guide enhances the experience.

One of the most beautiful cathedrals in South America. This church is one of the few cathedrals in South America that clearly demonstrates Spanish construction on religous sites. I have only seen this type of cathedrals in Spain. This church is also a symbol of domination and genocide of the aboriginal people that lived in this community. Some of the staff were rude while we were visiting as they were having loud conversations on the phone and with each other and one person was pointing at one of my friends indicating that my friend was taking pictures of the church (not allowed). I went to the guard and asked them why they were pointing at my friend and they indicated that my friend was taking pictures. My friend had no cell phone or camara, he simply was sitting and looking at the ceiling. I pointed this out to the guard and also told him that instead of making false accusations, he should not have loud conversations on the phone that are disruptive to the visitors.
Stunning inside. Have a look on a sunday you dont need to pay but it is nice to have a look at how the catholics and peruvians merged the history together. Very interesting

Beautiful church and paintings. Go on a guided tour if possible.. A beautiful cathedral on the inside. It didn't look that large from the outside. But it seemed enormous inside, although I think that is because it is compartmentalized into a number of chapels.We were part of a small tour group, and I think it greatly enhanced my appreciation and enjoyment by having a directed tour and more detailed explanations of the structure and the artwork.There are a large number of paintings and I found them all to be beautiful. I understand that they represent the "Cusco School" (Escuela Cuzquena), a Roman Catholic artistic tradition and style. Many of the paintings are large murals. Of course, included among the paintings is the famous Last Supper depiction by Marcos Zapata, in which he incorporated several elements of his local people, such as the guinea pig entree and chicha. Our tour guide added an interesting tidbit about Zapata's painting: one of the apostles is clearly meant to be Judas, with a frowning and uncomfortable look on his face, not seen on the other apostles. But Zapata drew the face of this Judas to look like Francisco Pisarro, a likely satirical dig at the conquistador for his supposed "betrayal" of the Incan people.I read some of the negative reviews here. Many seem to complain that an admission fee is imposed, whereas they feel that entrance to any church should be free. Well, that's nonsense. Historical churches such as these need to perform a lot of maintenance to keep the artifacts in good condition, so I am not opposed to the charging of admission fees.

Take a photo out the front but don't bother going in. This was a undesired addition to our city tour and we elected to go inside rather than wait awkwardly in the plaza for an hour and a half. Entry was 25 Sol, which was 5 sol short than the cost of an entire tour of the sacred valley - which I found a bit dubious. Free audio guide at reception - no photos allowed inside. Essentially if you have been to any church in Italy/England/Spain you would find the internal contents of this one pale in comparison. I wouldn't recommend visiting it but it's definitely worth viewing the architecture from the front and grabbing that quinessential 'been to cusco' photo (cathedral with plaza de armas fountain in the foreground).
A Must. The Cathedral has three sections, all interesting. It is built over Inca spaces in the Spanish style. Most interesting is to see how the art, especially in statues has adopted Inca symbolism.

City of churches . Cuzco has countless squares all framed with a Spanish church or cathedral, it's interesting to see the integration of the Inca culture with the Spanish inquisitors. The cathedral del Cuzco is in the main square does have a entry fee but nominal is really worth a visit especially during prayer time when it states " no tourists " but you can just hangout back of the Church !

Highly recommend!. This is a must do in cusco! So much history, art and culture. They have a free video/audio tour, you just have to borrow the device at the entrance. That way you can understand what exactly you're looking at. I found the video was very detail and informative. Unfortunately no photos/videos inside.
Beautiful. Beautiful Cathedral. Must see. They provide visitors with an ipad which serves as a guide through the cathedral. Interesting history regarding the introduction of Catholicism to Peru.

I was inpressed. Probably the best Cathedral in Cusco. I would definitely recommend it. If you have the time and money go for the package ticket that includes the other Cathedrals. The only other cathedral worth visiting is San Blas.

Move over Vatican - Cusco has great Catholic church art too!. Wow! We have been fortunate to tour the Vatican with a guide and see many of its treasures and wonders. Meanwhile, while the Spanish did much that was wrong or unfair to the Quechuan and Inca peoples when they invaded and took over, nonetheless they shared with the native people their art, language, faith and passion for life. The Cathedral embodies the best artistic expressions of both the Spanish and Quechuan peoples in their expressions of their faith in God. It is as compelling if not more so than Notre Dame in Paris and St Peter's in Rome. But don't take our word for it - go see it yourself

just lovely. I passed by so many times with no interest to go inside. There is a no photo policy, but it was the stolen snapshots of the interior that convinced me to go in. Entrance fee is fair and the treasures inside are worth a visit. I especially loved the Cusco style Last Supper.

beautifull. you have to visit this catedral, it is a good example of the spanish arquitecture , very good experience even if you are not catholic, its not a mater of religion, its a matter of history, enjoy

i was impressed with the ornaments. this church was big, silent and imponent, it made me feel a lot about spiritual intern devotion, i would like church would be more open minded about snapshots as souvenirs, but anyway all was impressive.
Architecture. The building inside and out is gorgeous but it really burned me that you can't take pictures of the inside. Photography is kinda my thing.

Looks like a lot of churches.. Nothing particularly impressive, though nothing to warn you of or to keep you away. Just meh. If you like churches and are religious, you'll probably enjoy it. If not, have a wander in if you happen to pass by, but no need to visit specifically.
Ornate Spanish Church . Very ornate Church filled with gold and silver plus many amazing paintings. Worth the visit. No pictures or hats allowed.
Beautiful cathedral. This is a must see. A beautiful cathedral, offering a self-guided tour. The silver used inside is from local silver mines.
Dark Spanish interior. The exterior is classic Spanish Colonial, and the interior is filled with typically dark Spanish artwork. Not particularly appealing to me.

Not to be missed!. This magnificent cathedral rivals the most ornate and expensive churches in Europe with its riches of gold, silver and elaborate wood carvings, as well as oil paintings. An audio guide is included with the admission price, and it takes about an hour to explore all 3 naves. This is a must-see!
Absolutely amazing. Do not miss this!!!. The most beautiful cathedral you will ever experience. Save two or three hours so you can explore and experience it all.

Impressive colonial-style cathedral. This cathedral is built in Spanish sixteenth century colonial style. It's massive facade dominates Cusco's central square and was probably meant to over-awe the local Indian population. Inside there are some superb examples of the Cusco School of religious art, a style that grew up as a fusion of local and Spanish artistic styles.

Amazing inside. This cathedral looks amazing from the outside, but the inside is even more impressive. And, it's important to learn about the history of the site on which the cathedral was built - there was an Inca temple there before the Spanish arrived. I highly recommend going inside.
Family trip. This is quite a church! They say on the tour that it is the most beautiful in the world and I believe it!!

They didnt let me photo some pictures. This is the most important church and cathedral in Cusco, it makes me wonder how they could paint the giant murals...its astounding because they show a guinea pig in the last supper

Amazing Cathedral!. Cathedral del Cuzco is right in Plaza del Armas, one of two cathedrals. Highly recommend a visit. Been to a LOT of cathedrals and this is unbelievable. It's much larger than it looks once you get inside. Can't say enough how fantastic this was.

Eye-opening. Just to see a painting of the Last Supper in which Jesus is dining on guinea pig was worth the visit. To convert Incas to Catholicism, cultures were blended, and I doubt there are places in Cusco with better examples of the unique hybrid culture.

Our Favorite Stop in Cuzco. Loved this church and it rich history and blending of colonial spanish along with inca culture. Zapata's last supper which infuses the scene with local food (guinea pig, corn, etc) to teach the story with in situ was one of the most fascinating paintings I have scene. The church itself is quite magnificent and more ornate than the Gothic cathedrals of Europe. Fee is about $8 entry but it comes with a helpful audio and video guide for free.

City of Hills. Cuzco is a city built on hills with very narrow streets. The altitude takes some getting use to when you climb the narrow streets. There are many sites to see surrounding the city and I recommend them all. Take a walking stick or purchase one in the city. The Plaza is a place to sit and interact with interesting people.

A cathedral just like many others in Peru. So the cathedral is a sight you might feel interested in, or not! It is just like 100s of other cathedrals around Peru where if you have see a few you might have seen them all, still if religious architecture is your thing, why not go there, it is conveniently located, but in Cusco not a hype of any trip
Cathedral main plaza. This an impressive building. It seems to be three or four buildings joined together. If you enjoy churches this is a must. Even the non religious would be impressed

Historically incredible. This place is amazing, the history of the lace is so interesting yet quite amazing. The architecture is just incredible. Well worth av visit if your lucky enough to visit the area.

Beautiful, enormous church. We did an official tour and it was worth doing - the church has so much history. The ceilings are enormous. We weren't allowed to take photos but I wish we were. Note: We did this on our first day in Cusco -- and it was a smart choice -- there are a lot of seats so you can go slowly. A few people got sick from the altitude and they have medical personnel -- and oxygen -- available.

Really nice Cathedral. This Cathedral is so different from the ones I've seen in Europe. Less ornate but just as immense. It was hard to believe the church had a chapel for Guinea Pigs!
Worth a special visit!!

Excellent and well organized. If you're interested in religion and art, or architecture, it's a nice cathedral to visit. I liked the tour with the electronic device and headset they give at the entrance. It allows you to explore the cathedral and receive explanations without a tour guide and at your own pace, skipping whatever you feel like.
Nice Cathedral.. It is always interesting to visit the areas cathedrals. We were taken there as part of the tour of the city.

Meh, more interesting from the outside. Not a very beautiful cathedral compared to anything in Europe. Best part is the Black Jesus and the Last Supper painting in the corner of the main altar. Notice the guinea pig instead of fish. Feel free to skip as it is paid entrance and no pictures allowed.

Cusco Is An All-Around Nice City!. The Cathedral is gorgeous! The tour guide was very specific about you not taking pictures of the original pictures they had displayed inside, just have to be sneaky (; The view you can get of the city is amazing.

Beautiful cathedral but I object to paying to visit a church!. I had mixed views about visiting this cathedral for a couple of reasons: firstly, I don't think it's right to be charged to visit a church & secondly, because it's a reminder of how the hypocrisy of the Spanish invasion & obliteration of the Inca & South American cultures in the name of the Catholic church.However, that does not alter the fact that this is a beautiful cathedral & I know that my views on history are not going to change it!We bought the audio guide so that we could better understand the cathedral & its contents. All very sumptuous & gorgeous. No expense was spared by the colonisers in their religious buildings. Then again, they had plenty of gold & silver to pay for all this.
Beautiful Spanish architecture on an Inka foundation . Beautiful Cathedral similar to one's I've seen in Spain. Impressive inside and out overlooking the Plaza de Armas.

Worth a visit. There are actually three churches in this complex, the Cathedral, Jesus Maria and El Triunfo. You can visit all three churches with one ticket. There is also audio-guided tour available. The interior and the decorations were well maintained. Some of the decorations were made by using the silver produced in Potosi. The building itself is interesting, with the churches built using Spanish style, but on Inca building stone base. It is,worth a visit to this church when visiting Cusco.

Beautiful cathedral not to be missed. The Cusco cathedral is beautiful, if not one of the most beautiful cathedral I've ever seen.I went there with a guide that I wild highly recommend but you also have to option to rent an audio guide at the entrance. You'll need either of these to understand the very particular story of the cathedral. Only negative comment is that we can't take photos inside. Highly recommended, especially in a rainy day!

Romantic / historical / Colonial . Located at historical square . Well done preserved . Look like time stay as colonial & Inca era: stone street and colonial balcony make a great scenery for this majestic Cathedral. I would said the best in Latin America.

Atrocity . While this place is beautiful from the outside, it is a true monolith to the hypocrisy and opulence of the Catholic church. I felt sick the entire time we were in there. So much of the decor was simply stolen outright from the Incas and reprised into huge structures fraught with the hubris of this religion. You couldn't pay me to enter that place again.

Standard cathedral in the centre of Cuzco square. The building is beautiful over the square but it is a normal cathedral. If you have never visited one you should go inside otherwise you could avoid it, no problem!

Worth the visit . This is a beautiful historic cathedral. I've been to many in Europe but this is definitely one of the best I've visited in South America. The self paced audio guide was very helpful to bring you through the three churches. The guide has pictures on the tablet so it's easy to find the different locations in the cathedral.

An absolutely stunning cathedral. The outside itself is an impressive architectural wonder, with extensive detail and an imposing presence on the square. It is humbling to go inside such a gorgeous structure and imagine all who came there before you.

Treasure layered on treasure. The riches in this museum, both art and precious metals, are impressive! The iPad/audio guide that comes with the 25 Soles admission price provides detailed explanations of the Cathedral's interior, and at about $7.41, why bother sneaking in for free during Mass?

Excellent site to visit . We went to visit this historical church and see all the wonderful architecture of this buildings.As well the art and sculptures were incredible. Incredible history that the inca people have gone through.I highly recommend this with or without children.A great representation of how the Inca people were ingenuitive.
Astounding. One of the most amazing cathedrals I have ever visited. A must see. Right at the main plaza. Close to shops, dining and hotels. You can drive within a block of the plaza.
Must see. This was one of the most interesting and beautiful cathedrals I have seen and I've been to many in Europe.
Nicely restored magnificent cathedral with a history central to understanding cuzco. Very accessible, important site to the history of the Spanish conquest and an example of a historic site

Amazing gold and art works. The first chapel you enter has all guilded statues, etc. The main chapel filled with large art pieces. Some very interesting like a pregnant Mary with baby Jesus and the Last Supper where Guinea Pig was on the menu.
It Goes On and On. An amazing, yet eclectic collection of chapels & naves under one roof. Once you've thought you've seen it all, you turn the corner to another treasure...and some quirky stuff.

Beautiful at night. This cathedral is set in a beautiful plaza and has a marvelous exterior. Unfortunately we couldn't get to see the interior due to a public demonstration taking place directly outside so just had to settlecfor admiring the exterior this time.

Cathedral. The Cusco Cathedral is one of the most magnificent churches is Cusco. The religious arts, paintings and vessels are amazing. If you love arts, paintings, architecture snd history, this is a must- see.

Very good cathedral . Best cathedral we visited in South America. It took about 50 minutes to get around the whole cathedral. The audio guide is very interesting. Note the picture of the last supper with the guinea-pig in the centre of the table. When buying the ticket you can buy a ticket for 4 other churches and religious buildings around cusco which I would recommend. This ticket can be used for up to 3 days after purchase.
Amazing Cathedral.. Likely the best cathedral in the city and located in Plaza de Armas. Plan for a short 15 minute visit to see an amazing historic landmark
Beautiful cathedral in the heart of Cusco square.. There is a s/10 or $3 admission fee to get into this marvelous place, but if you love history and old churches this is the place for you!
interesting history. Much more interesting inside than outside. Be sure to have a guide who can point out Incan influences in the art of the church.

Oppressive. So much stuff. I can only think of the Spanish conquistadores taking this people's land and natural riches, destroying their temples to use the stones for this institution and giving them poverty and religion. The ornate materialism is oppressive. Many statues of Christ with embellished hip wraps. Hope not to offend, but I was offended by this display.

Magnificent. This would rate amongst the best cathedrals you would experience in Europe.The wealth in the gold and silver is astronomical and hard to fathom in what appears to be a poor town.Only downside is that unable to take photographs - this is understandable in terms of use of flash but with modern cameras being able to turn off the flash a bit behind the times.

Cathedral. I think it is an important place in the city. However, there is not much to see if you are eager to learn more about Inka's culture. This is an important Colonization building but it is not so interesting if you have been in Europe or other cathedrals in Latin America.

Large Cathedral. I visited here with my wife. The interior of the Cathedral was beautiful and large, but I was sorry that I could not take photos inside the cathedral.
It was true that Jesus was about to eat the mouse (cuy) in the painting in this cathedral.
beautiful artifacts. i went with a tour guide and wish i had more free time to look at the paintings and craft. overall a glorious church to visit. couldn't take pictures but glad it was built.

A good self-guided tour. An audio headset with a tablet is free, works great, and is the best way to tour the Cathedral. Better than hiring a guide. You can go at your own pace and blocks the sound of any large group tours. It takes about 45 minutes and is worth visit.
If you like churches, visit this cathedral. I personally love visiting churches in different places to see how the structures and architectures differ. This huge cathedral and basilica is beautiful!
Thieves. These are symbols of the invaders and the destruction they brought, can you believe a church that charges entrance fees......

What a beautiful building. This is a stunning building opposite the Plaza De Armas, you can take a tour of the inside, however we never had the time, it’s not a lot of money for the tour.
Worth a look

Stunning! And don't forget to ask for the IPAD, it's included in the price! . It costs S/ 24 to get in but it's worthy to pay a visit. It's big, so go when you have time, more than one hour. Bring an ID in order to get the I Pad with the explanation on it. If you go early, at 6am for the mass, than is free. No pictures are allowed. 😥
Stodgy. An unlovely cathedral whose main features are the Inca sun symbol and the black christ. Architecturally uninspiring. 10 mins max.

Amazing place. The Cathedral is spectacular to see. I recommend taking the guided tour to give you the entire nuance and the integration of beliefs between the Inca and the Spaniel during that period. A lot a detail to look at and history to learn.
Beautiful. Absolutely amazing inside, glad we had such a competent guide called Manuel or Manny as he is known locally, otherwise we would have missed much of the history

stuning spanish colonial architecture. right in front of plaza de armas and just across the street from the irish pub. lots of turist seat on the front steps to chat and enjoy the fantastic atmosphere
Very large, beautiful and interesting cathedral. This cathedral was more impressive on the inside. We toured it with a guide and it really enhanced our understanding of what we were seeing.
Well worth a visit. They have done a phenomenal job at restoring the interior of this fabulous cathedral that is steeped in history and has multiple naves within it.

beautiful church. Visited during our stay in Cusco waiting for trip to Machu Picchu. Most beautiful church. Had to pay entrance fee then was able to get a private tour guide for extra cost after getting through door (well worth it!). Definitely worth a visit to learn about the history and the see the paintings especially The Last Supper with a guinea pig. No pictures allowed at all inside, so somewhat disappointing. Yet, a gorgeous cathedral to visit.

Step in off the Plaza and enter another world.... This cathedral is well worth the small cost to enter and wander inside. It is filled with history and fascinating religious art and artifacts and wonder to see. We sat in a pew for a few minutes and just took it all in - a very powerful spiritual place.
A one of the finest cathedrals. A guided tour of the cathedral and the attached Chapel of the Sacred Family revealed one of the finest cathedrals in the world. The imagery throughout is magnificent.
Massive Cathedral, very ornate!. The Cathedral give you a glimpse of what the catholics and Spanish did to the local inca people. So disturbing and fascinating at the same time.

A Very Historical Cathedral in Cusco. This cathedral is located in the center of the town square. When you enter the building, you are amazed at how large it is. It has many religious paintings and artifacts and Romanesque architecture. It was completed in 1654 and took 100 years to complete. If you visit Cusco, this is a must see.

Gorgeous Cathedral. The Catedral del Cuzco is a beautiful, historical church located on the Plaza de Armas. Unfortunately, they do not allow photos inside the church, but it is a must see while in Cusco. I was surprised at how large the interior was and was blown away by the beauty in each room. Really stunning...

Home of the black Christ. You are actually visiting three different churches side by side.They offer a tablet powered self guided tour and, unless you are an history buff, this is a good investment. Most of Cusco's history evolves around the Catholic church and it all happens here.No pictures, no video...

A statue of Jesus that is unusual!. We engaged a guide to take us round the cathedral and it was well worth it, as we would never have understood the intricacies of this place.The Incas saw Jesus as a dark skinned saviour and dressed him not in a loin cloth as he is most usual portrayed, but in a skirt, which was the costume of the Incas.Some interesting paintings and beautiful architecture.

Great photo opportunities. I got some really great pictures of this building lit up at night. During the day time we were there about 4 times and there was only 1 day that it was open and there was some sort of event, possibly a wedding or something going on and we got to peek inside. The outside is classic colonial look and at night it is lit up nicely. Only negative is that they have some tacky colored lights on a couple spots that just dont fit in.
Amazing church. So much gold and silver in this church . A car no less is there ready to drive away for ceremonies. This is where the inca gold and silver went!
No photos inside!. Beautiful church! But no photos inside the church! Was very disappointed with no pictures. But I would suggest seeing it.

Amazing. I have never seen such a wonderfully over the top cathedral. It's excellent, I loved every minute. And even better it's 2 churches and a cathedral, how cool it that! Particularly enjoyed learning how local artisans blended stiles to come up with their own interpretations of European styles.Go, soak up the atmosphere!
Just beautiful. Amazingly nice, big, with a special character. There is an entrance fee but I would say it definitely deserves it. No pictures allowed, which is sad...

Expencive tours, only do them if you are interested in history.. We thought the tours were quite expencive here, so we did it without a guide. Sure we didnt get all the facts, but we were here mainly for the views!Those are quite spectacular! Gold and silver and beautiful artwork everywhere. Highly reccomended.

A lovely church and a good guide. This was a fascinating church with some very interesting art. A local guide approached us and offered a tour. He was very knowledgeable and brought each exhibit to life and context. No spoilers, but you should give it a visit.
Worth a visit. Cusco's cathedral is a must see. Attending a ceremony (8 o'clock) is worth getting up early. People are so connected, and the cathedral itself is absolutely unique !
Very impressive place. This place is full of great history; you can really see how the Catholic Church and the culture met. If you're interested in history, this is a good place to walk around.
Beautiful church. Would recommend taking the audio tour through the church. Many amazing paintings. One of the must see's of Cusco. Soak it all in because no pictures can be taken once inside.

Very impressive and majestic. I am not always fond of audioguides but this one was very well done: 23 spots explained and on the small display (sjze of mini IPad) the details were zoomed in and/or additional information was given-a short informative film to each point (23 over all) on the cathedral. Very well done indeed -the 45 minutes passed very quickly.

Incredible Cathedral. Do yourself a favor and hire a guide to tell you about the history of the church. The interior is decked in gold and great artwork. Such history that you will miss out by just walking inside and having a look around. Guide is necessary.
Beautiful cathedral. I'm so happy I ventured in and heard the choir singling and the organist and violinist playing. It was truly beautiful.
Impressive interior. The interior drips gold and has an interesting history. We had a guide which helped us make the most of our visit.

A cathedral that goes over the top. The Spaniards and their successors have certainly put their gold and silver here. There are three huge sanctuaries with a lot of side areas. It makes you wonder what could have been done for the citizens of Peru if the money spent here was used for social projects or education.

Very impressive!. We're not religious at all but we still wanted to see it and it really impressed us!
You can't take pictures but it's worth it.
You'll have to see it yourself.

Go when they are having a service. I noticed comments about an entry fee but I strolled in at 8 30am and was mesmerised by the music that was playing during a service. Amazing sound.
I just sat and absorbed the atmosphere. Fantastic!
Its a nice church inside and out - worth the visit
Very Pretty. Great place to just people watch, camp out in the square across the street, lots going on there most of the day and night too.

Getting to know Inca. This place is full of great history. Cusco was the center and starting point of the incan revolution. You can really see how the Catholic church and the incan culture met.
If you're interested in history, this is a good place to walk around. Start with a guide, then go by yourself.

Very impressive comes with audio. I was wary of paying extra 25 soles (8 usd) to see a sight outside the comprehensive tourist ticket (boleto turistico). However is well worth it, specially with the audio guide included. You walk around with a tablet and headphones (included) and walk around with it. Very nice experience.

Amazing!. I was very pleased we paid for entry to this cathedral. The ceiling was stunning and the artwork through was great. I don't think you need to spring for the guided tour, though we saw several people who did. Just know that you have to pay to get in and can't take pictures inside.

A must see in Cusco. I love Cathedrals, but you can't compare South American Cathedrals to European Cathedrals. So I was intrigued by this one. It is very spacious inside. The room packed with silver is one of my favorites to look at. I have never heard the history of this church, as all 5 times I've been in it, I was working and unable to hear my guides explanation. There is a lot to take in visually. This year I went down into a small room just left of the exit, a catacomb of sorts, but it was a tiny white cemented room with plaques on the walls. Take your time going through, and they do not allow photos.

Astonishing symbology. It may seem anomalous that a non-religious person such as myself enjoys visiting churches and cathedrals in South America. I enjoy the architecture; the ornate (to the point of being gaudy) representations of religious figures; the high standard of the artisans responsible for converting the riches of a few into incredible carvings, gilded works, paintings, construction techniques, etc., to awe the many.But the outstanding feature of this cathedral for me was the symbology displayed in the painting of the last supper, where a guinea pig is shown as the centre-piece of the meal and Judas is displayed as a person of swarthy features whereas Jesus and the other disciples are white. More astonishing was a figure of Christ as a black-skinned person with Joseph and Mary displayed as whites - this was a temporary display, I think, perhaps associated with a ceremonial day the preceding Sunday. There was more of this incredible symbology; in my experience surpassed only by the amazing Mezquita in Córdoba, Spain.

Nice architecture . Worth a look for the architecture but nothing special to be honest. If you're religious maybe you'll see a different side than I but all the virgin Mary's and Jesus' badly painted and dressed in lairy clothes just seemed a bit much to me and pretty fake too.

3 churches in one. We visited this church, we were amazed that the church was so big and so beautiful, we are both interesting in ancient history; we were absolutely surprised on how beautiful the church was on the inside. I would highly recommend it!
Amazing churches . You will for sure see these churches on your trip. Most are open all day and free to enter. The workmanship is amazing to say the least. I think there are 4 or 5 here to see.
Worth a look. Make sure you pay the small entrance fee to have a look around, we went in with a guide but you can rent the headphones to get the history.

Wonderful. Example of a historical building in the heart ofCusco ,covers one side of the Plaza de Ames.Mamy treasures on show. Our tour guide had arranged a local guide so it was very interesting to walk around with someone who was both informative and pleasant .The main altar is gold and very beautiful .Also the famous painting of the Last Supper with a Guinea pig .

Amazing cathedral in the heart of Cusco!. This outstanding cathedral is vast inside and houses many historical treasures and art works. The extravagance of cathedral highlights how the Spanish and catholic church were complicit in exploiting the indigenous people in establishing their dominance in Peru. No need for a guide - the self guided audio tour is very user-friendly and covers all the major attractions inside the cathedral.

Huge and Creepy - In a Good(ish) Way. This is definitely not the bloodiest, creepiest, Latin American catholic church I have seen. But you will find creepy crypts and statues of conquistadors walking on indigenous people. It is disturbing and fascinating and worth a visit. Though the entrance fee is relatively steep.

Unique church in archetecture and art. This Roman Catholic church reflects both traditional Catholic and Inca beliefs. The main alter is gold and has numerous paintings and some are devoted to Mary and also pay homage to Mother Earth of the Incas. The second section has paintings that are Peruvian views such as the Last Supper with a platter of a little pig. The third section is modest in decoration and does display the first cross brought to the New World.

Cusco meets Catholicism. The Last Supper with a guinea pig? Welcome to the Cusconian School of Art. The Cathedral is an ethical challenge, certainly beautiful in its own right, but knowing the granite was taken from Sacsayhuaman makes it somewhat less "pure" to me. A case of 'to the victor the spoils'.
Inti v Jesus. The conquistadors destroyed the Inca temples but look closely and you'll find traces of the Inca religion including a Guinea pig as part of the last supper

Another church. Yes its a cathedral not a church but seen one seen'em all.Not being religious at all we found the excessive opulence and wealth on display quite obscene when you compare it to the poverty close by and seeing so many made it worse. All guides take pains to say how the Spaniards were so crafty in impressing the Incas with huge staues, lots of shiney stuff, all the symbols of unadulterated power and how the gullible indigenous people fell for it hook line and sinker yet for some reason they cannot see themselves in the modern role of the Incas. The real clincher for us was being shown the massive shrine inside the cathedral 'owned' by the Cusco football team. Said it all.

Out of thousands in Peru, this is the Cathedral worth visiting on its own. Astonishing Cathedral full of history, unique architecture, beautiful art work, paintings and an imposing atmosphere.There's thousands of Cathedrals in Peru and most of them are included in every tour but this is the one worth visitting on its own. Beautiful place, you'll hardly be able to take any pictures yet you wont forget the look of it.

Amazing woodwork. The woodwork, carvings and alters rival the churches we have visited in Spain and France. I particularly like how they regionalized the facial features and coloring, and how they snuck in the figures from the Inca culture.

El Sincretismo...... Boy oh boy.....what an astonishing place. Three churches attached to one another in one fascinating complex, revealing the complex relationship between the Catholic Church, local customs and Inca history

This Cathedral is well worth a visit. Visited this cathedral & was quite overwhelmed by the opulence, you are not allowed to take photos inside this Catholic Cathedral. The alter is 1 1/4 ton of solid silver, decorated by 5kgs gold leaf, what else can I say, I found it a bit overwhelming in its opulence. Admission is 25 Sol

Cuy at the Last Supper. We toured this cathedral and its chapels with a sense of sadness knowing that it had been erected as an expression of power as well as of faith. Audioguides are available and may be useful; however we did not use them since we have toured so many medieval cathedrals. This is an amazing spectacle and was especially interesting in its artistic expressions of faith. Jesus and the Last Supper featuring cuy as an entree are not to missed.

Stands tall in the plaza!. This is one of my favorite buildings in all of Cusco. the cathedral stands tall in the middle of the Plaza de Armas and it so beautiful either during the day or at night. It reminded me a lot of some of the cathedral I have seen in Europe in the past and is so beautiful to look at.
Very beautiful. This is a very beautiful cathedral, but you do need a guide to explain things. Interesting mixture of Catholicism and Incan cultural references.

Impressive. This is the place I call the church of many churches. It seems that over time thry expanded on this site by attaching another incredible church. I really enjoyed learning about the history of this old site. It seems the Spanish were intent on converting the local people in just about any way possible. Even depicting a more tan Christ and guinea pig being served at thr last supper to appeal to the native people.

Special. You have to spend some time there while in Cusco. It is beautiful, but if you have seen some of the european kathedrals it is quite awerage. The history is interesting, and where else can you see a black Jesus and guinea pig on "The last supper"? Notise that Judas is colored. You might like a guided tour.

Amazing place. This huge cathedral is amazing! Do yourself a favour and either get a guide, or, as we did, avail of the free audio guide included in the entrance fee. We would have missed out on so much if we hadn't had the audio guide. It's an enormous place with some brilliant art - don't miss the Last Supper featuring a roast guinea pig as a feature of the banquet!! You need to allow at least an hour with the audio guide.

Beautiful!. We toured this church with a guide (Juan) who was stationed in the church. He was very knowledgeable about the art and architecture. You will get to see the Spanish influence through Inca eyes.
Fascinating. When you go inside it's like Doctor Who's tardis as so much bigger, lots of paintings, artefacts, altars, take a guide or get a tape and headphones to get the best out of this visit

Beautiful Basilica! A must see.. We toured this church with a guide and he was very very knowledgeable about the church ( and sites around the church). I highly recommend going into the church and get s guide if possible .

Rivals Europe's Mightiest!. My wife and I visited the cathedral while stopping in Cusco on the way home from a trip to Machu Piccu. We've been in cathedrals in Europe and were amazed at how ell this rivals the mightiest of them in size and architecture.
Cathedral. You re in cuzco and need visit this. Here you ve many cathedrals and churchs but this is one of the best of Peru.
Main Cathedral worth visiting. Worth visiting as this is the major cathedral in Cuzco with some terrific art and gilded gold. Central location in the heart of the city on the main square.

Extravagant. It's quite the place to see, but it's depressing in a way. Not only is there a lot of gold and ornate items for a poor country, but also that the church was built by tearing down Inca sites. Keep that in mind. However, you should still see it, for two reasons. It's part of history and we need to see the good and bad, and because it's really amazing. One of the grandest cathedrals I've ever seen.
Tons of Gold and Silver.. This Cathedral doesn't speak well of the colonial Church. Way too much Gold and Silver that could have been better served helping the poor. Beautiful to see but disturbing.
Stunning. Bought the 60Sol book and got postcards thrown in. Clean toilets. Wonderful carving and pictures a bit too Baroque for some taste. Lots to see.

Best cathedral in South America. You will see the grandeur of Spanish influence because Cusco used to be the capital of Peru and used knowledge and artistry of Inca to edify Carholic images , it's saints and art pieces.Learn how they still use glue cloth to make statues and paint them. A wonderful collection of silver and gold. See the alabaster altar. I cannot remember everything-- because picture taking wasn't allowed.

Nerve center of Cusco. Sept 18A highlight of the Cusco city tour, this magnificent Catedral, built upon an older Incan temple to show the power of the Spanish conquerors, has impressive interiors as well as exterior public space. A tourist magnet, this stone structure with a base of Incan stone work, seems to be a center of city life--lots of locals, tourists, restos, vendors, hawkers.On the steps fronting the Catedral, we met with the owner of Intense Peru, our TO, Sofia Arce, and our TA, Lisbeth Guillen. We thanked both of them for the successful execution of the tour so far.

Worth Popping In. Its worth going in here to check the several churches. They all have great art in them. Be sure to check out the cript in the last one, to see De La Vega. Just for historical significance.

Depend on a professional guide. This dominant of Cuzco completed in 1654 is not only the main place of worship, but also a repository of local archeological artifacts and colonial art. In 1983 it became a UNESCO World Heritage Site. As such it is must-see for every visitor of Cuzco. Its interior is famous for the amazing amount of precious metals used in its decoration. Apart from the commonly known "Ginny pig last supper" by Marcos Zapata, there is number of other valuable paintings and rare pieces of art, in which an ordinary visitor is very likely to get lost. It is therefore almost inevitable not to visit the cathedral alone, but to take part in a guided tour.

A must visit while in Cusco, Peru. The grandeur of this cathedral in the midst of one of the poorest cities is striking. Alters of gold, incredible art work and alter after alter. The choir area and pipe organ are spectacular. Attending a mass here is an experience of a lifetime.

Not to be missed!. Absolutely take a guided tour of this impressive cathedral! Besides the fact that it is truly beautiful, there is so much to be learned about the methods used by the Spaniards to convert the indigenous people, and how the natives incorporated ancient ritual images into the building's artwork. It is really interesting! Walking through the cathedral without the benefit of a guide would be a big mistake here. This cathedral is a ornate and fabulous as any in Europe. Plan to spend at least an hour.

Only comparable with Saint Peter (Vatican) and Seville Cathedral (Spain). Cusco cathedral it is just amazing. In my opinion it is between the three most incredible and impressive churches on the world, just comparable in size and richness with Saint Peter at Vatican City and Seville Cathedral in Spain. There are tons of gold and silver inside in the shape of altars, decorations and saint images. It is a mix of architectural and art styles. A must to see for every visitor to Cusco, especially for those lovers of art and architecture.
A must visit. I love architecture and this church has it! A must visit if in cusco. The inside was very impressive !
Just a cathedral. It's nothing more than just a cathedral, there are plenty of churches like that in Europe. We were hoping to see inca influences and sth different but it was just the usual for us.

It worths a visit . I visited the cathedral as part of a city tour, initially I did not want to buy the ticket, usually I don't visit churches, particularly the ones that I have to pay, but I am glad I did! The visit was extremely interesting! It is worthy, at least to see the paintings, The Last Supper by Zapata.
Fabulous. Although it cost money to get into this church it is an amazing place and the history is wonderful. Take the time and do it.

A Jewell BUT go in a guided tour. What I found fascinating about the cathedral, was the history behind each "corner", so for you to fully enjoy it, hire a professional guide to explain everything. We were surprised, as we did not expect much (after all, we had visited the Vatican and all great European cathedrals) but our guide was also a history professor and loved his job, so he made the tour a fascinating one, my wife and I enjoyed very,very much.

amazing. a must go. you can hire a guide or it looks like there are tablets that you can rent and listen to it. I am not sure if it is free or not. i think it is great as there are lots of paintings and it is nice to hear something informative about each painting. we saw the last supper with the guinea pig, which is kind of funny. there are lots of silver altar. it is amazing. it is as good as any cathedral in europe.
Reserved and Ancient. Very old and beautiful. Paintings centuries old. Religious Saints and Statues very old 10 sole's to enter no pics but worth the price.

Silver altar was incredible. Also look out for the Guinean pig in the last supper painting.. Went as part of the city tour. Very impressive, with lots of treasures. Would have been nice to stay longer, limited time due to the tour.

Glorious but Saddenning. The Cathedral was magnificent in its display of the many altars. The attempt by the Spaniards to impose their faith and the means of doing so by the quantity of Gold and silver that had been used was unimaginable. It was also sad to think that it at a cost to the Inca people.

Stunning exterior. A truly goliath and stunning cathedral exterior. We did not spend the money to go inside, but rather popped around the right side of the cathedral to a smaller worship space that was as impressive as it was intimate. The inside was completely covered in gold leaf and locals dotted the pews. As a non-religous person taking part in a catholic school holiday I felt like I was able to view the alter much more comfortably (and less like a tourist) than I would have inside the cathedral. So, although it would have been nice to see if the inside of the cathedral was as impressive as the outside, I didn't feel like I missed out on anything.
Catedral de Cuzco. Worth the visit. Meet the Spanish heritage still visible in Cusco. Take a guided tour and learn it historical facts.

Do not miss!!!. This site is simply breathtaking. We did not realize what we were walking into but were pleasantly surprised. If you are going to this site, buy your combination ticket at the museum of religious art. It will cost 30 soles for 4 sites instead of the 25 for just the cathedral.
Interesting Historical Church. Beautiful Church. Be sure to request the price INCLUDED guided tour ear phones (leave driver's license). Makes the visit all the more rewarding.
very interesting. Beautiful monument. It is amazing to see the combination between the peruvian natives belief and the the new belief that Spanish broght with them and forced them to accept.

Worth the Visit. We were approached inside by a guide and it was well worth it too. His experience and knowledge of what we were experiencing made our visit more enjoyable. I highly recommend a personal guide as it is well worth the small amount of money. Even though you can't take pictures the surroundings are something you will never forget.

Inside the Inca Culture. The Catedral is quiet big inside they have lots of pictures. The God inca is there very beautiful, if u got o the service in the morning u dont need pay 25 soles. But when we pay we have access for the museum next to the Catedral. Takes around 3/4 hours to see everything.

Worth the money, and the time.. Amazingly gorgeous, both on the inside and the outside. It's a shame there are absolutely no pictures allowed inside the Cathedral, but I'm glad, so I could focus on seeing, rather than taking pictures. This is NOT covered by the available Tourist Pass that is very common.

Holiday of a lifetime...Peru. Holiday of a lifetime...when in Cusco this icon is a must see. In fact and perhaps not surprisingly the cathedrals across Peru are so very different to their counterparts in the UK and Europe. Really beautiful with their own cachet...
Beautiful interior!. Huge building : a cathedral and 2 chapels. It's good to visit with a guide who will inform you of the history of the place.

Lots of history. The history here is extensive. The preservation of the cathedral appears to be well done, I can't imagine the man hours to take care of something like this. There is alot to do around the square where this is located too. Dining, shopping, etc.

Very ornate church. This place is made up of three churches: the cathedral, the Chapel of the Holy Family, and the Chapel of Triumph. Very ornate interior. Lots of history, so go with a guide. I don't know if it offers audio guides.

Silver altar and mirrors - must go in and check it out. Very impressive silver altar. Do not miss a visit inside the Cathedral. Also, notice the mirrors.... and ask for the reason why this cathedral has mirrors.... interesting story.
An impressive Cathedral.. Well worth a visit, full of gilded chapels and altars. You cannot help being impressed by the grandness of it all.
Splendid Cusco Cathedral.. Totally amazing Cathedral full of gold and silver inside and paintings to tech the Peruvians what Christianity was all about.

So much gold and silver on the site of an Inca palace. This Cathedral is striking in its place on the square, the gold and silver used in the altars and the collection of local art combining the Christian themes as portrayed by indigenous peoples. They incorporated local foods and Inka traditions into pictures depicting Christian stories. Quite a conflict between "my God is stronger than your gods".

Inca and Spanish collision wrapped up in a church.. Stunning architecture with an equally fascinating history. Right in the heart (in fact it could be the heart itself) of the Plaza de Armas in Cusco. It symbolizes the clash of two cultures: Inca and Spanish with a riveting back story. No spoilers here, just a recommendation as a must-see while in the very underrated Cusco -- not just the staring point for your Macchu Picchu adventure.
Fantistic Cathedral.. By far the MOST beautiful of Cathedrals. Breathtaking paintings, alters etc. Very knowledgable guide. Fantiatic tour by GATE !

Must-see cathedral. Attend a mass if you can.. Amazing cathedral. We had a private guide who explained so much. Without this, get the audio guide. The history of the Inca influence within this church is apparent and so interesting.

Great visitor spot with lots of history . This is in the middle of plaza area. Nice architecture. Great photo opportunity from outside. There are conducted tour. No need. Just grab prerecorded headphones for 10 usd or less. Takes around 2 hrs. So much to see inside.

Bring passport or drivers' licence as deposit for free audio guide!. This is definitely a must-see for anyone visiting Cusco! The building is lovely from the outside but does not give due credit to its stunning interior! There is a student discount.I was told if you go between 6am and 9am you can go in for free!Definitely bring a passport or drivers' licence as a deposit for the free audio guide! I wasn't told that it MUST be one of these two forms of identification until after I had paid my entrance fee, so walked through the cathedral without one afterwards because I didn't want to pay for a guided tour by myself. No photography allowed inside.
Literally tons of Silver.. A must see, almost too much with the amount of silver. Right off the square so easy to get to. Good place for mass for visitors.
Beautiful Catedral. This is a beautiful catedral in Colonial stile. Not the most incredible one I have ever seen, but it is worth it.
Cusco cathedral.. A nice church in Cusco to visit but not as grand as some we visited. Peddlers become a bit of a nuisance at times.

IN ISOLATION IT'S PROBABLY VERY INTERESTING. Soory, but by the time we came to this on our tour of Peru I'd had enough of churches and cathedrals. It's all very ornate and I can admire the artistry of the builders but I have little interest in religion and even less after 2 weeks of seeing many churches etc.

Beautiful Cathedral. Beautiful cathedral in the heart of Cusco. The building is stunning from the outside and just a beautiful inside. The displays are pretty spectacular and there is an amazing amount of gold inside. You are not allowed to take photographs inside the building.

Must see to understand blending of European Christianity and the native Andean beliefs. Stunning church with blending of the European Catholicisim and the native people faith.
