A good guide or audio tour makes much more sense of how the Spanish spread Christianity and the local natives were incorporated though not always flul conversion. The last supper painting is remarkable and the whole church is amazing.
very impressive. From outside and inside is so beautiful, very impressive!!!!Is in tne center of Cusco, I recommend it!!

Cuzco. If you are travelling through South America, then you expect the unexpected. The Catedral is one of those places. Beware of petty crimes in the square outside the Catedral, but take advantage of a meal at one of the quaint cafes lining the square.

Timeless Architecture On The Outside. If you traverse the Plaza de Armas, you cannot miss this iconic building! It is very beautiful and the layout is a mixture of European influence blended with local architecture. Attended the mass here and though it was in Spanish it was, it was worth the experience. The inside is really gorgeously decorated. Reminds me of the Basilica in Oaxaca, Mexico.

European/Peruvian Take on a Cathedral. European and Peruvian influence meld together to form a grand cathedral! I recommend doing the free audio tour (get at the entrance by leaving an ID) if you are interested in some of the details of the chapel but don't want to hire a guide. There is so much to see in this cathedral (made up of three sections). It took us about 45 min to go through the whole things. We loved seeing the cross that the Spanish conquerors carried during their victory over Peru in the final Victory Chapel.
Incas vs Christainity. It's all here b. Interesting or awful, depending how you look at it his place...the amount of gold and silver, also the artwork with the Indian influence is worth seeing.
Worth the time to visit.. A beautiful setting with a lot of history and background. We enjoyed our touring of the facility and learning about the history of the facility.

Fascinating old churches. Cusco cathedral and its two connected sister churches are not just beautiful old buildings, but also a testimony to around 500 years of history and cultural change. The recorded English language commentary (included in the entrance) is excellent and informative about each of the key shrines and chapels. Look out for the Peruvian menu on the huge Last Supper painting....!Unlike many Spanish churches it's not massively over decorated so the shrines and paintings are clearer and more striking. The plain wooden carving of the choir stalls is stunning. Do go, it's an incredible place!

Pay the local guide for a quick tour. My wife and I decided to go see the inside of this cathedral. As soon as we entered we were approaced by a local guide who offered us a tour for around $10 USD. It was well worth it. He pointed out a number of interesting things that we would have missed if we didn't take his tour. The church is beautiful - tons of gold and silver and jewels. Lots of art and history. It is just as impressive as many of the big cathedrals in Europe.
Don't miss this one!. This cathedral is simply beautiful. I think I could have spent all day in there. So much history. I'm still in awe of how beautiful it was!

Sunrise service. 7 am Mass on weekday, only the serious local devotees are awake, and a few faithful tourists of course. Hopefully you are lucky you hear the enthusiastic organist, Mass is usually in Spanish. Great art, and notakings pics

Book a guide for this one!. Amazing architecture and finery. Definitely do it with a guide- nice to visit on it's own but you'd miss SO much fascinating information about it's history, the history of the local religion, the explanations behind the different icons, paintings etc.

Amazing and intriguing history. A large place to go around. exceptionally uncommon place, particularly with the burial section. You get a strange mixture of feelings of awe, wonder,surprise . You get more wonderstruck in the age old library with a large collection of books from times immemorial. Great experience.
Wonderful cathedral. Gorgeous cathedral with dramatic architecture and wonderful art work. This is one of the most spectacular cathedrals in South America and should not be missed.

Great square and beautiful Cathedral. We stopped at Cusco to get acclimated to the altitude before heading to Machu Picchu. This Cathedral is beautiful, inside and out. Lots of artwork but its pretty dark inside.
Amazing Cathedral. Spectacular Catedral w/ magnificent altars and artwork. A must see while in Cusco! The underlying history is amazing, but the pure visuals are unmatched.

I am so Proud to be Peruvian. Great place to visit, large amount of art work and easy to follow guided tour. The only thing no pictures allowed but I can understand why. So no harm done. Definitely a place to visit .

Great art in a lovely cathedral.. Our schedule was such that we could only go in the morning during Mass. Gorgeous art although side altars were dark...to discourage tourists during Mass.
Last supper with Guniea pig is to the right of the altar up high.
Beautiful. Loved my vist. It's Worth it with a guide. Take about 40 minutes. Lots of restaurant near by. Lots of shops also.
Worth an early rise. opens at 6am for mass. We got up early to see the This magnificante Cathedral. We arrived for mass. No pictures during mass. It is so well preserved! Gourgous!
Stunning.. Beautiful. Rent the self tour headsets with tables for free. You just need to leave your identification.

It's ornate, but don't miss it. A must see. An audio tour in included with admission, and is a great way to see the cathedral. The cathedral is a mix of Baroque and Gothic styles, and is incredibly ornate. There is gold everywhere, and a silver altar that is amazing. You hear about the earthquake that hit Cusco in the 1600's. You see the first cross that was brought to South America. The explanations of the paintings and icons are very interesting. The cathedral is unique because when you enter, there is immediately an altar, so you don't get the grandeur of scale of the space. After the audio tour, just sit in one of the pews and think about the melding of the Spanish and native cultures alluded to in the tour.

In God we trust, but the balance of payment is due in cash. El Catedral de Cuzco is one of the main attractions of the Inca capital, well worth the $10 entry fee. Nowadays they offer headsets in English that let you set the pace, rather than be led around with a group by a guide that is difficult to understand. The history behind the church is amazing, having been built on the foundations of the last Inca king, started in 1550 and finished 100 years later. It is gaudy by some standards what with all the gold and silver the conquistadors plundered - but it works.

Guinea pig for Last Supper. The cathedral is probably more impressive from outside than inside, but worth your time if you made the trip all the way to Peru. Look for the Last Supper painting where guinea pig is served.
Beautiful cathedral :). Beautiful cathedral in the heart of Cusco. I would recommend to go in if its open - remember not to take photos :)

Different century architecture in one building.. We visited here on the Independence Day in Peru. They had a parade. We also arrived before 10am and could hear the choir singing. It was beautiful. I was thankful we had our guide from REI adventures to share important information as we toured the facility.
Most. A most if your like art ....one of the big collection of religious art in all Peru ....In front of Paza de Armas ...

Great church, excellent architecture and paintings. It is a good idea to stop by the Cathedral, located in the Plaza de Armas, since it has many interesting paintings and it is a good example of Peruvian architecture. The Cathedral is in fact part of a complex that ties three churches together. All of them are worth looking into.Of particular interest is a painting of the "Last Supper" where the main dish is a barbecued Cui, a mainstay of the Cusco cuisine.

Quite a switch from the standard Spanish Cathedrals. If you look carefully, you will realize that this Cathedral supplanted an Inca Temple. If you have seen the Spanish cathedrals anywhere such as Sevilla, you are used to Moorish renovations. This one is quite unique. It is beautiful and a good example of the only riches which were not carted away to Spain.

Interesting art . If you like cathedrals it's worth a visit. 25 Soles entry which includes an audio guide (You'll need a passport or driving licence to deposit for the audio guide).Plenty of religious artwork and silver to keep your interest. The audio guide also gives a detailed history about its construction and earthquake damage. The cathedral contains the oldest cross in the Americas. It also has an interesting depiction of the last supper. No photos or videos. You can buy postcards and books and other paraphernalia at the end of the tour.

Worth taking 2 to 3 hours to tour the four churches included in this tour. Get the pass for the four churches: cathedral, museum, San Blas, and San Esteban. Ask for the audio equipment (it is included in your ticket, but if you do not ask for it, they will not give it to you). It is worth while touring this. If you have to miss one church, miss San Esteban. But please do not miss San Blas!!
Large interesting place. Not the best cathedral, as Arequipa is more friendly and looks better, it is however an interesting place, though the statues with real hair on are a little worrying
Worth the trip.. It's an interesting place. You can ascend a narrow passage way to get up to a landing for a good view of the plaza.
Astonishing. This is a gorgeous place, must visit. Never thought we would find something like that in the small town in South America.

Beautiful Cathedral!. We were on a guided city tour when we visited this church and I don't think I would have done it any other way. I would not have picked up on any of the details and the history the guide provided was great! The only sad part is no pictures inside, although I did purchase a beautiful picture book at the end of the tour.This is a definite must see!

Quite unique, very expensive.. Nice... and unique in its own way of course with those Quechua influences in the catholic art: that's nice. But it's too expensive!! Typical Cusco tourist trap.... So just think about whether you think it's worth it...
Visting Cusco. Don't miss seeing this church while in Cusco! Lovely place! We were on a guided city tour. Nice grounds and gardens, too.

When the details make the whole picture. Definitely worth while visiting with a guide as there is quite a lot of subtleties among the pieces of art inside. Our guide (Rodney) helped us how local artists that has been contracted to paint the conquistadores' wishes kept twisting tiny details to express the discontent of the population with the invaders that turned out not to be such gods after all. So spend the time and money to learn about the history through this visit.

Golden. The workmanship in the Spanish churches is phenomenal. Worth seeing a few of them. If Catholicism isn't your thing this is still worth it as the gold inside is not to be believed. Remember the Spanish looted the Inca's for gold.
The church. One of the most beautiful churches in Peru. I recommend the visit. And don't forget the audio guide (free).
Surprised me. I loved Cuzco--don't forget altitude meds. Lots to see, lively, old, archeology and trendy night life.

Very beautiful . A must see here in cusco. If you plan on going, which you should, there is the ticket "Circuito Religioso Arzobispal" which includes the cathedral, templo de San Blas, templo de San Cristóbal and Museu Arzobispal. They are not that great as the cathedral but the entire ticket will cost 15 soles. So if you have a spare time you could go.

One of the best in the world. This is one of the best cathedrals that I have ever seen. It is located at the center of Cuzco. It is filled with silver and gold materials which makes it attractive. Besides of these richness, paintings about colonial times are worth to see. The last supper of Jesus with spanish conquistador Francisca Pizzaro is worth to see. Different Jesus paitings are also interesting.
Don't miss it!!. The cathedral is the single biggest reason to go to the town square. The inside of this cathedral will leave you in awe.

Not to be missed. This is really three churches in one. The original cathedral, now The Church of the Triumph, adjoins the present basilica on the south, while to the north is the Church of the Holy Family, with a magnificent altarpiece. The cathedral itself has many fascinating paintings by early Peruvian converts.A fascinating insight into evangelistic methods is a huge Last Supper with a guinea pig (a favoured dish for Incan solemn occasions) on the table in front of Jesus. One of the highlights is the raised choir at the west of the nave.
vacations at Cusco. Excellent and beautiful place to learn about the history of the Inca and the Spaniards interaction since the early dates. The art collection is grat.

Wonders to see inside. This cathedral was begun in 1560 and took more than 100 years to complete and is well worth your time to explore. There are many interesting things to see including the main altar which is crafted of Bolivian silver and weighs more than 880 pounds (400 kg)! Wonderfully built over an 11 year period by the famous silversmith Pinelo. The Lord of the Earthquakes crucifix is said to have calmed the 1650 earthquake and be sure to take in the Last Supper painting depicting Christ feasting on chuy and corn beer, both local Inca staples. And the intricately carved cedar choir has beautiful depictions of saints and popes throughout.If you've made it all the way to Cusco you shouldn't miss seeing the inside of this church.

need a guide for this one. Seeing the cathedral is fascinating but there is so much history embedded in its walls that one should only have to get a knowledgeable guide that can explain to you what it is you are experiencing.
If you go early you can get in free. Went at 8am so the place was quiet and entrance was free. The Cathedral has some impressive paintings.

Wonderful architecture and exhibition. The architecture and history of the cathedral is worth a visit but the exhibition of Cusco school painters and their colonial counterparts was excellent and insightful. Wonderful paintings and explanation of the era that brings a new dimension to this period in Peruvian history.

Beautiful, worth a visit. This is an impressive cathedral with lots of interesting artwork and an amazing altar on the inside, although it does not quite match the standards of many of the large cathedrals I've seen in Europe. Even so, it is worth some time to visit if you have some time to spare in Cusco. The admission charge was 25 sols/per adult (about 8 USD).
A must see. The tour inside the church is incredible. It is the most beautiful church that we've seen (we have not been in Europe).
Cusco. The architecture, the history, the people ... just fabulous! A trip of a lifetime and a must do for eveyone.

Impressive Art!. The amazing architecture take in a vivid trip to the colonial time in Cusco and the beatiful paintings show a unique mixture of the Spanish and local ways to represent different aspects of daily and spiritual life.

A cathedral to rival Notre Dame. I was very impressed by this cathedral. The architecture was stunning. The decor was appalling---only because so much came from theft from the Incan natives. But it is definitely a cathedral worth seeing.

Excellent Tour. Again, as with other places in Cusco, I think you're doing to do best with a guide -- because a guide can tell you all the meaning that you wouldn't get otherwise. I especially liked hearing about the ways in which the Incan painters told an indigenous story along with the Christian.

Wonderful cathedral. This is really one of the most amazing cathedrals I've ever visited. It's huge and it's beautiful. The carvings are fantastic, and are all painted in gold. The silver work on the alter pieces are gorgious as well. The figures representant the Virgin, Jesus and different saints are typical south american/spanish dressed in elaborate textiles. There are a lot of paintings - some good and some not so good.

Worth a visit. We went to the Catedral Del Cuzco with a guide, we recommend this as there is so much history in this building. We are not Catholic but enjoyed all the beauty and history of this building. the wood work is incredible.

Lovely architecture and some nice art. The building is lovely, of course, and there is plenty of art to take in. I went during mass so I lingered and didn't get in anybody's way. The vocalist was very good and added to the peaceful experience.
Last Supper Guinea Pig. Beautiful church, as are the many we visited. If you like the architecture and history of churches then it's a must see.

Tour this one twice!. Heard perspectives from someone with Incan ancestory, and also from someone with Spanish and Catholic heritage. Two different paradigms, both different from our own, gave more insight into the depths of perspectives in this historically rich city.

Do the Audio/Visual tour. We were in Quito as well and we visited over a dozen well know churches and this was tops. Have your passport with you to do the audio tour. My daughter wanted to absorb it on her own. It only takes about 30 minutes and you get information as you are gawking at the magnificent handicraft surrounding you.

cateddral. Its a fantastic cathedral, on entering look to the Leftthere is a local painting of the last supper , Jesus sorroundedwith the apostles ,look closely and see there is a wine gobletand on the plate is a plate no bread but a guinea pig

Iconic. Huge, ancient, with the feel of medieval Catholicism. Well guided and a real window on the Spanish Catholic presence and how the native people tried to make it there own. I found being in there quite oppressive.

A Lot of History. We toured the Basilica Catedral as part of our Incan civilization education. This is a tour best completed with a guide as it consists of layer upon layer of history. The BC is regretfully suffering from a great deal of deferred maintenance but is still a grand component of the area. BC provides examples of expert carvings and the application of gold leaf. This church, like many of its era, has collected a great deal to see during a tour. To some this may seem overwhelming.
What a sight. More art than many art museums. Amazing architecture. The self-guided audio/viseotour on a tablet was very good.

Must see Cathedral in Cuzco!. Located in the heart of Cuzco you cannot fail to see this great cathedral. We visited with our tour guide who provide us with great insight into the history and significance of the cathedral as well as the influence of the Spanish who typically built all their religious buildings on top of Inca religious structures.You need at least an hour or two to fully appreciate the entire cathedral. There is a small fee for the visit, but it is well worth it!

Don't miss this. Looks impressive from the outside but is more impressive on the inside. However, you do need to have a guide or some sort of book to really help you appreciate the uniqueness and beauty. We were here when all the statues had been brought in for a celebration from surrounding churches and it was very amazing to see.

Impressive! Worth the visit!. This was a part of my City Tour, not something I would have picked otherwise. Was nothing but impressed once inside. So much more than you expect, an absolutely glorious place. Also I'm not religious and still throughly enjoyed the history and architecture.

Bigger than it looks. I thought the Basilica was just the center section; I neglected to notice that on each side of the main Basilica are two attached cathedrals.... all are connected and open to one another on the inside. If you've made it the Plaza, don't miss seeing the inside of this Basilica.
Imposing Cathedral. Quite a site that dominates the plaza. The Cathedral is worth seeing, and taking in all the art etc. A bit expensive though at 25s per person.

Beautiful & interesting. If you are even slightly interested in architecture and history you will enjoy a tour of this building. The interior is quite spectacular and the workmanship visible in every aspect & artwork is fantastic. Take the self guided tour or just wander and marvel at the 'over the top' decoration, you can't help but be impressed. The only thought that kept coming into my head was what it must have cost to build while the people lived in poverty, but I guess that is pretty much the same the world over. Allow at least an hour to see it all. Only drawback is that no photography is allowed.
Beautful and interesting. Beautiful church with lots of interesting tidbits of the spanish influence and how the peruvian culture changed as well as excellent craftmenship.

Must See in Cusco. The Cathedral is the center of the lives of the people of Cusco. The majority of all who live in Cusco are Catholic. The architecture is stunning and the interior truly speaks to the history of the town beautifully. It is located in the Plaza in the center of Cusco. So, there is also lots to do and see in the Plaza as well.

i am not a church goer - this is well worth a visit. Not the prettiest of religious building from the outside and was not expecting much.Was I wrong!When we entered we had to leave some id e.g. driving licence to borrow a tablet and headphones. It was already set-up to hear English speaking guide (multiple languages available).Off we went being directed by pictures of what we should be looking at and listening about the history of each piece.In side the Cathedral was huge and kept opening up into different areas.We learnt about the culture, the people of old were taught about morals.Lots of gold and fascinating relics.We must have spent over an hour wondering around and built up a thirst afterwards so went to Paddy's Bar (also worth a visit) - where there's a Church there is usually a pub!

Great example of Spanish architecture.. This cathedral was certainly worth a visit. Very ornate and traditional interior. More gold and silver than in many other Catholic churches/cathedrals. Great area of the city to wander.

Cathedral visit a must. This was one of the most ornate architectural structures I have ever seen. Tremendous replicas of art work. Numerous great statues and floats. This is truly a must to see if you are in this area

Impressive Hostorical Cathedral. The Cuzco Cathedral was impressive both in its beautiful decoration and its history. The main altar is stunning. There are a lot of paintings including the most famous one, the Cuzco version of the Last Supper (with chicha and guinea pig). The Black Christ side altar was also very interesting. The catherdral was built on top of old Inca ruins. There is an S/. 25 admission fee (Turistico Boleto does not work), but you get an audio/visual set which marvelously explains the important points in the cathedral and the colonial era. Though the European cathedrals might be bigger, the Cuzco one stands up well.

Stunning Spanish Architecture. This is a beautiful church. If church visits are your thing, you should go here. The Spanish designed this basilica to teach the Cusco locals Catholic history with paintings. They also used a lot of silver and gold, used by the locals to represent the moon and the sun, in their designs. Plus, all of the clothing of the Virgin Mary are in the shape of a mountain!

Visually Impressive. A beautiful cathedral, visually stunning. Beautiful architecture and ornate, glorious golden decorations on the inside. Surprisingly impressive cathedral and would recommend the audio tour. It's no Notre Dame or Westminster but it's a pleasant and interesting way to spend an hour.

Impressive. very impressive complex, main cathedral alter and side altars and two side churches. Excellent interior structure and paintings. 25 soles pp to enter, not cheap for Peru. Pity no photos allowed inside but understandable why.
Plaza de Armas - Cusco Cathedral. This beautiful Cathedral was built during the 16th & 17th centuries, it is filled with colonial paintings. It is a must see if you are in Cusco.

Get audio guide. Main cathedral in Cuzco and worth the audio guided tour of the chapels. The grandeur of the space combined with the explanations of the chapels makes for a good 60-90 minute intro to the interaction between Catholism and Inca religion.

Much like every other church, but larger. I'm not a huge fan of churches, but I visited many on my trip through Peru. The Basilica Cathedral is more expensive than many others (12.5 soles for students, 25 for others) and offers much of the same views, no pictures allowed. However, it does have several chambers/rooms. If you don't hire a guide, you can sit in on the tour groups that are going on. When I visited, there were at least 3 English-speaking tours going on, and no guide said anything when I hung around behind the group and listened. There are also English signs explaining some of the areas, so the guides are not needed.Overall, decent church but much like all others.

Lovely. Both of the cathedrals in the Plaza are worth visiting. They are stunning, and have really cool stuff inside! Make sure you go up or down all the stairways - there's hidden stuff! Watch for the Inca signs of rebellion hidden around.

Golden altars as you have never seen. So much gold and silver used in many of the altars; is jaw dropping. Hire a tour guide to walk the cathedral it is worth it. After your tour sit outside on the stairs in front of the cathedral and just enjoy for a while the energy of the place. Buy a coffee or tea and take this time to feel the peace of the place you have just visited.

Grand and extravagant. The cathedral is very grand, incredibly ornate and mind blowingly sumptuous in gold and silver, as well as having extraordinarily detailed wood carvings abundance ... a must if you go to Cusco.

Every year the statues are brought to the cathedral in procession. The cathedral itself is interesting, because of the combination of different buildings from different periods of time.What made our visit especially interesting was that the annual procession of the statues for redressing them just took place. Unfortunately the procession in which the would be brought back to the respective cathedrals took place after we left.

Not just another church. The size of this cathedral is mind boggling. The art is a little different from what we were used to finding in churches. Take a guided tour if possible so as not to miss the Incan influence on Spanish Catholicism>

Very Old church and very well mantained. It is very old Incan Palace and main centre for the worship of the sun god. after spanish conquered the city they bulit a church over this temple. Even though it is very old the site has been kept in excellent condition and it is amazing to see how big and how well the structure is bulit so many years ago without machines etc.

Take the Audio Tour. It was well worth the money to take the audio tour throughout the cathedral. The workmanship was unbelievable. The gold leaf altar was stunning. Knowing the history behind each side altar made the visit much more interactive. I was disappointed you could not take any pictures.

Beautiful cathedral, gave me goosebumps, must visit!. I really enjoyed visiting this cathedral. It was so dark, so mysterious, so breathtaking. The artwork and statues inside were really a sight to see. The moment I walked in I felt calmness in my soul, and it gave me goosebumps. I would love coming back here again.
Main Catedral in Cusco. The Catedral is large, but the style inside is very gaunty and more of a place of worship than tourist spot. It's worth a visit, but not really a main thing to see.

Worth seeing the architecture and and the beauty of this catedral. The inside was beautiful and the architecture like most of the other churches we had been to.If one is into history of churches then it would be worth getting a guide, although there was free audio tour available.

Magnificent. The sheer magnificence of the intricate works on the cathedral is worth the visit. It's centrally located and you can't just miss it. Take your time walking about and enjoying the artistry of the place.
Worth a look. All these Cathedrals are worth making a visit to them. The detail of the churches are extremely interesting, along with the history of the time.

Look Into Peruvian History. Just like pretty much everything else you are doing in Peru, the Cathedral del Cuzco is a look into the history of Peru. It's not unlike any other Catholic Church that you would visit in Europe-- great art, gaudy alters and stunning architecture.When we went in, the have tour guides waiting to to offer you a full tour in English. The rates/times are negotiable. However, they have a free audio tour. We did that, and felt it was very informative, and told us everything we wanted to know. Also allowed us to go at our pace, and skip sections we didn't really care about.No photos/video is allowed inside the Cathedral.

A Fascinating Place. For 25 Soles each, the tour came with use of a tablet and headphones with a tour program that guided us through the basilica and gave a good explanation and background of what we were seeing. I found especially interesting, the many examples of the way the Catholic Church presented its liturgy in the context of the Inca Culture. For example, there is a large mural of the last supper. The main course was guinea pig (a common Inca dish) and the other items on the table were food common in the Inca diet. Photography is strictly prohibited, It would have been good if they included a C/D with pictures as part of our admission as other churches did.

Glad we went !. This cathedral was part of our "Discover Peru" tour. The cathedral is gorgeous. The altar has lots of precious metals and you head is always on a swivel as you are wondering what you will see next. Don't miss the last supper painting. If you are not with a tour guide go before 8 AM and the admission is free. Photos however are not permitted in the cathedral.

Must see if touring Cusco. The Cathedral has a very rich history dating back to the period of Spanish conquest. My favorite part, though, was a rich discussion by our guide about the indigenous artists who learned to paint in Europe and then returned to add a bit of Incan culture (and some fun resistance to the Spanish) into their gifted replications of European paintings.

Holy Seat of the Cusco catholics. The best part about this cathedral is the numerous paintings within. It is a very serene place whereby you can spend hours just sitting inside.Must see the last supper painting and being painted by a cusconean artist, don't forget to notice the unusualness about it. I don't want to point it out in my review and rob you of the discovery.Also, goto this cathedral before 8 AM and the entry is free.

A must see. This spectacular cathedral is stunningly opulent! If you only visit one cathedral in South America, this must be the one. Mid blowing amounts of gold & silver decorate everything.. Beautiful paintings and some interesting(!) statues.

Includes a Must-see Painting. If you are Catholic, you will find this cathedral interesting, especially if you are a Catholic from another part of the world where your practice is slightly different (example: Mary accending, Mary descending). If you are not Catholic, it may all seem a bit over the top in the same way as a carnival. But you must see the painting of the last supper which is really great. It features a guinea pig as part of the meal and Judas is portrayed to look like Francisco Pizzaro.
beautiful. The church was the most beautiful things i have ever seen I am a Catholic it is said it is the 2nd most beautiful church in the Americas it really is amazing.

Amazing. Very interesting cathedral, as you would expect, tons of history, loads of gold and silver. Many interesting facts provided by our guide, incredible carving of the tons of Peruvian Cedar wood all around. Well worth a visit.

Just Amazing. Every so often when travelling you find your self somewhere that leaves you lost for words. This is such a place. I don't want to say to much about it because I think it is better enjoy the surprise. But as churches go it really is gob smacking. Just worth mentioning though the painting of the last supper. This was done by a local artist. When you find it look for something on the table that definitely would not have been there at the time of Jesus. Obviously his little joke!
Beautiful cathedral. It is worth seeing and paying the 25 soles to enter the cathedral. I recommend it and also to pay the 10 soles to enter the neighboring cathedral Compania de Jesus.
Very interesting. Definitely visit it and take a tour in order to understand most of what was going on in Cusco at the time

Glimmering. It’s a shame that you can’t capture the beauty since photography is strictly prohibited. The views on the other hand are such that it makes you want to pick up a camera. As much as it is beautiful from the outside, the interiors is a different story altogether. It is quite evident that a whole lot of wealth was gathered for the construction of the church. The historical aspect though is a bit painful one owing how the people were forced to gather means for its construction.

Very large in a city of fairly low rise buildings. The cathedral is located in the main square. Inside the cathedral it is huge with lots of paintings, statues, side alters and wings to it. Ornate baroque, gold leaf, and French style carved wooden alter - it is dazzling in its art work.

Beautiful. The Catedral was part of the religious circuit tour. We bought the ticket that included six religious sites in Cusco. There was an audio-guide that helped give us perspective of the rich history of the site as well as the city. There were plenty of artifacts and religious works of arts to see. This is a must see if one is in Cusco.
Have You Ever Seen a South American Cathedral?. Unless you're in love with cathedrals and you haven't seen any other ones in South America, I would give this one a miss.

Take the audio tour. This rivals the finest Maneuline cathedrals of Spain and Portgual. There's so much to see, at least get the audio tour if not an actual tour guide. You'll spend a good 2 hours if you pause to see the major elements, more if you read the plentiful plaques (Spanish only).

Lovely example of Spanish influence. Incredibly ornate, the gem on the Plaza de Armas is worth touring for both architecture and art. A good introduction to the influence of the Spanish and Catholic church on Peru.

Beautiful and surprising. Nowhere did I see the terrible destruction of the Incan empire by the Spanish empire more clearly than in this cathedral with its sometimes subversive native produced art and its obvious display of plundered Incan ruins (stones of Saqsaywaman were used to build the cathedral.) The Spanish routinely built their cathedrals on he site of ancient Incan temples to display their domination and this is no exception. Inside the cathedral you can see The Last Supper depicted with a Cuy (guinea pig) and other local delicacies gracing the table of Jesus Christ and his disciples. It's a beautiful and grand cathedral. the Pintura Senor de los Temblores is a fascinating painting depicting the city during the 1650 earthquake. The gorgeous silver alter, the "Black Christ", and the choir room are also fantastic to see. Great site.

Gold,gold, and more gold!. I have never seen so much gold leaf covering cedar wood .It must run into many thousands of kilos!There are three churches here combined into one as the years past by,it is spacious, well guarded and of course there is a fee to enter!The pope will visit this very Catholic country in July. I wonder what he will think of so much gold!

Overwhelming. The cathedral and its surroundings are very impressive.One can marvel at the construction and the enormous presence of gold and artwork imported from Spain.However, despite all these favorable impressions, one is reminded that the work was carried out be indigenous slaves who also had to provide the gold.Could leave a bit of a sour taste.
beautiful church. Went with the group. Lots to see ... beautiful church, but as usual shows how much money was spent for the church than for the people.

Mixture of Cultures. So I thought went I toured this that it would just be a beautiful cathedral but there was so much history to it and it too combined peruvian beliefs with Catholocism. There was a black Christ of Tremors. It was very opulent but our guide told us that in the 1980's that the poor were allowed to stay here while they got back on their feet.

Cavernous and riddled with gold and local Religious Artwork. One thing I wish I could have done when I visited the 2nd largest Cathedral in South America is to take pictures. But taking pictures or videos is strictly prohibited. Even during mass, the prohibitive signs are everywhere which was a letdown for me since I was hoping that I would be able to get pictures when I attended mass. But anyway, the cathedral is composed of three churches. The one of the left riddled with gold and the other on the left, riddled with Silver. The one on the center was a mixture of both. And the Entire Cathedral had small chapels in it too. The difference with this cathedral and the other cathedrals I have visited before was the limited seating it has. I think it is because the choir room is not located in the loft of a church but it is at the ground floor of the church and covers almost half of the area of the cathedral. That being said, it was very interesting to see Church paintings and sculptures made by local painters and sculptures that despite being Christian, also had the "Inca" or Cuzco element in it. For instance, the painting of the Last Supper had the Guinea Pig in it and some sculptures of the Blessed Virgin Mary was shaped like a mountain which was (they said) what the Inca's believe represent Nature/ Earth.I hoped that they include a CD with all the pictures inside the Church with the 25 soles entrance in the future just as the Jesuit Church did on the other side of the Plaza (but just for 10 soles). But

Outside is the best part. this cathedral was built with the spoils of the Incas to crush their spirit and prove the superiority of Spanish colonialism. The most interesting part of the tour was that after 100 years of building (the Spanish weren't as efficient as the Incans) pacha mama (Mother Earth) had enough and it was completely destroyed by an earthquake. Alas is was rebuilt in full Spanish rococo style and is over the top busy busy busy and shiny. Buy a postcard of the last supper with the guinea pig and sit outside in the sun with a beverage of your choice.

Beautiful piece of history . Such a beautiful historic cathedral to visit. Well worth the donation. Take a local guide to learn about the history. Disappointing to see tourists being disrespectful in this cathedral. I really think if you want to visit, do take the opportunity but respect the culture of others and don't ruin the experience of others that are there!! I'm not a religious person, but I was moved by this experience.

Take your time. This is an amazing sight, especially if your experience of cathedrals is limited to the Gothic austerity of the great European ones. This is an expression of faith written in very large letters, burnished with gold, and shouting "Alleluia!" So much to see, so much to learn. Look out for the side altar that doubles as a float in the Corpus Christi procession - it's too heavy for people to carry, so it's mounted on a truck chassis. You can see the steering-wheel poking up through the altar-cloth - quite an anachronism.It's a great shame you can't take photographs, but after all, it is a sacred place.

Glitz Glore!. If you enjoy a church with stunning altars of gold and silver plating, you will be duly impressed with the Catedral de Cusco. This is really a combination of three separate churches linked together to make up the catedral. One of the three alters is adorned in stunning gold plating and another in silver plating. Part of the granite blocks used for the building came from the ruins of Sacsayhuman after it was destroyed by the Spanish. The walls are covered with interesting paintings including one of the Last Supper.

impressive. The 25 Soles entry fee and picture ban is stiff compared to iglesia de Jesus at 10 Soles with a gift photos CD on the other side of Plaza de Armas. Still it is impressive to visit. But the real 5 Stars gem is 35 kms away at San Pedro de Andahuaylillas. Also 10 Soles with CD>

Amazing. We went to the Cathedral on the recommendation of our tour guide. We had no idea what to expect. Most importantly don't forget to get the audio guide after you get in. It is included in the price and really helps explain everything. The cathedral complex was huge and took almost an hour to see the whole thing. We have seen many churches and cathedrals all over Europe this is the first one we have seen with so much gold and silver. It was really overwhelming and definitely worth a visit.

Absolutely breathtaking art. Only 10 soles to enter and you get an English taped tour. Best value in Cusco! The many alters and 14-15 century art is so beautiful. Especially all the gold and silver put in the cathedral. Takes an hour to really appreciate all of the skill put in building and decorating this cathedral. Much more impressive then the outside would lead you to believe.
Beautiful. One of the most beautiful cathedrals in the world, great history and the mix of andean and spanish culture is great.

Ornate, but with a sad history. This is probably the most ornate and richly decorated cathedrals that I have ever seen. The main altar, and every shrine are richly and ornately decorated in gold or silver. However, there is nothing of the history of where all this gold and silver originated. Basically, it was all stolen from the Qechua, (Inca's), by the Spanish Conquistadores. Think about this if you visit.
huge, amazing historic basilica. im a basilica fan and this is one of the better ones ive seen. incredible art and artifacts, best seen with a good tour guide

Grandiose and Opulent rather than Beautiful. Listening to the universal oohs and aahs of everyone around me, I sure my opinion is a minority one, and even feel it only fair to rate it as very good. This actually three churches which are adjacent to each other and connected: the church of the Triumph (over the Incas), the Cathedral, and the church of the Sagrada Family. Many, many well-done statues, most dressed on gorgeous gowns. Elaborate baroque altars of silver, a Sala de la Plata (roomful of Silver), lots of gold too. Painting after Huge painting, almost every one by that most prolific of Baroque artists: Anonymous of the Cusco School. A side room full of portraits of princes of the Church, towering wooden carvings, a crypt where the mortal remains of one of the most famous early chroniclers of Inca civilization (the son of a Spanish noble and Inca princess) may lay, or not; all the identified deceased are churchmen, and all died in the 19th century or later. This is conspicuous opulence on steroids, sort of like a Mafia don being driven through Brooklyn in a gold-plated Bentley. Exactly how all this relates to the teachings of the Little Shepherd of the Poor I leave to the theologians.What I do is that while the fabulous CAN also be breath-takingly beautiful (e.g. San Pietro in Rome and Santa Maria Della Fiori in Florence). The Michelangelos and Giottos of the architectural world, alas, had nothing to do with this! It is possible to have buildings which use massive amounts of silver and gold, but are still beautiful: the silver Ordination Hall in Chiang Mai comes to mind. The Golden Pavilion in Kyoto manages to be perfectly beautiful in Zenlike simplicity, despite all that gold. Here, you get conspicuous ostentation to the Nth degree. However, there's something to be said for being a contender for most ostentatious house of worship on Earth, and if you're in Cusco, it's well worth-while wandering in.

Gorgeous!!!!!!. Possibly the most beautiful cathedral I've ever seen in Latin America. Unfortunately photos are not allowed but they use to sell a book about this Cathedral . I recommend , regardless of religion, know this symbol of Cuzco.

Never seen so many altars and religious icons under one roof.. Beautiful and impressive colonial cathedral that took a hundred years to build.The number of altars and selection of religious art within this building is as impressive as the structure itself.Many of these are used for for different religious festivals, where they are carried out and paraded around the town.Worth visiting just for the irrevernt local interpretation of the Last Supper painting, complete with roasted guinea pig centre table and Judas, bearing the face of Francisco Pizzaro!

Eclectic and beautiful. This cathedral was built over many years, and its styles reflect this. Most interesting is its combination of traditional Catholicism and local culture, including a painting of the Last Supper with a roasted guinea pig in the center.

The Basilica Catedral of Cuzco is well worth visiting.. This Catedral is many faceted and full of treasures of a spiritual and economic kind. The Catedral is well preserved and our tour took us to each of the main facets of the site. It is clear that this facility has a very strong hold on the Cuzco community and it will be here for decades to come. Visit this unique Catedral and enjoy the history of Cuzco.

Breathtaking. It is said that this is the most beautiful Cathedral in the Americas. I was in awe of the gold, silver, artwork, workmanship. This was definitely my favorite spot after Machu Picchu on our tour. No photos are allowed, but they sell a wonderful book in both English and Spanish for memories. There is no comparison though to standing in awe at this beautiful cathedral.

Beuatiful. Worth to visit and pay the ticket. This cathedral is one of the most beautiful I have ever see, including the ones in europe, were you find the best ones. Is full of cuscan art of the colonial period, and very well maintained.
VERY HISTORIC. A must visit in Cuzco this cathedral is very opulent, clean, old (good way). The artifacts were amazing to behold. My only disappointment is that we could not take pictures.

Very well done visit program, worth the cost. The cathedral is quite large and very interesting. Yes there is an entry fee for visitors. But having thousands of visitors going through a church creates need for maintenance and security that the locals shouldn't pay for. The cost is very reasonable considering it covers several places and includes an audio guide at each place. The audio guide was surprisingly good. It provides real information and background that makes the visit more meaningful. While the politics that led to the conquest of Peru and construction of the cathedral might be despicable, your visit to the cathedral with the audio guide will help you understand more of the history.

Beautiful Cathedral. If you are into architecture, history, or Inkan theology, this is a great place for you to check out!There are many beautiful Madonnas and and paintings within. A lot of the Catholicism from the Spaniards, you will find, has an Incan spin. This way the Incans did not have to conform to the new religion without relinquishing their own beliefs.
Excellent example of Catholic Church. This is a very old building that has been perfectly mantained. Still in use today, you can get a graps of what the catholic life is like today in Cusco.

Great cathedral - full of contrasting styles. Spent 20 minutes enjoying the contrasting styles of this wonderful colonial cathedral. The Last Supper is a very local take on an iconic scene but we particularly liked the pretty silver altars. Over the top but wonderful!

The grandest cathedral in all Americas. To top the Incan achievements in Cuzco, the Spaniards decided to build a cathedral whose interior design and rich decoration would be among the best of its kind even in their native Spain. Chapels rich in decorations, beautiful choir, big paintings above each doorway, monumental entrance doors, etc.It's a pity you can't take photos inside, while the publications they sell have photos of very, very poor quality (poor focus, unnatural colors). Such a shame...
beautiful cathedral on the Plaza de armas. A rich site with a lot of history, with an interesting architecture, interior design and paintings.There are a lot of tourists.

Beautiful and interesting history. This cathedral literally sparkles with its lavish gold altars. The history of the Spanish conquistadors is very present here and makes a tour of this beautiful cathedral key to understanding the culture and history of the area.
grotesque. the best and the greatest cathedral in cuzco. full of pictures. The entrance is S./25!!! To enter for free you have to go on misa "mass" between 6.3-9 am.
Cusco nice place. one of the place to be in Cusco, indeed the architecture is very nice and inside it is like a travel in another time

Crazy Story. Great time here with our guide. The most interesting to us was the story of the statue of Jesus that was given to the people as a gift from the Spaniards. As for the rest, the cathedral is very ornate and beautiful but please note that we have never visited cathedrals oversees (out of the USA), so we cannot compare it to any others.

Beautiful Cathedral. We were lucky because it is not always open but there was a mass being held and we managed to enter. Otherwise, one has to visit it by buying a ticket, but the feeling of being there during a religious service gives it a different dimension.

Worth a visit. We were in Cusco before doing the inca trail. We hadn't planned to visit but very glad we did. We paid a little extra ( about £6) for a personal guide who took us round the cathedral and explained everything and the history behind the building and the interior. The cathedral is different from any European one I have been to. The Inca/Spanish influences were fascinating. We also saw restoration work in action on some of the artworks. Well worth a visit.

old spanish cathedral. The usual large spanish church. Although they do have an interesting painting of the last supper. The natives have a different take on christianity. And it shows in their statues of the saints.The altars are beautiful. A must see.

cathedral tour. The cathedral is in great shape inside and out. I wish we could have taken pictures inside, but they would not let us. The church was ornate and filled with old paintings, gold, and silver. Lots of wood carvings. It was beautiful to see.

On the way to Machu Pichu. We had to stay thee days in Cuzco before going to Machu Pichu. Beautiful city rich in Inca and Spanish history. Very cold in mornings and nights so we had to buy alpaca sweaters which can be purchased from high end boutiques or street vendors. The Peruvians are very religious, so expect to see many amazing Virgin Marys and Saints dressed in heavy coats of gold. The plaza de armas is the center of Cuzco where everybody meets at night. Lot of excellent restaurants and local bodegas. There are a lot of Inca ruins and temples around Cuzco not to be missed. Best season to go is From Jan. to March.

Interesting. This cathedral is worth a visit because it is unique. I have visited cathedrals all over the world and have never seen one quite like this. I especially enjoyed the different saints they have statues of.

Beautiful cathedral. I found this cathedral to be quite interesting.It was interesting to see how the Inca people mixed their religious beliefs and culture with Christianity. For example, pay close attention to the paintings! Eventhough some are are replicas from Europe, there are llamas and guinea pigs in the paintings! There are three parts to this Cathedral and it cost 25 soles to go inside. However, I noticed that the doors of the cathedral was open to the public and you didn't need to pay (maybe during service time?)You can't take photos in the cathedral. If you try, a security person will come to you and tell you no.
Fantastic experiance. Defenetely worth seeing.. Of all the Cathedral's we saw in Peru, this was the most unique. Great history and surprisingly beautiful.

Great, European influenced Cathedral - beautiful experience. The Cathedral is quite impressive. Although, the outside is a bit plain, the inside is gorgeous. It is more interesting and ornate than the cathedral in Lima. Absolutely beautiful, full of silver and gold. Easily compares with the churches and cathedrals of Europe. Second only to St. Peters. in Rome Many chapels to explore. I had a private guide but there is an audio option as well. Go early and attend Mass to get the full experience. Also, make sure and see the Last Supper painting. It is truly huge and depicts Christ and the disciples feasting on guinea pig. This is a must see while in Cuzco. The only negative is that photography of any kind is not allowed inside.

A visit helps you understand history. We found our visit to the cathedral to be worthwhile not only to see the beautiful artwork and altar pieces, but to better understand the methodology used by the conquering Spaniards. Who would have thought that the use of mirrors helped the Spanish to win over the hearts and minds of the Incans?
Huge colonial cathedral. A must see on your visit to Cusco-Machu Picchu. Toured with a guide which was very helpful and worth the $Soles.
Wow. This cathedral is gorgeous and ornate and has of one of the Cuzco School's Last Supper paintings. It was incredible to see. I wish I had more time to spend in the cathedral.

I love taking pictures of this cathedral. This is the first thing you see in entering the Cusco San Blas Plaza. The structure is huge. The inside has three distinct churches in it with several side places to pray. You cannot take pictures inside the cathedral. No matter your religion, it is an interesting place to visit.

Great fusion between different cultures. We did not have a guide, but I had read about this interesting Gothic-Renaissance style cathedral and its history so I was very excited to see all the amazing gold and silver plasted items and the fantastic mixture of indigenous (Inca) and European (Spin) art. It is worth the visit!!

Enjoyed my visit. I had a great guide for my visit. There are great artifacts in this site. I got to hear some great history and gives you great insight on the role of the church in Peruvian life back then. Unfortunately you can take pictures but it was time well spent.
worth a visit. worth visiting to see the very interesting mixture of Christian and indigenous art and sculpture. The painting of the last supper including local delicacies is fascinating!

It is worth the visit. . It is a very historic place with paintings and sculptures.
There is lots of gold and silver plated items that makes you view going to different places at the same time without knowing where to look first.
It is worth the visit
Stunning place to vist. Superb workmanship and beautiful building combine to make this a "must see" in Cusco. In the main square, so very convenient.

Interesting paintings. Definitely an over-the -top style Cathedral dripping with gold and silver. Worth going in to see the Last Supper painting and the Lord of the Earthquakes statue. There are a few English signs to point things out. Unfortunately, no photos can be taken, even without flash and postcards are only sold in packs of 10.

Amazing Fusion of Inca and Catholicism. Our Peruvian National Geographic Guide shared with us the history and "hidden" meaning of many of the statues and paintings in this magnificent cathedral. Without his expert guidance and explanations, we never would have realized the "rest of the story"! Amazing history and beautiful art work.
Worth to visit. One of the best in South America for sure, dont miss it. There is an audio guide (included in the ticket) it works well.

Stunning must see cathedral. More interesting than the cathedral in Lima. Absolutely beautiful and full of history. The silver in the altars is impressive. One side altar has about 350 lbs of silver in a moveable float. Look for the very Cusco Last Supper portrait. Mass here is an experience

Pity About that the Wealth did not go to the Locals. A very impressive cathedral which is comparable to many European cathedral. One wonders what could have been achieved in Peru if the wealth that went into this magnificent cathedral had gone into infrastructure for the local people over the years (better education and hospital facilities for example). Notwithstanding it is still worth a visit.
Gorgeous!. This is the most beautiful and amazing church I have visited! Specially the Sacred Family Chapel! I found the audio tour very boring! It is better to pay for a private tour ($15)
Beautiful. We were there the day after Easter. The flowers were a beautiful addition to a Beautiful Cathedral. This is a must see in Cusco

check out the paintings.. what makes this cathedral worth the visit are the paintings which the Spaniards had the indigenous people do. They lend a local flavor to the religion that is very interesting. Check our the last supper!
Beautiful on the outside, go to mass to get in.. Incredibly expensive to get in as a tourist. Go very early to mass and you'll be able to take a look at it, though you won't be taking pictures.

Amazing!. I recommend the audio tour for La Catedral... there is so much to look at it, the audio tour helped us make sure we didn't miss anything and also knew what we were looking at. No photography is allowed in most churches in Cusco. This probably has helped them to protect the art inside - there is relatively little damage to most of the statues, carvings, etc. Allow plenty of time in this place to take it all in!

Outstanding. I must admit that my expectations were not all that high when entered what I expected to be just another church in a provincial Peruvian center, but I was delightfully surprised. An elaborate beautiful structure, not to be missed.
disappointed. I wish I had enter the cathedral but is so expensive I had to quit, is a shame even at Saint Peter Cathedral is free of charge

Don't bad to check out. Found the church ok and did go in and check everything out nice historical church for the area with significant history to it,But when you traveled to do many cities you can become churched out, so for me its was ok and I did spend about an hour there.

Not a fan. I personally love old churches but this Cathedral was a testament to the Spanish crushing native culture. The audio tour describes it as the 'blending of cultures' but this just felt ignorant to me.It was very expensive and I would not recommend doing the tour. Visit during mass and it is free.

Beautifully rich!!. Not to be missed this church ornated in pure silver and with their enormous "cusqueños" paintings hanging on the walls! And full of history, too, with their sacred tombs of Spanish conquerors, inclusing that one from the bloody Pizarro, the Conqueror of Inca Empire, who was looking for the Eldorado and became, at the same time, the most incredible Inca people slaughterer!

Visited during Holy Week - a real treat. The cathedral can't be missed as is, but we happened to arrive in Cusco on Palm Sunday. Thus began Semana Santa, or Holy Week, and what a week it was.When we entered the cathedral it was already crowded. A mix of tourists and locals stood in awe of the Black Christ as musicians played, singers sang, and various attendants lit incense and threw flowers at the crucifixion. By the time we got back outside, there were thousands of people in the square. The Plaza de Armas was filled with police, military regiments, TV reporters, and more. It was beautiful to see how the society came together to celebrate and was a great time to be visiting.This isn't quite as large or ornate as some of the truly overwhelming cathedrals in Europe, but it is beautiful and definitely worth spending time in.

Amazing historic religious place. If you visit cusco and are interested in art, you can not miss this place. By the enter price, you will have a guided free visit, supported by a tablet and earphones.
You need to get inside!!!. This church is absolutely amazing they don't let you take pictures of the inside but it's worth every minute you go in there.

Gold!. Gold everywhere! The church was beautiful, sure, but with such poverty all around it, how can teh church justify tying up so much wealth in ostentatious display? Kind of rubbed me up the wrong way.
Beautiful. Wonderful traditional cathedral, stunning silver alter. At night when it is lit up, on the outside you can clearly see all the intricate carvings. A gemm, don't miss it.

Cusco's Finest. WOW... Go inside and feast your eyes on some of the finest alters,carvings,frescos,paintings and wealth in gold and silver you will possibly see anywhere.
Still is a working church today although built in 1600's

Look to see the accommodations made to native values. The cathedral certainly dominates in more ways than one and is relatively plain compared with the Jesuit Church just across the road. However what is most interesting is to see the use made of native symbolism in many of the statues and paintings. These are far more dramatic than those in Lima and elsewhere and reflect the strong influence of the Cusco school of artists.

Cathedrals Come and Go, But This One is Signficant. We got to the Cathedral with very little time to spare before closing, but the ascending darkness helped glorify this absolutely gorgeous church. Individual Altars surround the main altar. In my opinion the most mesmerizing was the Black Christ homage. Gold and gold leaf are prevalent in all depictions. Wonderful- not to be missed.

Top attraction in Cusco. huge cathedral with lots to see including a 6 ton silver altar and the Inca version of the painting known as the Last Supper. Lots of Inca influences can be seen in the adapted religious art that adorns the cathedral. no photography allowed.

The Center of Attention. This Cathedral anchors the Plaza de Armas and is the center of attention in the square. Didn't go inside since they charge a fee and you can't take pictures, but a very impressive building on the outside.

Beautiful. Sitting in the plaza looking at he cathedral you can help but marvel at the church's massive size and grandeur. The church is the mother church of the Catholic Archdiocese of Cusco. Next to the church is a smaller one and was the first Christian church to be built in Cosco. Inside you will find many pices of art and artifacts as well as replicas but you will pay to enter.

3 churches in 1 visit. There are 3 facilities connect here to walk through. Some amazing carvings made centuries ago by local artisans. We were told a variety of interesting stories about how the artisans managed to weave Incan beliefs into the Catholic works. Possibly without the Spaniards realizing. Might need some explanation here - we did have a guide with us.

weird. i have been very disappointed when i tried to enter. first of all you need to pay a entry fee to visit it unless you enter during the mass. despite of you wanna enter during the mass, the many entry guards simply tell you that you cannot enter at that time but wait the mass end, pay the entry fee adn then you can do it BUT they dont tell you that you can enter for free t that hour... then they r very strict if you wear shorts or skirts.

For those interested in history and culture...not for families. The Cathedral is one of Cusco's finest blended architectural displays. The building was constructed in 1550 with stones stolen from Sacsayhuamán. And if its cavernous baroque design doesn't wow you, the Cathedral's opulent ceilings, gold and silver altars, and ornate oil paintings certainly will. The paintings were created by local natives that were trained by the Spanish who tried to repress the native culture which occasionally come through...the local artist's interpretation of the last supper with guinea pig. The Cathedral also houses a world-renowned painting believed to depict the earthquake that shook Cusco in 1650. Between the many, many 'Cusco school' paintings and the melding of Catholic and Andean indigenous influences, this is an absolutely fascinating church to visit......if that is where your interests run.
Another beautiful Cathedral. I saw too many churches on my trip to Ecuador and Peru. Had I not seen so many perhaps I could have appreciated this one more.

Impressive church - get the free audio tour. From the outside, this place looked more like a prison than a church to me (I actually went first to the Iglesia de la compaña because it looked more like a cathedral to me from the outside).But inside is a totally different matter. The gothic ceiling in the main sanctuary is impressive. There is gold and silver and paintings everywhere.However, I'm not sure how much I would have appreciated what I was seeing if I had not gotten the audio tour that is included in admission. It was very well done - it directed us around the church with a map that indicated where to stop and look at specific things. I learned a lot about how early church figures used their art to make the Christian story accessible and relevant to the Quechua people in Cusco. It made the whole thing way more interesting than just wandering around and staring at things on my own.Well worth seeing.

Elegant. Very interesting to see what was destroyed by 2 earthquakes and rebuilt. Lots of shrines inside--photos not allowed. Many of the current paintings were done by locals trained by the Europeans before the quakes. A large painting of the Last Supper shows a Cuy (Guinea Pig) on the platter - done to try and attract the indigenous people to Catholicism.Very elegant interior and worth the visit but need a guide to explain everything.

Interesting but not a must. Visited the Catedral was part of the city tour. Was interesting but felt less time would have been sufficient. The altars were not to my liking but I thought the paintings were interesting.
AMAIZINGLY BEAUTIFUL. Gold and silver everywhere, you can't take pictures. However is just beautiful. You have to pay 10 soles to access it.

Not worth money. yes, interesting, old time fan attraction but if you have a family of 4 and spending almost 100$ for a short walk inside was not worth it. Plaza itself is great and fun. many restaurants and places to eat and spend some time with overview to the city
Nice to visit but not a must. If you think you can go back in time come inside the Catedral you will be stepping back in time. Interesting architecture and nice peaceful energy.

In A Word - "Gaudy". If you've seen one church, you've seen this one. It's beauty is on the outside. The architecture is again of two cultures with the Spanish building on top of the Inca. The best thing about this Church is it's location. It's in the main square, where there's lots to do. There are steps leading to the Church to sit on which gives you a great view of the square.Once inside, there's much gold, art and even a black Jesus (due to all the smoke from the candles) It's huge with many rooms to see but it's redundant. It's decorated with such excess is tasteless.

Spectacular cathedral. We visited it as part of an optional tour on a Gate 1 tour. The two large side chapels, the main altar, the many side altars and the large collection of paintings are beautiful. The large local artist's interpretation of the last supper with guinea pig on the table was very interesting. It was disappointing not to be allowed to take photos inside. We also went back with another couple to a morning mass and the music reverberates throughout the chapel.

Beahtiful catedral inside/out. We went to see this beautiful cathedral part of our Cusco half day tour. It look majestic from outside, located in the northeast sector of the current Plaza de Armas of Cusco. The inside is huge with many original paintings, fabulous decorations and beautiful artworks, it was rather different than the cathedral in Europe. Glad that we had a tour guide that explained the past history of Christianity according to the Peruvian. There is a small fees to entrance the church and museum, unless you attend the morning mass on Sunday. It is a nice place to visit while you are in Cusco.
Spectacular. The Catherdral was a beautiful spot. Paintings and gold decorations were spectacular. The gardens being restored were beautiful and of course the Sun Temple.

3 Churches in One. This is actually 3 churches/museums connected as one building. Very interesting with a number of large artworks present. The most famous is the Last Supper with Guinea Pig as the main entre.

Spectacular. We wanted to see the original Zapata painting of The Last Supper with the guinea pig entree, which brought us to the Catedral. (We ended up buying a pass that allowed entrance to several other locales, which we did not visit. We did not mind, because the price difference was minimal and we knew the money was supporting important sites.) The cathedral is incredible. Overwhelming, actually. Filled with history and artifacts and art. As with most museums, there was so much more than can be taken in in a single visit.
beautiful cathedral. You must go...it is a museum now and you must pay a small fee to enter. You need a guide to help you understand it.

Magnificent. Wow. We have seen and visited many cathedrals but tis one besides history has a lot to see. It is three separate buildings adjoined so that you are able to see it throgh time. It is really a beuty.

Cusco. There are a number of churches in Cusco worthy of a visit, but the Basilica de la Virgen de la Asuncion is really nice. It also contains Marcos Zapata's famous rendition of the Last supper. In Zapata's 1753(?) painting he combines both European and Andean cultural symbols, ie instead of the traditional lamb, this Last Supper features a heaping platter of guinea pigs, beans and corn. On a curiosity level it just kinda of fun to see but on a deeper mufti-cultural level it can be very meaningful. But either way it's worth a peak.Cusco itself is a very accessible town with lots interesting shops,stops and stays to keep you entertained for some time. Check out the Super Mercado, and get a meal there. If you can plan to be in Cusco during the Festival of Corpus Christi, (its like mardi gras, new years and 4th of july all in one) great food street fairs, activities and good times in a non threatening environment

Fantastic. I am not religious but these massive cathedrals are always wondrous. They show case the extent of human ingenuity and perseverance to the highest level. Cuscus cathedral is among the best in Latin America out of the ones I have seen.
Very pretty. A beautiful church with interesting history, can't say much more than that, but the ceiling is worth a look so is the alter very pretty.
cusquenian canvas. here is posible to see all the kind of the cusquenian religious canvas dedicated to the , saints and virgins that in cusco are worshiped.

ABC - Another Beautiful Cathedral. Being in cusco even if you aren't Catholic you shouldn't miss the opportunity to see this place. Fantastic church and completelly packed down of art and great architecture.
Then only down side is people isn't allowed to take pictures but your memories of the place will be the best

Not to miss when going to Cusco. There, you will find an amazing collection of "cusqueños", those wonderful anonimous gold-framed pictures depicting religious themes which are a landmark of this capital city of Inca empire.

Beautiful Cathredral. This is a lovely place - while you can't take photos inside, it's well worth a visit and they have a small gift shop where you can purchase post cards and books. It's an impressive structure.
Beautiful buildings. Fascinating tour of the cathedral - our guide was an older (but very well informed) man and it was great listening to him.

all that gold and silver.... impressive, although it made me feel a little uneasy, knowing where the gold and silver was taken from. Still. take the audio guide. see the "last cene" with Cuy on the table and Judas' face. admire the craft, and the mix between Inca and catholic. A travel through time

amazing wood and gold altars. this is an imponent building, that had survived a few earthquakes, was rebuilt after some others but is still a really beautiful cathedral, with vitrals and amazing altars

The 1st Christian church . We visited with our Gate 1 tour group on February 8. Is this the most opulent and beautiful place of worship? We have visited Rome and in many areas this catedral stands above all others. The wood carvings are fantastic along with the art works. Superior craftsmanship, artistic chapels and atmosphere make this cathedral the place of God. Even non Christians should visit to see a very beautiful building

Glorious Cathedral with Cusqueno School Paintings. This cathedral built in the XVIth Century houses hundreds of colonial paintings from the Cusqueno School, who first "religiously" tried toreproduce the classic style of the European masters, and then later used their art as a form of rebellion against their conquerors. The most famous, perhaps, is the painting of the "Last Supper" by Marcos Zapata, showing Christ and the apostles eating guinea pig ( one of the main courses frequently eaten at sacred feasts in Inca times.) Very worth a visit!

Beauty and opulence amplified by great tour guide. No photos allowed but they wouldn't capture the magic anyway. Huge paintings on wood and canvas. Ornate alters and choir boxes. Catholic and Inca symbolism. The old, older, and ancient. While spectacular in its own right, our native tour guide, Henry Melgarejo, brought out so much that we would have missed! The passive resistance of the Incas is still on display and, like the Spanish, we would have missed all of it without Henry bringing it to life. There is a great deal here that tells the story of Machu Pichu, Cusco, the Incas, and the Conquistador invasion, but you really need a native lens to make it visible. Not to be missed!

Traditions Combined. This is a Catholic Church that combines Inca traditions. The Catholic missionaries forced the Incas to convert centuries ago but they could not force the Incas to totally adopt all the beliefs. While this church is as ornate as they come, covered with gold and silver paid for by some of the very poorest, many of the art pieces that are replicas of famous artworks painted by local artists, have glaring Inca symbols in them. Many of the statues or paintings of Jesus, which normally have Jesus' face turned left, have Jesus' face turned right in defiance of the Catholic Church. So go see the Church, but I suggest you go witha guide who can explain all,the nuances.

Incredible. The whole church complex is huge. It is an incredible experience to visit it. You must have an English guide, otherwise you would miss most of what the whole setup is about. In many instances the Christian and Pagan symbols are intermingled and makes it quite interesting.

Wow is all you can say. All you can say about this place is wow. A must see for any one visiting Cusco. We had our Scenic tours guide take us through and explain it all, but it is amazing. Don't look at the outside and make an impression you MUST go inside
Ornate. These cathedrals leave me under awed because they are so gaudy. So many icons supposedly for Christian worship seem almost pagan.

Take a tour guide. This church is fascinating when you have a guide point out all the details in the artwork. The spanish basically gave the local people small versions of many of hte paintings that adorn the walls and told the locals to recreate them, larger, and put them on the walls. When the locals did this, they added in all sorts of small elements to hold on to their own beliefs and integrate their worship of the mountains, the sun, and the pachamama. Look for a snake in the virgin's dress, the darker skin of judas at the last supper, the mountain like shape of the virgin's dress, the "sun" halos around the saints heads, etc.

Buy the all inclusive attraction ticket. Buy the all inclusive attraction ticket and it will pay for itself within a few stops. This church has about 1000 pounds of gold and silver in its alter decorations. It also has a silver encrusted tractor that you have to look at hard to notice the driver seat. On some holiday they fire it up and drive it out of its church garage. As you enter the church it is on the right wall. It looks like a pile of silver at first glance. In fact it is a pile of silver, just motorized.

So Much Beauty!. What a beautiful cathedral this is, built from 1560-1650's, integrating some of the stones from the nearby Inca ruins of Saqsayhuaman (not sure that this notion sits well with me; irreparably undoing ancient history for the benefit of religion...) with its intricately designed, carved, painted, and gilded altar, as well as the altars of the two attached churches (Iglesia del Triunfo, the Church of the Triumph, and Iglesia de la Familia Sagrada, the Church of the Sacred Family), as well as a more rustic, hand-crafted tableau of a rural scene, an antique mapping and illustration of Cusco, a Last Supper painting that includes NOT the Paschal Lamb, but an Andean chinchilla (kind of like a guinea pig) and gorgeous, wooden arch-braced roofing above. Entrance before 10AM is free for those seeking prayer and alone time (with its soaring roof and open spaces, and lots and lots of tourists crowding their way through, it can get very noisy here!). Ignore the noise and people, enjoy the religiosity and design.

Overpriced and rushed. The feel of being taken on a tour through the cathedral was one that they were trying to see how much money they could grab and how quickly they could rush another group through. It was overpriced and noisy inside due to the large number of concomitant tours being conducted. Give it a miss unless this particular cathedral holds important significance to you.

Beautiful Church. This is one of the must see in Cusco.The Basilica is right in the middle of the city (Plaza de Armas) and has a rich history.There have audio tours in different languages. Careful with all the people trying to sale stuff to the tourist just at the entrance. No pictures allow (inside), but you can but a video if you like...At night the Plaza de Armas is light up and it makes really good pictures with the church on the background.

Beautiful complex, free audiotour. This complex is stunning to see, and offers student discounts for entrance. Definitely worth a visit, especially given the Cathedral's history and grandeur. Plus, the entrance fee covers a free audio tour that is very well done.

The best among all churches in Cusco. Located in Plaza de Armas, this jewelry is also known as The Basilica of the Assumption of the Virgin. Its mixture of renaissance, baroque and gothic architectures makes it one of a kind and a must see for all visitors.
