Best time to appreciated was during the celebration of New Year´s Eve as all visitors and locals gather together to sign the countdown to celebrate the New year, full of happiness, people from all over the world and 2 hours of amazing fireworks!

AMAZING PIECE ARCHITECTURE. I didn't make it inside but the outside alone makes it the most attractive piece of architecture in Cusco. It sets the tone for Centro Historic area of the city. There are services on Sunday and people walking around selling hand made souvenirs for tourist. It is a must visit if you are visiting Cusco. It is walking distance from most hotels in downtown Cusco but a taxi ride is only $1 when traveling around the centro part of Cusco. Happy Travels!!!

spectacular art and architecture. I would recommend visiting this site on your own time... While the city tour brought us inside, and gave us some information... there was so much that we had to pass by to keep on our schedule. If you are truly interested in art and architecture, enter solo... if you just want a quick viewing and a few pics... then the city tour is the way to go!

See their version of the Last Supper...... A Cusquenian artist painted the last supper - and the face of Judas is the face of Pizarro (who is the Spaniard that killed the last Incan Chief) Little local touch.The church is right on the Plaza- great area.

amazing mix of inca believes and christianity. This church is definitely worth seeing with a guide. Otherwise you will miss many interesting details. Inside the cathedral are some examples of the Cusqueña school of painting, including a painting of Marcos Zapata of the Last Supper - check carefully - you will see the local specialty, cuy (guinea pig), as the main dish. The painting also depicts bottles of chicha (a brew derived from fermented maize) on the table.Look for the statue black Jesus with the inca skirt...And for the painting of the earthquake - you will see the procession of the priests and at the bottom the women kissing pacha mama ( mother Earth)...Wish we had more time to spend there

25 soles to visit a church. Disappointed. rude lady at reception. This church is making a fortune on tourists.we paid our 25 soles each and were left to tour ourselves. The church is ornate, but if you are familiar with European churches I wouldnt bother visiting. You can visit for free during church services (but no shorts allowed). We were ripped off for our money, and got no service or help.
even if you are tired of churches.... This one is very large and grand with incredible detailing inside. Worth a visit; even our kids agreed.
Beautiful Cathedral but not worth the entrance fee. A beautiful cathedral, lots of paintings, great carvings in the choir of 93 (or 91??) different saints. but not worth the 25 sole entrance fee.

Look for The Last Supper!. What a beautiful sanctuary. Make sure you find the painting in the right front corner. We enjoyed a rendition of "go Tell It on the Mountain" and "Come all Ye Faithful" in Latin.

A BIG and interesting Cathedral. This is a massive building and well worth the visit. It is very ornate in some of the internal chapels but you cannot take photos inside!One chapel has over 6 tonnes of silver involved and the others show similar extravaganzas of detailed finery.On a scale with many of the large European Cathedrals and just as ornate inside.Think how many could have been helped if that massive wealth had been applied to the overall community!Definitely worth a visit while you are in Cuzco Peru.

Christmas Eve in the Cathedral. We visited the Cusco Cathedral on Christmas Eve. What a beautiful church and what a wonderful experience There were a group of local parishioners in a procession from side altar to side altar, singing traditional Christmas hymns and accompanied by a few people playing simple musical instruments. The Silver Altar is magnificent while the large painting of the Last Supper by Marcos Zapata adds real insights to the Peruvian culture.
Do not miss. This is just magnificent Very ornate with magnificent altars painting statues If you only go into one building in Cuzco this should be it

Do not miss this one!. If you will enter one church, make it this one. Outstanding Catedral, comparable to those in Mexico and Sevilla.It is rich in history, paintings, treasure, and architecture.Do buy the Archbishop Cusco ticket (30 soles, five churches including the Cathedral). I cost 25 just to enter the Cathedral, the others are very interesting as well.They have free audio guides in several languages. Very useful.

Colonial glory. Of all the magnificent religious buildings in Cuzco, one of the finest. However if you want to attend a Mass service, you might be better off elsewhere (e.g. La Merced) because it gets very crowded.

Very shiny. Having read the reviews and seen many a cathedral all over the world, we had high expectations. I will say that it is very shiny on the inside, with lots of gold and silver and creepy religious icons. If your are into those kinda of things don't miss it.If you have seen as much Jesus art as us and aren't religious, you may want to skip it. Not a fan of Baroque and ornate decorations, my favorite part was the lovely and simple ceiling. At 25 soles this was expensive.
Beautiful. What an amazing Cathedral, I was amazed by how the statues are created. You can fell a since of history while visiting the site.

Nice but quick visit. You can't take pictures here so the tour goes quickly. It is a beautiful cathedral and worth a quick tour. They do not have candles to light as you find in most cathedrals. The art work is so lovely that you could spend a bit more time looking at it. It is helpful to have a guide.

we loved it. but we're into cathedrals and history, we went to them all. normal folks might suffice with just one or two. majestic, and if you do your reading, it brings alive a period of spanish colonialization that was surreal for its brutality.
Beautiful. We loved the giant paintings and learning about the Inka history and the introduction of the church.
Gold gold gold . You can see all the inca gold melted and used in this place :) . Interesting history ; amazing art integrated with inca culture ... no photos allowed inside ...

Top attraction in Cusco. This cathedral is a grand building. Built in 1550 on the site of an Inca Palace it is grandiose. It is one of the most impressive cathedral I have seen. With high ceilings, baroque carvings, gigantesc oil paintings, gold and silver altars, it is a star attraction in this city. Interesting to see the mix of Christian and non-Christian influence.

Historical Highlight. The cathedral is beautiful & stunning. In certain parts one is able to discern what wonderful woodworkers they were, before they were forced to learn to work with stone, which is also beautiful. The use of mirrors to reflect light is clever & elegant,

Over the Top. The interior of this Cathedral is incredible. The workmanship and amount of gold create a brain overload. By the time you have finished you are struck with the excess the Spaniards put into their churches and realize just how much they took from the Incas.

Beautiful Cathedral. Unfortunately the cathedral is not included on the tourist ticket but it was still interesting to check out. I think entry was about 25 soles. It is quite a grand and expansive church with all the intricacies you would expect from such a place. It was interesting to see the differences in a grand South American from what you would see of something similar in Italy, France or Spain. I would recommend checking it out if you have a day or two in Cusco.

Georgous! A must see. It was my favorite visit in Cusco. I was very impressed by the art at the Cathedral and I'm glad we stopped and took the time to take the tour. Stunning! For 25-30 soles (can't remember!) you get a self-guided audio tour to the three churches/chapels and takes about 45 minutes.

Glory to God. I have seen many churches in Italy and France, but interms of gold and silver, this one has them all beat hands down. Sad to think that it was built upon the backs of miners who had shorten lives because of same.

Go there at 8am. ... and you won't pay 25 Soles for the entrance, because the mass is taking place.Watch out for the cuy at the Last Supper painting ;)Only con: You are not allowed to take any picture, even without flash
so decorative. so much gold and silver everywhere.....for such a small little town for tourism...the plaza outside is great for chilling.....

Awesome. Awesome is an overworked word but it fits for this gold-ladened basilica and 13 chapels. We've seen churches around the world and were tempted to give it a pass. That would have been a major mistake. Its worth a couple of hours

Beautiful. We were very impressed from the moment we walked into the cathedral. We had a guide to give us the background and the significance of what we were observing. It is so much more meaningful if you have a guide to explain the history and be able to help you understand the time period and background.

Nice but expensive. This was the first time we have experienced such a high cost to enter a cathedral. Cuzco was a neat city with lots of sites around it and a great launch point for Manchu pichu. as for the cathedral it was ok nothing special when compared to Europe but if your there and enjoy cathedrals then by all means check it out.

Worth the visit. What a spectacular site. So much gold !!
Make sure to have a guide who can explain it all to you when you visit.

Impressive church. These inmemse structure encompass the history of the city since the Spanish conquistadores came to the area. Once again an impresive work of architecture and engineering. The area were the chorus is located is a work of art. The wood work is at par whit many of the churches of Europe , Our guy was able to relay the historical, social, political and religious importance of this church.

Wow. This certainly has the wow factor. Whatever you might think of the church as a an organisation one has to admire the sheer magnificence of the interior here. Our guide was understandably quite scathing about the pillaging of Inca buildings and gold which made this building possible and how the church continues to own large parts of Cuzco and receives large rents as a result. There is a no photograph rule which I believe is all about the church selling more guide books than about reverence. Nevertheless an interior to be seen and should not be missed.
Cathedral. The Cathedral is a historic monument in the center of Cusco. Its definitely a place to stop while in Cusco. It has a lot of interesting painting and etc.

No photography - how dissapointing. This is a truly amazing cathedral filled with masterpieces of religious art and spectacular architecture. The Cathedrals and Churches in Cuzco are obsessive about people not taking photographs of the interior. I have no idea why this is the case. Most Cathedrals around the world which are proud of their art allow photography - especially if they charge for entry. Cusco thinks differently. I wanted to take high quality photos of the interior (without flash) and show them to my friends and family, promoting Cusco to the world and bringing more tourist dollars to Peru. However, whoever made the not very well thought through decision to actively prevent photography is damaging Peruvian tourism. I did not want to pay for the few poor quality postcards of the interior (badly printed) and I would happily pay more money ($$$) to actually be able to photograph the interior with my own camera.
Spectacular. These cathedrals rival those in Europe. Much larger but also much more ornate. You can see the wealth and Spanish influence. Interestingly grand.

Make sure you get the audio tour. If you are not part of a group or don't possess a guide book ask for (because it is not obvious that one is available) the audio tour which is included in the admission price which will give you a far better idea of what you are looking at.The interior is very grand and very interesting. The explanations of some of the paintings were also very good.
This is amazing. The outside is nothing great...but once you are in. This is the most beautiful church I ever saw (and has a European a saw a couple of them). Overwelming.
A superb cathedral with many riches. There are a wealth of interesting pieces of religious art in this beautiful cathedral, and it truly does merit a visit. Not to be missed.

Unbelivably massive building. Best value entrance fee is to buy a combined ticket for two other historical sites, Sacsayhuaman and Qorikancha as well as the Catedral del Cuzco. Enjoyed the tour guide's talk. So interesting with fascinating details of it's history and development from the original Catholic concept to the adaption to the local traditions, such as the painting of the Last Supper with the local delicacies on the table. Lots of walking but opportunity to sit in the pews. No cameras allowed but post cards available at exit. I don't like visiting churches but this one changed my mindset.

Great surprise. I went into this church assuming it would be just another pretty but uninteresting place (seen alot of churches so they start to blend together). I really loved this one - it was different than all the ones I'd seen before with so many interesting altars and paintings and carvings to look at. Worth the (not expensive) price of admission.

Full of gold and silver altars !. Huge cathedral on Plaza de Armas, it was badly damaged by an earthquake in 1650. Full of altars adorned in either gold leaf or silver. The Spanish certainly like to plunder the local gold and silver ! It costs 25 soles to get in, or you can by the combined churches ticket for 30 soles, which is better value.

Worth a visit. There is a lot of gold and silver and some interesting works of art. Worth seeing with a guide. Check out the altars, the food on the table in the last supper painting, and the Christ on the crucifix turned dark from candle smoke

Cathedrals are always worth visiting. In the absence of any evidence I can see to the contrary, I'm not a believer in the afterlife but I always like to visit any cathedral and this is no exception. The decor is something to see and there are some very special paintings. The atmosphere inside cathedrals is special, particularly when there is some sort of service in progress and this is often the case.

Well worth a visit. The cathedral is well worth a visit.I have never seen an altar like this before,it is about 2-3 storeys tall and completely made of silver !The choir stalls are interesting and a mix of traditional church and pre conquest carvings.There is no photography allowed inside.

An hour or so well spent. A very special spot consisting of 3 "churches" - a mix of pre-Colonial and Colonial architecture and culture. Mucho art, carvings, art, and silver. You need a guide or guidebook. No photography allowed. Entrance fee was about $13/head.Many hidden aspects in the artwork by Peruvian artists although commissioned by the conquering Spaniards.There is also the famous Last Supper painting showing a table of peruvian food including guinea pig as the main course, local fruits, and Judas with the face of Pizarro. Much to see - a bit overwhelming....
Bombastic Building. This Catedral is very bombastic, lavishly decorated. A bit too much. You can not take it all in, it is just too much!

You can only travel to see this Cathedral. I recommend a visit of this Cathedral. There is nothing else all around the world like it. It is a combination of the traditions and the art which came from Spain in a best ever way. It was many times in fire and ruins but survived to tell us a history.It is free for visit after 6 p.m.If you only visit this Cathedral in Cusco, your trip will be fully justified and useful.

Something you would see in Europe!. This is a beautiful cathedral and, at times, I forgot I was in South America. the paintings, decoration, architecture, and layout all are reminiscent of European Cathedrals
Very nice. This should be on your must see list.. No cameras. . I think 10 dollars to get in unless you go for mass which is daily. .Find a guide to explain all the hidden incan easter eggs

Very Pretty. This cathedral is beautiful, and definitely worth the visit. A free audio guide is provided upon entry, but ours had several kinks and did not work properly, so there were certain bits we would have liked more information for but could not get.

very impressive. I have visited many churches and cathedrals in the past, including St Paul in London and the cathedral of Seville. The cathedral of Cusco is special, very special ! What a pity that they do not allow photos or videos to be taken inside. The building is quite simply outstanding in its structure, decoration and history. It drips gold and silver everywhere. I particularly like that it has integrated the peruvian culture and art in its decor in particular the representation of Christ as a peruvian as well as the virgin Mary, also the galery of archbishops showing the two latest one being peruvian as smiling all pervious ones non peruvian being so serious. To add to the local colour the painting of the last supper displays a table full of peruvian food including guinea pig , tropical fruits and Judas being given the face of Fransico Pissaro. A comment of our guide to justify how this was allowed to stand was "this is Peru!". The conquistadors just had to accept this. The blend of the two cultures works remarquably well.I loved it. The wood carving from the local artisans is quite simply outstanding.

Guided tour is a must do. The City Tour (Cathedral, Coricancha and four ruins outside of the city) can be skipped if you're planning to do the Sacred Valley tour. You'll see plenty of ruins in the Sacred Valley. However, a guided visit of both the Cathedral and Coricancha in Cusco are a must do. Despite the fact that I've seen enough cathedrals for two lifetimes after traveling through Europe, the Cusco Cathedral is really one of a kind. It's a weird mix of the European catholic culture with the culture of the native South Americans. For example, there is a large painting of the last supper that shows Jesus and the gang feasting on guinea pig. The face of Judas is Francisco Pizarro. Bottom line: even if you've seen a thousand a one cathedrals on your travels, this one is different and shouldn't be missed.

Take a tour. This is 3 cathedrals in one. A guide at the gate offered to take us around for 20 soles. We'll worth it. Highlights- paintings with Jesus and Mary with a large wad of coca leaves wadded in their cheeks. The last supper with the sacrificial lamb replaced with roasted Guinea pig (a Peruvian staple).

Massive. By now have to say that we were Cathedralled out but as our guide was so enthused it would have been churlish not to have followed her. The place is a combination of way over the top,incredible craftsmanship and terrible history,but if in the square it is worth a visit.

Visit to Cusco Cathedral June 2014. Beautiful cathedral especially at the carnival time we visited although I am always a little perturbed by the gold / silver/ jewels on display some of which could be used to help the poorer people of teh community. Nevertheless well worth a visit
Incredibly Beautiful!!. Do not miss this incredible wonder, said to be one of the six most beautiful cathedrals in the world.The paintings, the icons, the awesomeness are beyond description, SEE IT!!
Nice. A nice Catedral in the center of Cusco that is worth to visit due to interesting architecture and art.

Massive. This is a huge church with beautiful artwork, statues, etc. A free audio guide comes with the price of entry that does a nice job pointing out how the Catholic church worked to integrate itself and it's teachings into the existing Andean culture.

Waste of Incan foundations and plundered stones!. Although christian, we found this example of lavish splendour of statuary, structure and paintings way over the top. I believe the Founder of the catholic church would have found such opulence deeply offensive. We enjoyed the Incan foundations. No doubt, some people may find the gold and lavish fittings of some beauty.
full of Inca gold. An exceptional cathedral which is still in service with times set aside for tourists. It contains 10 separate chapels with lots of history and religious artefacts

SPANISH COLONIAL WITH SOME LOCAL TWISTS. Visited with large group with guide. Lots of gilding and silver on display which is not to my personal taste. Some nice local touches such as a painting depicting last supper with guinea pig on table. I was told that this is the menu of choice for Good Friday. All of disciples and Christ depicted as European and Judas as a native of Peru so not entirely sure what point the artist was trying to make. The Cathedral has been damaged on numerous occasions by earthquakes and rebuilt/repaired and weight of upper parts of building including the roof kept to minimum by extensive use of timber painted to look like stone. Quite clever but not entirely convincing. Worth a photogragh of the outside but only if taken from the main square which at least has some colour from shrubs and other plants.

Central Cathedral. It is right on Plaza de Armas and continues to serve as the center of activity for the city since the Spanish Conquest. Not all Incan culture was suppressed, can be seen in certain decorations incorporated into the Spanish design. Unless you are a scholar on cathedral design and decoration, you’re likely not notice without direction form your local guide.No photography is permitted inside.

Tour of the Cathedral. We took this tour on our own. This church is unbelievable. They tell you the story of the mirrors and why they are in the cathedral. We went down into the catacomb to see where some of the priests were Burried.

Poor value. We bought the 25 s pp tickets, and THEN learned that no photos were allowed, and they had run out of audio tours in English. Since few of the signs are in English, we didn't get much from the experience.

Enforced Christianity. This is a monument of enforced christianity over one civilization that they extinct. You are going to Cusco to see archeological sites from Inca and pre-Inka era, not to visit replicas of Spanish churches. If you are not of their flock and if you not going there to receive Holly Sacraments, you can skip this site with no regret.

Not the prettiest church, but worth the visit. If you can, go to one of the mass, there is 3 or 4 everyday. That way you can not only see the church in use (and what the price is saying, is nice if you are religious or just like anthropological observation experiences), but also can escape to pay the entrance. You don't need to stay for the entire preaching, just for some minutes. You can not walk or talk loud during the activities!
Pure art.. The peruvians learned extremely well how to create and craft the best frames covered with gold leaves that provided a unique pattern and real masterpieces.
Amazing. Its an amazing and huge cathedral. Impressive details with a lot of gold. It must have costed a lot to build. As stated before, be sure you have a certified guide.

This is a must see place. I have seen so many colonial cathedrals around the world but this is sitting in the top 3. Must see place, be aware you can't take pictures, make sure you hire a guide as it has a lot of history and details to be discovered.

Beautiful!. I have never seen so much gold leaf as I did in this cathedral! There are so many stations/alters to pray to different Saints. The murals are amazing as well. It is probably the only cathedral that you will see a guinea pig on the table on the mural of the last supper...

The duality of religion. Amazing building that goes on and on. Would not be appreciated without the wonderful story-telling of our guide. He focused not on the architecture but the culture and the duality that was brought about. Fascinating. A must-see WITH a qualified guide.
Don't miss this church!. The various altars were very ornate. You have to see the Last Supper painting with Cuy on the plate in the middle of the table!

A Basilica with Quechan masterpiece indeed!. The Gold and Silver Altars were very nicely done! The paintings done by Quechan workers were comparable to the works of famous European Painters. Too bad they cannot sign their names to be properly recognized. The wood carvings are delicately done. A true masterpiece!

What jewel. There are no words to describe the beauty that you find inside! I found myself without words just admiring the splendor of this beautiful and sacred placed! One thing that did bother me was the lack of respect of the tourist! A lot of history!!!

Incredible wealth is stored here!. I was amazed by the wealth of precious metals and representation of Saints that exist in this Church. It's so ironic when I consider the simple message that Jesus is supposed to have passed on. So much tragic history of Spanish oppression is on display here. It's compulsory viewing for anyone, I think.
Amazing Catholic Church. Had the historic guided tour by a local guy, which was amazing. Really impressive building. The tour only takes about 30 minutes and is well worth it.
Well Worth The Visit. Nice attraction and beautiful cathedral, well worth the visit if you're in Cuzco. Moderate crowd and surprisingly wasn't swarmed with too many tourists.
Golden Church. I hated that photos are not allowed inside this cathedral but the images are memorable - so much gold and silver - very worth a visit.

Beautiful Cathedral. I always go for a visit to the Cusco Cathedral, it is very special for me
I like to walk around in peace and look into the beautiful artwork
Now that the renovations are almost finished you can see it in all her splendor

Pretty amazing place. This place is big and flashy and typical of a Catholic Church. It is lovely to see! But if you are not a fan of religion or of how the Catholic Church took over the Incas and ruined their families, farms, and lives than you might not want to step into this building. It is overflowing with gold and silver and pomp and circumstance. It has a lot of history but most of it at the expense of the Inca people... Def. worth seeing.

A dominant sight at the main square. The Cathedral of Santo Domingo (Cuzco Cathedral) was a large religious complex at the center of Cuzco. However, it is better known for its collection of Colonial arts, and for its stores of Peruvian archeological artifacts and relics. It is now a World heritage site in Cuzco. Interesting to note that most of the tourists came to see the painting of the Last Supper where Jesus was to share a Guinea pig and a glass of Chicha with the Apostles. The Guinea pig was a delicacy in Peru. Don't miss the painting; very interesting.
Beautiful old building. A very beautiful old building located right in the historical center of Cusco. One of the biggest cathedrals in Peru and one of the oldest. Totally worth a visit.

Great cathedral. This is a beautiful, interesting site. Takes about 45 minutes to an hour. Helpful to have a guide. Ornate. Interesting to see the way in which the church adapted to native tradition and culture.
Shouldn't be missed. Beautiful inside. Having a guide to tell you all the little things was very nice. Ornate and certainly a piece of Cusco history.

No visit to Cusco should miss this. This gem of a place is full of history and it depicts the Spanish influence on the endemic peoples to convert then to Catholicism.The Mary Magdalene is depicted in a mountain shape to tie into the Peruvian idea of Mother Earth.The pictures and carvings clearly indicate an advanced understanding of the planets Then there are the massive elaborate silver structures designed to carry images of the saints through the streets at festival times . It takes 32 mento carry them.An interesting building all round

Cathedral at Plaza de Armas Cusco. Plaza de Armas is a wonderful place to visit is the Historic Square of Cusco, lots of restaurants, bars, café, Icre Cream Parlos el HADA (the best), fast food, very nice to visit and the most important thing if you like history, please visit the Cathedral, make you day!! is wonderful, beautiful, lots of history, 3 churches in one...I had the chance to visit the Cathedral in Corpus Christi, so I m sharing some of the pictures , so incredible and nice day I spent...I love it.
Nice on the outside.. the cathedral is nice on the outside. Right at the Plaza de Armas. Lots of people hang out on the cathedral steps.

No Indoor Pictures Allowed - Bummer. This Cathedral is a good place markers so you know where you are when you pass through Plaza De Armas. There are many steps to sit and rest or wait for the bus or taxis. Many locals are outside trying to sell you trinkets or take pictures with them while they are in they traditional Peruvian dress/hats. They charge to get in and no photos are allowed. Because of that, I can't give a good rating in that photos are what reminds us of the various places us tourist have been. (To Travel Is To Live)

Beautiful colonial cathedral is actually 3 churches in 1. My family and I visited the church as part of a half day Cusco city tour so it was nice to have a guide to point out some of the significant features. I love visiting churches and especially love how over the top many Spanish colonial cathedrals are in South America. This one is actually 3 churches in one with two churches attached on either side of the main basilica apparently due to a rivalry between the Dominicans and Jesuits. It is interesting to see how much of the artwork and carvings were done by native artisans who found subtle and not so subtle ways to include their culture and beliefs. The most notable example is the painting of the Last Supper that shows Jesus and his disciples enjoying cuy (guinea pig) as part of their last meal.

History On Top Of History. This beautiful Gothic Renaissance style building the Cathedral Basilica of the Assumption of the Virgin dominates the Plaza de Armas in central Cusco. And like most other cathedrals and basilicas in Peru it contains many large iconic paintings and probably one of the most beautiful altars. But of course the beauty only depends on your point of view since this building was erected on the site of the destroyed temple of Viracocha. Its construction took near 100 years and was completed in 1654.Still it is certainly worth a visit if you travel to Cusco.

Stunning art with interesting history. There are many pieces of religious art inside the cathedral, all heavily influenced by Peruvian culture. Ask for a free guided tour at the booth located inside the cathedral (Spanish and English available, departing when there's a sufficiently big group) as only the local guides can provide you with all the inside stories and history of the place! Very educational and a true eye-opener on Catholicism in Peru!

Breathtaking. While the Cathedral is simply amazing, it the history of it makes it lose some of its lustre. Knowing all that happened when the Spaniards conquered the natives does make me look at the building in a different light.

Wow - amazing religious images. So many pieces to this amazing cathedral. Lots of separate altars each with their own history. Haven't seen that much gold-leaf in one place and probably never will again!!!

An imposing building. You cannot avoid this when you visit the historic centre and spend time around the Plaza de Armas. It totally dominates the landscape, A beautiful building with a great sense of history.
Class !!!!. This is a very good cathedral and historical and a huge one . Worth a visit. The painting were very good and the church is still in service
Another must see in Cusco. We did this tour as part our trip around Cusco real nice place to visit would recommend it's very close to all the main attractions
wow. Incredible....take your time here and really check it out. The only bad thing about this was no pictures were allowed.....darn

Beautiful cathedral. Huge cathedral with 11 other chapels. 2nd largest catholic cathedral in South America?! Went with a tour, but wish id gone alone. Paid 25 sol for entry, then only spent 30 mins there. If you're going to pay that much, you need to stay longer to marvel at the amazing cathedral.

Perhaps the most impressive cathedral outside Rome. Do not miss this if you visit Cusco. It is beyond any cathedral outside of Rome that I've visited. The size, the detail and the paintings. Don't miss the Last Supper. The face closest to you is the painter. Apparently he wasn't an enthusiastic catholic. Look at his expression.

Another must see when in Cusco.. One of the beautiful sights while strolling around Plaza de Armas. A grand old cathedral with all the charm and mystery that you would imagine. The smell of incense. The stained glass. The history. If those walls could talk. Definitely worth your time to take a moment to meditate on its beauty and serenity, at least from the outside if not interested in a tour of the inside.
Wow. Very impressive cathedral. There were a lot of paintings and gold everywhere. Some interesting stories related to the paintings and statues. But no photography allowed.

A very impressive cathedral, with a lot of interesting facts and history.. There is a great deal to see and hear about in this cathedral, from a Peruvian version of the Last Supper (with guinea pig as the main course and Pizzaro as Judas), to a massive solid silver car (now motorized) that is taken out and driven around the main square once a year. Also has beautifully carved choir, catacombs, and more. Definitely a good place for a guide, or at the very least a detailed audio-tour.

Beautiful, but can't take picture. Churches in Peru seem to me like very holy places. The architectural and interior design are different from other countries I've ever seen. I love the way the carved Jesus and Holy virgin Marie, very beautiful. Unfortunately, pictures are not allowed.
Spanish Catholicism. An amazing cathedral with Spanish Catholicism juxtaposed on Incan shamanism. Amazing art and gilded figures - a must see is the Last Supper with guinea pig as the main course.

loved it Here. A great area to relax and pass some time in the sunshine while watching the world go by. Contains the cathedral and many colonial buildings, shops and restaurants, including McDonald's and KFC.There always seems to be something going, when we visited there was a big parade going on.

Cusco Cathedral. Our guide was very well informed of the history and the people who did the artistry. There were beautiful carvings and artwork, but you weren't able to take pictures. There was also a nice jewelry store across the plaza, Ilaria, which had beautiful, different Silver pieces, at reasonable prices. They have other shops in Peru at the major airports and large malls.

Beautiful, but sadly no photos allowed. It was great to see the little hidden gems of local culture that the Cusco Artists hid within the artwork and carvings etc. E.G. The cuy on the platter for the Last Supper painting, the condors carved into one of the alters, the Inca Christ etc... Sadly you are unable to tale photos as previous photos were used to make postcards that were then sold.
Amazing. Great opportunity to view the beautiful paintings. Who can resist the Last Supper where the Black Jesus and the Disciples are sharing guinea pig and traditional bread from South America!
Looks good.. Architecturally magnificent from the outside, dominating the Plaza de Armas, but expensive if you want to look inside.

Spot The Guinea-pig!. A beautiful baroque facade on this cathedral faces the main square.It is next to the Jesuit Church - built on the site of an Inca palace and completed in 1671.
A visit here is well worthwhile to admire all the Peruvian treasures. We were particularly amused at The Last Supper which consisted of a lone guinea-pig on a plate!

Altars of gold and silver, and an unusual painting of the last supper. The architecture of the cathedral is what you might expect of Spanish influence. However, it is difficult not to be impressed by the altars in the cathedral. One has over a tonne of gold, whilst another has over 2.5 tonnes of silver. The painting of the last supper is unusual. The meal on offer reflects the local Peruvian delicacy! I leave it to you to see what it is! In addition, you can see close up some of the statues used in religious processions that occur throughout the year. It is well worth a visit
Pretty building/lousy acoustics. The cathedral is a very pretty old building however along with that comes poor acoustics. Found it very difficult to hear our guide. No photos allowed inside.

History Lesson. With a guide (we used Valencia Travel Cusco), this was an informative glimpse into the ways in which Catholicism changed the destiny of the original people in and around Cusco. We happened to tour in June during Corpus Christi and the traveling Madonnas were amazing to see. Permanent wood carvings also were of interest. Without a guide, I may not have gotten much out of the visit.
Worth a visit. Beautiful Cathedral. Well worth a visit. We had a good tour guide who told us a lot about the history.

The Church has Interesting History. This is a beautiful church, located in the main plaza of Cusco, that displays aspects of both the Inca Culture and the Spanish influence of Catholicism. The contrast of the two cultures is evident in paintings, sculptures, and religious artifacts. It is a very impressive structure that would provide a great photo for your travel album. Our guide had stories and pointed out paintings and art work that were examples of the influence of both cultures. For this reason I would certainly use the services of a guide knowledgeable in the church's history. This should be a "must" stop on your Cusco itinerary.
A must visit historical site. This cathedral is magnificent and steeped with history. The elaborate items included in the annual holy procession were intriguing.

Last Supper Cuy. Due to time constraints, only spent about 45 minutes in the church. At the time of our visit all of the floats used in the Corpus Christi processions held during the week were contained within the church. Later in the week they were to be returned to their respective churches. An interesting detail of the Cathedral is the Last Supper painting by Marcos Zapata that contains a plate with cuy on it.

Stunning, Significant, and So Worth Your Time!. Visiting this church is a definite must while you are in Cusco. It's right in the main town square, so conveniently located. The architecture commands your attention, but its the paintings inside that give this church its character. Ask a local Peruvian to explain some of the paintings. I don't think I would have nearly enjoyed this visit had I not had a guide to give a glimpse into why certain things are portrayed the way they are.
Impressive! Gorgeous paintings. Beautiful, it is best if you have a guide so you can learn about the stories and facts! sculptures,I really like the painting of the Virgin at the entrance hall!

A Tale of Pride and Woe. The Cusco Cathedral is an example of a culture superseding another culture (Spanish over the Incan), but with the subtle and resilient story of native Incans grasping to retain a semblance of their own identity and beliefs amidst the conquering (and often destroying) foreigners. Have a native Peruvian - and Incan descendant - help explain how the artwork and designs throughout the cathedral that were "commissioned" by the Spanish conquerers contain countless hidden (and sometimes courageously blatant) images of Incan religious and cultural symbols amidst the Christian/Catholic representations. The collections of skulls and bones of ancestors in the subterranean vaults are haunting, and bear witness to a bygone era of ancestral worship.

Fascinating history about beautiful cathedral. Oh my, what a tumultuous history for such a beautiful site. Amazing how the Spanish had the gorgeous Inca city of Cusco torn down and then reconstructed in European style by the Inca themselves. Using the gold from the Inca cities and temples to create the Catholic altars. Though the Catholic religion prevails now throughout Peru, it does make one question at what cost to another culture and people! Definitely a site in Cusco worth visiting and pondering.
Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit but like so many sites....make sure you have a local guide to explain all the interesting facts and features.

Magnificent!!!. I was in cathedrals and churches of Italy and Europe, but this cathedral is incredible, for its art, incredible painting and sculptures with a lot of funny stories about all paintings and sculptures

Amazing, beautifull, historical. It is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever visited. If you like to pray, there are saints for everyone =). The organ pipe sounds great, I hope you can hear it in any mass.

impressive!. There is so much to see! So many small chapels and so much detail in the adornments. Go down in the crypts to see where the Bishops were buried and the last ´Inca´ and his relatives. You could spend 2 hours there!
Beautiful very old church. Definitely visit this church when you are in Cusco. We walked around on our own and did not have a guide. There were plaques with main verbage of what you were looking at.

Stunning display of opulence. The Spanish took the gold from the Inkas. Then they build a cathedral. While absolutely stunning (much nicer than the one in Lima), still a reminder of the gross robbery committed by the Spaniards.

Good but not worth the excessive entry charge !. We enjoyed looking round this place , but the entry charge was excessive! Having been around many churches in Peru I did not think it was worth it when compared to the many other sites in the city.

Beautiful but sad. The architecture was beautiful and the colonial design and "décor" was impressive. It is sad, however, that so many of these sites are so slanted toward the Spanish and seem to ignore the atrocities inflicted on the native Quechua population during the colonial period. The forced conversion to Catholicism was so apparent. The submersion of the native Quechua beliefs was awful and is totally unrepresented in most of the cathedrals turned museums.

Nothing special. Not that interesting unless you've never seen a cathedral. The painting of the last supper with a guinea pig as the entree was funny and culturally interesting, but you can just google it and save on the entrance fee.

Get a local guide so you don't miss the details. The architecture is an amalgamation of styles, and lovely. Our favorite thing, though, was the paintings that showed how the sometimes-super-strict Catholic leadership allowed integration of their theology with the local beliefs. My favorite was a painting of the Last Supper, with guinea pig as the meat on the platter (also corn, potatoes and local veggies). We were here with a tour group and our guide added a lot to our understanding and enjoyment of this cathedral. It was a highlight of Cusco for us.

Very large cathedral. Amazing site one of the largest cathedrals visited so much to see would take hours to complete.Didn't like so many riches that the church has could be used to help local communities.
not that impressed. we went to more interesting convents and churches and it was quite expensive,although i understand its free in mornings

Different from most cathedrals. Interesting blend of traditional and local architectural styles. You should have a local guide. Was awkward that we were unable to take pictures but the security staff could watch the world cup at the front of the cathedral at full volume on a flat screen tv.

Glamorous colonial religious architecture. A guide is necessary to really appreciate the place. Beautiful cusquean paintings, master wood works... Interesting stories around the different spaces of the Cathedral

Beautiful church. A beautiful and historic place in the heart of Cusco, but a bit difficult to understand, since there are so many layers of construction, with the earthquakes demolishing everything, etc. It can be useful to have a guidebook to read along the visit to understand what you see, and grab the fun details about the place ; I prefer this option to hiring "real" guides, because their accent can be so difficult to understand... and you really don't make the most of your visit.
beautiful. this is a must to see huge and beautiful. guided tour is very helpful. a lot of history and amazing pictures and stories

costly and no photos. We asked for a refund when we found out you could not take photos inside. The entry was expensive if no photos were allowed and there were no signs to say no photos until you bought the ticket.

A Great Cathederal. We aren't really ones for cathedrals but this one was pretty good to look around. We had a great guide which makes all the difference. Lots of interesting sights and stories of how the post colonial Peruvians managed to keep the important parts of their religion.

Not what you would expect.... This is interesting as Cathedrals go. There is much gilt, many jewels, art of varying quality, unusual icons like the "Black Jesus" and activity. The site is 3 interconnected churches and that alone is fun to explore. A lot of money & energy has gone into restoration, and although you will take no photos, you will be blown away by the detail. We were thinking about the vast expense over time, amidst what you see in the surrounding city. There is much respect and honor for this site from Peruvians, and we recommend having a good guide to show you the curiosities, to impart a correct history, and to further inspire. We had 2 hours here, and that was about right timewise.

Worth a visit.. You have to pay to get in, I'm not sure how much as it was part of our tour. This is one of the best Cathedrals I have seen and I have seen many. The richness of the gold & silver around is unbelievable. 3 different sections to this Cathedral. Take note no Photos or video. They are very strict on this.

Black Jesus of Earthquakes. Cusco Cathedral sits wedged between the Church of the Holy Family and the Church of the Triumph. They all interconnect once you are inside. Entry is 25 Soles. The Cathedral dates from 1559 when the Spanish started to replace the Incan religions with Catholicism. Some stones come from Sacsayhuaman. No photos are allowed once inside, you can sneak the odd few if you are cafeful. Most revered item in the church is the Black Christ. He is paraded through town once a year and is said to protect the city from Earthquakes. He is locally known as Señor de los Temblores. It was impossible trying to take a photo, you will have to buy a postcard.

Started in 16th century, amazing. Amazing gold and silver covered altars, with statues and paintings. The "Black Jesus" resides here, and is believed to have calmed an earthquake, so is called Jesus of the Earthquake. Worth a visit, on a beautiful plaza.

Deceiving. I thought this was going to be another of the several cathedrals I've seen around the world, I was mistaken. It's deceivingly small from the outside. Inside, it's BIG. I was amazed at how advanced the people were at that time. Paintings and ornate structures were unexpected to me. A must see!
Not used to being expected to pay to visit a local cathedral.. What an opulent town cathedral, Quite spectacular. The view from the forecourt was very photogenic. Well worth the visit.

Marvelous combination of styles and cultures. Ticket is 25 soles. They take really seriously not taking photos inside, what is as it should be. Place is real mix of architectural styles and even building materials as it was rebuilt after the earth quakes. Of many altars, some are carved in wood, some made of gold and silver. Catholic visitors may enjoy beautiful rosaries and other religious accessories sold near to the exit of the Cathedral - and even participate in a Holy Mass - but you have to check hours.

It goes against the grain.. It is full of amazing treasures and wonders there are massive gold leaf on cedar altars, silver alters and works of art by native Peruvians. A minor niggle is you are not allowed to take photos - for security reasons! I don't believe it.The main niggle I have is the amount of wealth and money tied up in the church yet just a few yards from its doors there are people living in abject poverty.

SUPER INTERESTING. After been to st peter's basilica I thought I have seen the most beautiful cathedral, but I was wrong, this cathedral is more interesting than st peter's basilica due to it's faschinating history backfround. It is a beautiful mixture of andean and spanish colonial structure with lots of hidden messages were put in the design of this cathedral by local andean people. I found the native jesus statue the most interest and I have met with two guides, one is with spanish backgronud and one is local quechuan, they gave me different explanation on how they about this cathedral and it is very interesting to see the influence of different culture and education on their understanding. Usually I fuond cathedrals boring but this cathedral is so interesting and survived 2 earthquakes, it's a must see, better get a guide, it will be so much more interesting.

Some Amazing Architecture. The day we were here there was a transit strike in Cuzco. What this meant for us was that central Cuzco was free of cars. The Cathedral is beautiful inside. Classic European architecture influenced by the culture that had been invaded. It was very interesting to see the local influences throughout the paintings and carvings. This is worth and hour of your time. Make sure you have a real or audio guide take you through.

Don't miss it. The cathedral is actually three churches in one, with art work everywhere. What was fascinating was how many of the paintings reflected the local culture e.g., madonnas in the shape of a mountain, and guinea pig for the last supper. Unfortunately no pictures are allowed.

Lovely Square. The main Cathedral is located in the main square, which is lovely. The Cathedral was less than a 10 minute walk from our hotel. We did the Cathedral as part of a tour, and it was well worth it as the guide did show us certain things we would not have know doing it ourselves.

Don't miss, over the top interior. Over the top art and gold altars go on and on. It reminds you how much power the church had back in the Spanish conquistador days. Glad we saw it with a guide. Photos are not allowed, and postcards cannot capture the grandeur of the interior.

Cool cathedral. I normally dont like cathedrals or churches but this one is probably the best one I have ever been too. The only annoying thing is that you cannot take any pictures but other tan that, with the student price, it is cheap and amazing to see.

Very Interesting. We had a great tour of this cathedral - and the most interesting part of it is a painting that we saw at the end of the tour - be sure to look for it - it's of The Last Supper... and they are eating guinea pig! The fellow that is in Judas' place is actually Pisarro! And he is as creepy as they come. His eyes follow you around..

Home of the Painting of the Last Supper, with Jesus & Co. enjoying... A Guinea Pig and Chicha ( corn beer ). One can't help but walk by the Cathedral without stopping to take pictures and appreciate the architecture. Dominating the Plaza, the presence of the Cathedral demands your attention. If you only choose to visit one Catholic church while in Cusco, this is the one you should do.A most interesting painting graces the rear hall of this building, which shows Jesus and the disciples classic scene of the Last Supper. However, as the centerpiece meal, instead of lamb, you will see roast guinea pig ( technically, I believe Viscachas ), and instead of wine there is chicha, the local corn beer housed in Incan chicha cups.
Very bling. Interesting but really just lots of tortured Jesus images and lot of gold bling. It's cheap to get in and if you get guide he explains everything.

Beautiful and Unique. We enjoyed walking around the cathedral. Be sure to watch for the last supper painting with the guinea pig and the painting from the 1650 earthquake. We are Catholic and followed our guidebook, so we did not feel that we needed a guide. But there are a lot of little details and interesting touches, so a guide would be helpful if you are not familiar with the catholic faith or if you want more information.

Maybe my favorite cathedral in the world. This astoundingly beautiful Spanish Colonial cathedral houses about 400 paintings from the Cusco art school, and holds impressive (and almost overwhelming) works in gold, silver and precious stones. As many of us have, I have seen so many amazing churches and cathedrals around the globe and have almost become inured to their beauty. The Cusco Cathedral snapped me out of it. I walked around in almost a daze of awe. Highly recommend.

interesting church. My husband and I didn't mind the 25 soles each entrance fee, but we were very disappointed that we couldn't take pictures. I guess they want you to buy the 50 soles book at the tiny book cart. they only had about six different post cards for sale. But the book didn't include pictures of what we thought were the most interesting sites such as the women on the choir stall arms with stomachs that looked like potatoes. Also we found the chapel with the silver bier and the silver bird piercing his heart with his own beak fascinating--especially since it appeared that there was a chair and a steering wheel in the display which could turn the objects into a float. There was much gold and silver, and of course the famous last supper with guinea pig. We enjoyed seeing the church, but again, were very disappointed that we could neither take pictures nor find pictures of what we wanted to remember.

Great example of colonial arquitecture and art. Interesting and a must when visiting Cusco. However, expensive entrance and forbidden pictures or film even without flash appears absurd and not inderstandable in these times

Not to be missed.. It's a huge structure with impressive interior decorations Keep at least an hour if you want to see it properly.
Remember photography is not allowed.
Beautiful Cathedral. Gorgeous interior, can't take pictures, but you can buy them at the end of the tour. Very big inside. Lots of pictures and many altars to various saints.

Stunning but sad and a little gory. Cusco's cathedral looks reasonably impressive from the outside but the inside is truly stunning. It is a vast building packed full of enormous religious works of art, carved altarpieces, and much silver plate and gold leaf paint. The main altar itself consists of over 1200kg of silver - all stolen from the Incas, no doubt, as was the gold in the gold leaf. The sheer scale of this place hammers home the cultural loss arising from all those Inca artefacts melted down for their precious metals. One of the most famous religious paintings in Peru is housed here (although there are versions elsewhere, including in Lima and the village of Chinchero), a rendering of the last supper with a fascinating Quechua spin on it. Jesus and his disciples sit at a table, the centrepiece of which is a roast cuy (guinea pig; despite what the sign claims, it's not a viscacha, definitely a cuy) surrounded by Andean vegetables and bottles of chicha morada. Be aware that those with more delicate sensibilities may find the Andean version of Catholicism to be rather gruesome. There's a lot (really, a lot) more blood in the paintings and iconography than many will be used to. With an entrance fee of S/25 (about £6) this is one of the more expensive tourist attractions in Cusco but well worth it. Note that as with most religious sites in the highlands, no photography is allowed (with or without flash).
Deep and rich in history. Incredible artwork and history. So much to take in and process. Recommend a guide to truly gain perspective. Last supper with Cuy as the main course.
Golden. The catholic church sure do have some elaborate alters in their South American cities, and this was no exception. The artwork was fantastic as well.
Beautiful. You must to go in there. Some people think that it`s good to see just outside but inside you have all the place history. Take your time to see the cathedral. It`s worth it.

Well worth a visit. 25 soles each. Not included in the Cusco tourist card. No photos inside.After that news, the cathedral is a very interesting place to visit. Lots to see. Statues, paintings and the choir stalls. For me, the most interesting painting was the Last Supper and the crucifix, El Senor de los Temblores (Lord of the Earthquakes).One disappointment perhaps was the lack of a cathedral shop to purchase postcards of the more famous items - unless, of course, I didn't see it

Three churches in one. It was very amazing to have three churches in one building. Each was so different than the previous. Unfortunately you cannot take pictures inside. The "black jesus" and "guinea Pig" last summer and must-sees.

See the Black Christ. Yes, Zapata's guinea pig is here but my draw was the Black Christ. I was here for Easter morning mass and I can tell you that there was a throng of locals fixated on this wondrous sacred attraction. Be sure to see all crucifixes as they are quite amazing.

Take the Tour!. I wanted to visit the cathedral to see the "Guinea pig" version of the Last Supper. I didn't expect such an excellent tour and explanation of the artwork throughout the cathedral. It was fascinating to learn the many ways that the artists modified traditional works to incorporate local flora, fauna and traditions. Take the tour that's included with your ticket!
Watch your entry time. We entered within 30 min. of closing time and they start closing shop within 15 min. Lights were turned off and we were hurried thru. Really cool church...leave time.

Easter in Cusco. We were in the cathedral both for Palm Sunday and Easter Sunday. Both services were vibrant and the place was packed. standing room only. It wasn't the place or the architectural style of the building that appealed it was the people who made the place come alive.
So grand. We enjoyed the tour of this beautiful building and learning about it's history, we did this tour with headphones/speakers with a guide and this was fantastic, highly recommended.

Grand Cathedral! - Beware of Scam Tour Guides. Be very careful - you should ONLY be paying for the entrance ticket (10USD for adult, 5USD if you bring an ISIC card). "Guides" will try to scam you before you enter to lead you through the inside, but as we discovered, they actually have their own guides inside, leading tours every 10 - 15 minutes or when they have enough people. The negative ratings on this are mainly due to people NOT KNOWING this.No photos allowed inside. But it was a unique church with Peruvian twists. I have been to many churches in Europe, and I still thought this one was quite interesting and worth a visit.

Very interesting and beautiful. This is truly an interesting place to visit while in Cusco. Although I enjoyed the Coricancha slightly more this is still something you should probably not miss while in Cusco. This mixture of native Inca beliefs and christianity are quite interesting. Such as seeing the portrayal of Mary in a rigid pyramidal/triangular shape to symbolize mother earth/mountain is very interesting to see in person. We had a guide with us when we toured and found it to be very helpful and truly brought many of the things we were seeing to life. So much interesting artwork to see. I would recommend stopping through while you are in Cusco.

Amazing Cathedral. It was an amazing place - since there are actually three churches in the complex, it takes time to view all the art and church artifacts. only sorry we couldn't take photos - it is something to not miss in Cusco
spetacular inside. all the decoration (very rich) and the ambiance. The ensemble makes you very small and introspective

must visit in Cusco. interesting perspective on Inca influence on Christianity. outside is grand, you will not miss it. inside was cool too but it is just another cathedral. Spend more time outside in Cusco. Much more interesting stuff.

The Last Supper Painting with a Guinea Pig. The cathedral itself is interesting enough to merit a SHORT visit, but skip the guided tour unless you're a die-hard cathedral or religious art fan. One interesting thing to look for in the cathedral is the large painting of the Last Supper, where, in addition to bread and wine, there is a guinea pig being served up on a platter

Interesting in both history and culture. We visited in February 2014. We could only take photos externally and not internally. The Incas originally built their temple here, but when the Spanish conquistadors arrived, they took down the temple and built their Christian cathedral on this site.The cathedral has two altars, the original wooden one at the back and in front of that, an altar of solid-silver. The cedar choir has carved rows of saints, popes and bishops – all very detailed work. Check out their artwork of the Last Supper (it features a meal of local chinchilla - some say guinea pig - served with an Inca corn beverage).Also visit the "Black Christ” (a wooden crucifix that turned black from centuries of smoke and dust).Interesting cathedral and worth a visit.

Cathedrals in South America are very different from other parts of the world. The cathedrals in South America are much more ornate than what you will find in North America or Europe (at least, to any I have seen). And while some might not like the ornate display, I think it is fascinating!The colors are so much more vibrant and their statues are wearing textiles and other items made out of actual fabric. When you visit, you must look closely at the paintings as it is fascinating to see the way the artists weave in local culture and customs.

Worthy to see it once. It's actually a combination of 3 churchs.. big, full of bling-bling stuff and many old historical paintings. There are some reasons to have this as a "must" in Cusco:- It's big and looks great from outside- It was full of gold/silver once upon a time.- There is an interesting painting (The Last Supper with chinchilla as main meal)- They history of it in the Inca time and the Spanish time- It's very famous in CuscoIt costs 25 sols each if I remember correctly...For me, it's enough to visit it once in my life and no need to go back again and again.To go there mainly because it's so famous, so it feels not being in Cusco if not going there.

So good, we went back on our own. We went one day with a tour guide, who was very good and then went back the next day on our own. READ the caption under the painting of the last supper. The animal is NOT cuy! Everyone says and assumes that it is, but read the caption. The different Jesus figures rotate to the altar during the year - very interesting. You are not allowed to take photos. We would definitely go back as there is too much to absorb in one or two visits. We highly recommend that you hire a guide- there are plenty near the door. The building was modeled on the cathedral in Pueblo, MX but they ran out of money, so it is smaller. IT IS NOT SMALL. Have not been to Pueblo to compare. We were told that Good Friday in Peru is a day of feasting rejoicing - not like the rest of the world.

It isn't a guinea pig!. We aren't fans of such glittering flamboyance as is found in this very large cathedral but found the painting of The Last Supper interesting with a chinchilla (not a guinea pig) as the main dish. The chinchilla is a symbol of running water, very important to the Inca people.

An amazing cathedral. Unfortunately you cannot take pictures inside the cathedral. We saw several different altars. One covered in silver, one in gold, one carved out of cedar, and one with a Black Jesus. The craftsmanship of the Peruvian artisans under Spanish direction is incredible. There are frescoes and statues as well. This is a "must see" on a Cusco trip.
A phenomenal and interesting piece of history. This is definitely worth checking out while you are in Cusco (hard to miss really). A lot of history, and a lot of interesting stories about this place.

It is a master piece of culture. I am very impressed with all the paintings thereinNo dislike... The cultures, festivals and history and all , are all here.It is a melting pots of heritage, culture and way of life locals.Great place to visit.

Wow- impressive. We were in Cusco just briefly for an overnight on our way to Lima. We wandered to the Plaza De Armas for dinner and saw the cathedral and went inside. It was during Holy Week so the place was packed but it just added to the enjoyment- to see the church being used! There was music and a person reciting the rosary and it was decorated with flowers everywhere. The huge altar was spectacular. There were also many paintings. It's well worth stopping in and looking around.

Beautiful church. This is a beautiful church with many beautiful paintings. Probably the most famous painting is 1 of 3 paintings of the last supper with guinea pig being served. There is a fee to enter, but you can buy a pass that includes many of the religious sites in Cusco. No photos are allowed in the church - as in many of the churches in Peru.

Must see . If you have time to do only one thing within the town limits of Cusco, let it be this. They don't allow you to take photos inside but I guess that allows you to concentrate more on the awesomeness of all that it inside. The layout. The alters. The carvings. The gold. The silver. The paintings. The sculptures. All of it : totally amazing! My personal favourites are the depiction of the Last Supper (where the fruits were tropical and guinea pig were being on the table) and the story behind the black Jesus. I think it also made a difference that I had a really knowledgable guide which was able to explain to the group just how wonderful the place is. A real must-see!

An art Treasury. The Cusco Cathedral has three actual churches; St Francis, Cathedral and Holy Family. All are wonderfully finished in carved wood, and precious metals almost all done by local artisans of the time. This is not as grand as some European Cathedrals, but it rivals them nonetheless. Photos are prohibited within the building. The large Crucifix over the altar shows a black Jesus. This is because of oils used on the wood. It is quite beautiful! Once a year on the Monday before Easter the Crucifix is taken in a procession for about 6 hours around the old center of Cusco. I was fortunate to have been there for the event and got great photos.
Amazing. One of the most beautiful and outstanding cathedral.So much local history and local art inside...you must visit!!
Breathtaking. Amazing and imponent. Too bad they won´t let take pics inside. So rich and full of history! So breathtaking!

You have got to go inside. Its just brilliant! such an amazing place and the baroque facade is just beautiful, the inside there are many interesting things to see, the altar being the most impressive - the plaza de Armas its located on is interesting as well with a beautiful fountain where you can sit and watch people walk past the original building was built in 15th c
Interesting place. Usual church with lots of gold. Look for the float which comes out occasionally for festivals. Now with tyres and driven, not carrid. Amused me
Grandiose Spanish colonial splendor. You can't miss popping into here. The interior is reminiscent of most other Spanish colonial cathedrals but is worth a gander.

Nice European style church. The Spaniards left their mark with this church. You feel like you are in Spain. The art work is interesting, especially with the Peruvian influences on the catholic church.
Interesting. We did this as part of a city tour of Cusco It is helpful to have a guide to show you the highlights of the Cathedral. Very interesting and impressive.

Wake up!. Visiting the Cathedral is certainly worthwile, but one should not forget that it was built in Colonial times when the Spanish Conquistadores and the members of the Catolic Church that accompanied distroyed the Inca-Culture and thoroughly looted Peru. Funily the local artists creating the Cathedral made fun of their Spanish masters, e.g. the Spanish Code of Arms in one of the doorways does show "Condors" instead of the "Habsburgian Eagles". Finally one should not forget that during "the Colonial Times" the Inka-people dwindled from ca. 8 million people to ca. 2 million.

Definitely a worthwhile visit. Wow - this is amazing. I have seen a number of churches / cathedrals and this is definitely one of the best. The history!! - try to get a guide to go through with, it gives you a better understanding for sure.
Interesting tour. In a country like Peru with a mind-numbing variety of religious architecture, this cathedral still stands out for its Last Supper with a guinea pig on a platter.

wordless. Although it is not cheap, the cathedral is a must to visit, great paintings, the architecture, the main front made of gold... there is an access to the other two churches which form part of the cathedral. Awesome for people loving art.

Amazing. Cusco Cathedral is an amazing place. It´s possible to learn much about Peruvian history visiting there. It´s a pitty that pictures are not allowed. But it shows how they worry about preservation. I suggest a guided tour.

Cultural all the way. Visited with my trip group accompanied by a guide that was absolutely aware of every little story behind each altar and saint, I guess that is the main reason the tour was great! The church is really interesting from the outside and inside you can see its magnitude, the altars with amazing craft work from the artisans of the past (wood, metals, precious elements) and overall was a nice tour, it's worthy it!
impressive. Add it to the great cathedrals of the world. Do have a guide to really explain the ramifications re: Cusco and Catholicism.

One of the best cathedral in the world. The cathedral is really big divided by many sections. Not very touristy so you can pray inside the church and even attend mass daily. The ceilings are high and walls are adorned by old paintings. Lots of statues of Christ, saints etc. Altar was made of two tons of silver. its just sad that you cannot take pictures inside the church

This is good but not great. The cathedral is good to see, however in my opinion it looks better from the outside than inside. However, there are some interesting things to see inside, such as the wooden altar behind the main silver altar. Also some of the artworks have very interesting stories.
Interesting. It is quite a big Cathedral in 3 sections. It is pretty & interesting. However you do need to see it with a guide. No Pictures or Video allowed at all

Las Misas.... For early risers, recommend you quietly and respectfully observe or take part in one of the early morning Mon-Thurs local services (las misas) which are, I believe, at 0630 and 0800....you will see an authentic catholic service with praying, hymns, the Lord's Prayer in Spanish and "peace be with you" embraces with an obviously devout congregation that includes young schoolgirls in catholic uniforms before school to older Peruvians in formal dress....a very moving ceremony to watch regardless of your faith I'd say. The signs will say no tourists and there are certainly no pictures allowed inside, however if you are dressed appropriately and quietly walk through and observe the service you will not be asked to leave by any of the attendants stationed throughout this large cathedral....there were perhaps 6-8 obvious non-Peruvians who enjoyed the beauty of Las Misas and thus avoided the large tourist throngs and entry fees that commence at about 0900 hours.
Gorgeous church. Definitely a must see. I attended daily mass several times there, and found it to be such a peaceful way to start the day.

Beautiful Cathedral. We visited for mass on a Wednesday morning thinking it might be better than trying to go when the tourists hit. We had read several reviews that said it is more beautiful during mass anyway. I would disagree. While I don't regret going for mass, we actually came back later in the day and more of the church was open and the church was more lit up. You can also go into the 2 other churches connected to the cathedral during tourist hours. There is a fee to enter during tourist hours. I was under the impression that you could buy a "religious ticket" and see several churches for one fee, which is sort of true...the problem is that each ticket offers one local church and a couple on the outskirts of town so there is not way to pay one fee and do a walking tour of the churches that are accessible by foot in town. That was disappointing since we wanted to see several of the churches but didn't want to spend $50-$100 doing it.

Impressive!. It has a magnificent history and architecture. You can have a guided visit where you can get extra information about the cathedral. The work in wood left me speechless. No photos admitted though.

Impressive from the Outside. This cathedral is on the north side of Plaza de Armas and overlooks the plaza. It is impressive from the outside, both what you see from its front, but also from its back side. Be sure to walk around it.

Great Place, very nice, proves the Church has too much wealth. Very impressive, i usually do not like visiting churches. This one should be an exception. Very nice inside. Difficult to imagine the Chuch has so much wealth while people are begging outside
A Very Nice Large Church. This was a pleasant stop to see the large well designed and finished church. It could have been in any place in Europe.

Golden church. This cathedral is actually three churches and merits more time than we had on our organised tour. It is lavishly decorated with paintings and gilded altar pieces. The amount of gold melted down from the inca palaces and used in the new churches was considerable (several tons). It was interesting to hear that most of the artisans were of mixed blood and introduced their own mix of catholic and older traditions. One example is the way the holy virgin is portrayed with a wide dress (wider at the feet) to liken a mountain. Mountains were holy to the incas, especially volcanoes. As so often photography (with or without flash) is not allowed.

Amazing Cathedral. We did a tour of the cathedral (which is actually three churches next to each other) and it was a fascinating look at the Catholic impact on the Incan people and how they took some aspects of Incan religion and incorporated this into their icons in the church. Very interesting tour.

The most unsual and beatiful colonial building!!!!!!!!. In the old Inca square and on top of inca foundations the Spaniards built a cathedral which is full of colonial pieces of art. The most unusual canvass there is Andean version of the "last supper" where you will find a roasted guinea pig, another highlight is the black Jesus known as "El señor de los temblores" (lord of the earthquakes), He is the patron saint of Cusco.the art is so impressive that you can spent hours, if You really want to know about colonial art in the Peruvian andes. If you have a private tour guide ask him/her about the syncretism (mixture of inca and catholic ideology showed in the art).If you don't have a private tour guide ask for one at the ticket office (a private tour guide is provided for free when you buy your entrance ticket, Dora Aramburu is the expert).

A quiet and magnificent place. If you're tired if walking go in and sit down. If you're a collector of churches, this one is just about as ornate as you can get: one and a half tons of silver leaf on the high altar. If you wonder how they wrestle the icons around on festival days, take a look at the little car which hauls the silver canopy. If you'd like to see what's under the gold and silver leaf, go round the back of the high altar and look at the original: in unpainted cedar. Something for everyone.

Beautiful.... Any and all of the Cathedrals in Cuzco are gorgeous. However, the main Cathedral is what takes the cake. Make sure to have a tour book or get the tour guide to help you. It is worth the money.

Built to impress. Size seems to be the most important aspect of this building. It takes up a whopping 4000 square meters, or to put it another way, a whole acre of city real estate, in a mammoth effort to impress the local Indians and covert them, and apparently it seems to have succeeded. At first it was not so impressive as some other cathedrals I’ve been to, until I realized the immensity of the place. It is so huge it would really take at least one day to see it all. In some ways it feels more like a museum than a church, with the constant throng of tourist groups proceeding through the building. There are many larger than life paintings lining the walls, and I can’t remember how many thousand kilos of gold and silver that was stolen from the Incas. Of particular interest is a large painting of Cusco depicting the 16th century earth-quake. Photography inside the cathedral is forbidden, and I managed only a couple of quick shots… see below.With thousands of tourists piling through the cathedral every day at 25 soles per head, its easy to understand why the emphasis is now on tourism as opposed to running the church service (service only till 10am daily before the tourists arrive). If you are interested in 16th century paintings it is well worth the entry price. However in my book the church at San Pedro de Andahuaylillas on the road to Puno, despite the relatively smaller size was far more impressive.

Wow and wow again.. We spent about an hour on our tour but could have spent three hours. The carving of the woodwork, gold leaf applique and artwork is comparitive to cathedrals in France or other European capitals. If you go to Cusco, do not miss the Cathedral. Unfortunately, you cannot take pictures.
interesting but too expensive.. Highly interesting, not least the oddest painting of Cusco During the earthquake of 1658 (?) but charging 50 bob seems pretty steep!
Astonishing building. Interesting building to visit. It will take you ate least one hour to discover the details of all you encounter inside. A tour guide is desired.

Small cathedral. By the standards of cathedrals in South America not really that impressive and a little shabby. We saw it as part of a tour, you can easily see everything in this church in about 10 minutes.

Look out for the Last Supper. Interesting church with history covering the Spanish and Inca religions showing in the pictures and statues. The above picture shows an interesting choice for the Last Supper

Wow! Just wow.... Actually three different churches all connected together over the ages, this wonderful Cathedral is so beautiful, and so different from its European contemporaries. Your entrance includes an English speaking guide, so take advantage. The smash-up of Catholic art and the beliefs of the indigenous is fascinating.
Beautiful. Beautiful church. Interesting history on the mantel of Jesus. Saw a family procession when the mantel was changing. Such riches in this church.
