Fabulous even if your not religious. Well worth a visit even it's only to see the painting of the last supper where the dish of the day is guinea pig.Full of wonderful paintings and artefacts. Take time to drink in the atmosphere.

Three in one. We went with a local guide who explained the history of the three churches within the cathedral. Some beautiful stone and woodwork that manages to mix the the local and Spanish cultures. Well worth a visit.

Worth a Visit. This is a grand cathedral with interesting history. We actually visited twice, the first a paid visit with a very interesting guide to enjoy the entire complex and the second a free visit for Sunday morning mass. The two experiences were very different and both wonderful.

A different perspective. We opted for a group tour and this was well worth it. We were all given "Whispers" so that we could here the guide even if we were out of voice range. The guide was an indigenous person and very knowledgeable about his own people but also the impact they had had on the cathedral. This cathedral has many clues as to how they impacted the growth of the church which for us was highlighted by the picture of the last supper where the main dish is a guinea pig, a delicacy in these parts. If visiting opt for a local guide who should give you a good insight of the building.

Truly special, worth seeing. Truly beautiful cathedral, in line with the cathedral in Puebla, Mexico. You understand why Peru and Mexico were the wealthiest of Spain's colonies when you see this. The rather high entry price gets you ihto two adjoining churches and the cathedral. Well worth it for the art and chapels. Odd that independent guides were walking around trying to start a conversation and get a job, made it a bit annoying. Otherwise, we enjoyed as a much better cathedral than many others we have seen. Odd that masses seem to be only at very early hours - I guess that is why this is more of a tourist site than a real cathedral. The Puebla and Mexico City cathedrals are mainly for religious ceremonies, and the tourism comes on the side (and without a fee for tourists.) I take away one star for that - high price to get in and not really a functioning church anymore.

Beautiful. If you love cathedrals, this is a great one. The entrance fee was a bit too much to go with our 4 children that suffer from "cathedral burn-out" so I took a tip and went alone in the morning when it is free to get in. (6:30-9:30am when they have morning Masses). The artwork was incredible, I esp loved to see the original Peruvian Last Supper. I wish I went with a guide though, and spent more time. You could easily spend an hour and more if you want prayer time. So many beautiful side alters!

Typical Example of Spanish Colonial Building. A must for all visitors to Cusco, a very interesting example of Spanish colonial religious buildings, what's truly amazing is the amount of artefacts inside, statues, carvings, gold, silver and outstanding alters.

Beautiful, best cathedral. I've seen some beautiful cathedrals in my life, but this one nears the top of the list. The intricate details throughout the cathedral took my breathe away more than once. I recommend going alone or with your group to spend as much time as you like there. I was with a tour group and it was too rushed for my taste.

Typical baroque church.. Gold and silver altar, impressive Last Supper with roasted guinea pig as the main dish, the local favorite. Watch the feet and hands and forgive the painters, they were local, learning the craft there.

Get a tour. I found it most interesting because of all the explanations from our tour guide who pointed out all the ways that the catholic religion was adapted to attract the indigenous people. Also the sheer volume of gold and silver used is awesome.

Huge Cathedral. Very nice Cathedral with a ton of old gold dating back to Spanish colonial times. The cathedral was visited by the Pope (I think in the 80's) and has some beautiful paintings and other decorations, however not photography at all. They will take your camera if you try to beware

Beautiful Cathedral. We asked for a private English speaking tour guide and they provided one for $20. The whole tour probably lasted for about 30 minutes. You could see the Cathedral on your own, but the guide had a lot of inside knowledge that we would have not know. It's definitely a must see in Cusco.
Stunning. The inside of this cathedral is way bigger than it looks from the outside. Go during a service, the sound is hauntingly beautiful.

Must see. This was the first stop of the tour that we booked. The church was amazing and full of history. This was the place where our tour guide pointed out that the paintings were not in proportion...like the body parts were not in proportion. So many things to see and admire...

Stunning Cathedral at Plaza de Armas!. The cathedral in Cusco is beautiful, full of gold and shiny as well as a good meeting point since its so huge you can't miss it. A little tip: Early in the morning it's even for free to enter! We did the tour and also got to see some of the more hidden rooms in the cathedral and I have to say that this was one of my favorite churches on my whole trip in Peru!

Huge and beautiful. We had a guide for this cathedral, but found her really unnecessary as there are signs everywhere in English and Spanish which explain what you are looking at. We went on a Sunday, a mistake as it was so crowded you could hardly see anything. We returned the next morning and sat through the end of mass and then explored the cathedral at our leisure and without the annoyance of a guide who was at best mediocre. The cathedral deserved this second visit with our time and attention!
Beautiful!!!. Beautiful!!! Attended a Sunday mass for a few minutes. No photography allowed. Let your eyes rest on every image in the cathedral. It is breathtaking!!

Best Religious Site in Cusco. If you are into the Catholic heritage of Cusco, this is the best site for you to visit. Any student of Cusco style painting and baroque architecture could spend half a day in this church. The baroque style here rivals Rome.

Not to be missed. I was there for sunday morning mass with the service by Archbishop and it was feast of Immaculate Conception. Later, in the afternoon, I went in as a paid tourist with guide to explain but cannot take photos. A beautiful Cathedral not to be missed. :)

WOW!. It's located in the main plaza in downtown Cusco. I think it is best to take a guided tour to learn about the history and art located inside. It's huge and ornate, but breath taking. I think it is a worth the time.
Beautiful spiritual place. On of the most beautiful cathedrals in the world, totally worth the visit. IF you have the time, try to stay for a daily mess, very emotional and elevating experience!

Insight into Cusco ' Catholicism'. We toured with a guide - a must. An interesting church providing insight into how cusco Catholicism is blended with old Inca traditions. It is actually 3 churches in one built upon an old Inca religious site. Do get one of the 'all inclusive' attraction tickets for s/. 128 since the charge here is around s/.25 & you could save money if visiting other attractions. The procetional (?) equipment is interesting. Definitely worth a visit while in Cusco.

Amazing interior. Since we were part of a group, I didn't realize until later that there was a S/25 charge to enter this cathedral. We were traveling with guides, which helped us understand the cathedral and its features much better. Interesting that the central alter - all silver - featured Mary, not Jesus. There were numerous very large side chapels with breathtakingly beautiful wood, gold, and silver. Also many huge and beautiful paintings, including one of the baby Jesus being circumcised and another of the last supper where guinea pig (cuy) was the main dish. Don't miss the egg-shaped black rock about 3 feet high which represents God to the Inca ("is God" according to our guide). On the morning we visited, there were flower petals and small stones that had been dropped on and near the rock by worshippers. It was being moved out of the church about 40 years ago during a remodeling but local opposition prevented that and it was kept in a back corner. The church is much larger than it first appears and is certainly worth a visit. It bothered me that we may have been interfering with worship, though we were trying to be quiet and no photos are permitted.

Place for prayer. We arrived at the Cathedral and were approched by a unknown person claiming that the ENTRANCE for the Cathedral was on the left side of the MAIN entrance.But later found out that the reason you are sent to a different door is to LABEL you as a TOURIST and CHARGE you ( yes i said " CHARGE YOU" s/ 25.00 PEN Nuevos Soles ) per person to ENTER the HOUSE OF GOD during the Xmas season.I guess ,you have a tourist trap here instead of having a place to spent with GOD , twice were approched by unknown persons claiming that IF you want to come IN, you MUST PAY or LEAVE the Area ; because they get really MAD and confront you so you won't inform the other tourist about the FEES the Cathedral is making just to come in.TOURIST TRAP...FEES OR NOT GO.HOUSE OF GOD should be respected NOT disrespected by CHARGING YOU TO ENTER.

Beautiful. Oh my with so many cathedrals to visit, you must run in here. I was lucky enough to be in Cusco for the night of the cross. So beautiful, with processions in the streets and lots of candel's lite.Nothing like the very old cathedrals.

Worth a visit. 3 churches in one building, the baroque facade, the imposing bell towers mark the highlight of the tour. It's expensive entry and no photos are allowed, but still worth the visit. The art work is quite fine with gold, silver etc. The sculptures and paintings are quite good.Would recommend to go with a guide to understand the history better.
3 for the price of 1 !. 3 churches in one , being built one close to another , on the very same Inca sacred ground .Amazingly beautiful , gold , paintings , vaults , arches ., etc...

Expensive to visit. While most places allow access to churches for free here it costs 25 soles to enter. If you wish to of to pray you can in the morning but they do not allow you into the main cathedral just to the side which is literally just pews for praying.

Not Just Another Cathedral. Not a religious bone in my body but get a guide and take in this magnificent cathedral. Lots of the usual images of a poor beaten and tortured Jesus but you will see the very first (I think) black crucified Jesus image. Get a guide so you know what you are looking at...
Beautiful and humbling.... This is a beautiful place...not long lines, but rather cold inside. The interior of the cathedral is stunning.

Amazing Church...but no pics allowed. I loved the church and the audio tour, but a relatively expensive fee to enter and no pics allowed...flash or no flash. You could attend early morning services on Sunday. But a truly fantastic site.

Imposing monument - to the victors go the spoils. As far as cathedrals go, this one is large, ornate, well appointed with gold, silver, and art work. As other reviewers point out, there are numerous "churches" within the naves and apses of the cathedral. Having learned a bit of history during my visit to Peru, I knew that this cathedral was built on top of a large, important Incan temple as part of the Spanish program to "civilize" the natives (they built churches on top of every Incan temple that they found to send the message that their god was more powerful than the Incan gods). That knowledge along with the fact that Spain (and the Catholic church) enslaved the native people and took their gold and silver to build this cathedral as well as many others put a damper on my enthusiasm for what would otherwise be an impressive monument. I did enjoy the Cusco school of art work, done by natives trained to imitate European religious art - the most famous of which is the last supper, featuring a Peruvian delicacy, guinea hen. It is worth the price of admission just to see this one painting.

Can't miss!. Absolutely beautiful. And huge! Lots of beautiful sculptures and paintings. Get a guide if you can, it's nice to have things explained here. Check out mass if you're available in the morning.
Deslumbrante. Imensa, sóbria. Talvez um pouco sombria. Muito rica em detalhes e obras de arte.Gorgeous. Immense, sober. Maybe a little gloomy. Very rich in detail and artwork.

"Rivers of Blood, Rivers of Gold" (as Mark Cocker writes). Yes, excellent indeed was the ARTISTRY showing outside and inside of this impressive religious building: the baroque facade, the imposing bell-towers, the three different churches in one single building, the many huge paintings by the so-called "Cusco school", it all for sure left the visitor "with a dropped jaw"! Interesting enough, one of these paintings, depicting a "Last Supper" (Leonardo da Vinci would have loved to see this version of his famed one) understandably had tropical fruits and a roasted "cuy" (guinea-pig) as entries on the center platters...However, what bothered me the most was the impudence with which the Spaniards (and their Church, as a matter of fact) indulged in flaunting lavishly decorated glittering altars of gold and silver (the very reason they had come and conquered) in the face of the enslaved indigenous peoples who had managed to somehow survive the ordeal and the cruelties inflicted upon them. Even all the precious hard-wood ripped from the forests and employed to further decorate everything else, and the stones taken by dismantling the existing Inca religious buildings to build their own, leaves you wonder if you truly like it or not!As an Italian baptized in the Catholic Church, and having had in my upbringing to painfully digest its historic immoral (and at times) brutal duality, I have a hard time accepting as "beautiful" the altars of gold, built by rivers of blood!

Best part of Cusco. The cathedral is amazing inside & out, but I'm sorry to say Cusco as a whole, just skip it and go strait to Machu Picchu, cusco is very dirty, many beggars, hustlers, and barterer's roaming the streets, impossible to sit and enjoy the sights without being harassed by someone.
Bittersweet Site. This is a beautiful cathedral. When you study the history of the conquest of the Incan's it is somewhat bittersweet as this is built on their sites.
A beautiful Cathedral.. lt was a beautiful experience visiting the Cusco Cathedral. So many things to see and so many stories to learn.

Wonderful experience. Go with a private guide to appreciate its amazing 500+ year rich history and both cultures combined here. I was left in awe. Can't take pictures once inside but the most beautiful pictures can be taken right outside the church.

Incredible!. I couldn't believe how large this cathedral is. It's really about six different churches in one building. Our tour was excellent; the guide was well informed and took her time to explain everything clearly. Unfortunately, you can't take pictures there, but there's lots to see. The gold, silver and woodwork on the altars can't be imagined. There is also beautiful art work (don't miss the painting of the last supper with guinea pig served as the main course).

Fascinating history and mix of cultures. I spent a very interesting 90 minutes in the Cathedral,aided by the really good (and free!) audio guide. there is some amazing carving and gold work, and fascinating artwork, especially the Last Supper with CuyWell worth the price of admission

Inca /Spanish culture. I have seen many cathedrals all over the world but it is great to see two cultures blend in the Art..
see the "last supper" with a guinea pig as the meal...Love it

Touring the Cusco Cathedral. Built on the site of the Coricancha or Temple of the Sun is the Cusco Cathedral of Santo Domingo. It is located in the Plaza Mayor of Cusco. Among the buildings surrounding the square are the Cusco Cathedral (Catholic), and the Church of the Society of Jesus (Jesuit). Photography is prohibited inside the catedral. However, an interesting item inside the cathedral is a painting by Marcos Zapata of the Last Supper where a roasted guinea pig (cuy) is in front of the image of Jesus and other dishes typical of Peruvian food. Guinea pigs are a favorite delicacy in Peru.In the main altar covered with silver plates is an image of the Assumption Madonna to which the cathedral is dedicated to. There are two smaller churches adjoining the Cathedral: the Church of Triumph and the Churce of the Holy Family. Rivaling the Cathedral is the Jesuit Church of the Holy Spirit. These churches and places of worship are worth a visit when one is in Cusco.

Worth Seeing. A visit to the Cusco Cathedral is a great way to spend an afternoon. It is beautiful and inspiring and gives you a great introduction to the history of Cusco. It was an excellent start to our four days in Cusco

Imposing. Entry is actually for the Cathedral and the two churches built either side of it. The history and development of South American church architecture can be seen clearly through the three buildings. Some very impressive alter pieces, and the "Last Supper" with its latin alterations is well worth seeing.
Pretty neat but a little over priced.. I am glad I saw it, however I should have just gone to mass the next morning instead of paying 25 Soles.
Must see.... Beautiful site do not forget to visit the church next to it La Sagrada Familia, plan on spending 1 to 2 hours at least in this area. well worth the time.

Lots to see. If one can hire a tour guide and have guided tour, one learns a lot of history and is shown lots of items that if one does it by itself can miss. They have lots of treasures hidden within its walls. I recommend a guided tour.

3 Cathedrals in 1. 3 cathedrals made to be 1. First cathedral built in the 1550's on the site of the first Holy Communion led by the Catholic Bishop. Get a guide or you won't know what you are seeing. ;0Lots of catholic symbols mixed with Inka legend and culture makes it unique and interesting. Painting of the Last Supper includes cuy (guinea pig)! :) Gold and silver covers altars.

Beautiful Cathedral. Visited the Cathedral as part of a tour of Cusco and was amazed how beautiful the church was.All the extravagantly decorated altars..... cedar wood decorated with 18 and 24 carat gold leaf.Some very large art work as well.Can see why the city is nicknamed the 'city of gold and silver', its all located in the Churches.However no photographs allowed.definitely worth a look.
Spanish architecture. Great photos can be taken here. The wood carving is incredible. It was just beautiful! We spent a couple hours touring the interior.

Cusco Catherdral. very interesting , a guide is a must .not sure of the entry fee, as it was a part of tour package.We know many have difficulties understanding the entry fees , many religious, buildings charge,however it is very common in most countries around the world. The wealth the Church had as you see the amount of gold & silver,used is astonishing.
Beautifull building. Nice kathedraal, to bad they ask so high entrance fee. But from the outside it is already beautifull.

Central location. Easy to find in the middle of Cusco. Large and beautifully decorated. Lots of interesting stories told by our guide (you do need one). Decorated with a large display of flowers in the centre.

A very unusual church. I agree you should never have to pay to see a church. It was also one of the most gaudy churches inside I have ever been in. Let's just say that the catholic church did all they could to adapt Quechuan beliefs into this church. There was something even about a guinea pig in there our guide told us about. But I have to admit, our Quechuan guide was not to crazy about the catholic religion and what they had done to their culture. Oh well. No holy feeling grabbed my heart.

The Cathedral and churches ofCusco. What magnificent wood sculptures and gold and silver embossing. The artists of a bygone period represent extraordinary talents that can only leave the visitors in spiritual awe. There are so many churches within walking distance and most of the churches provide linguistic guides.The chapels and altars express such beauty that really took my breath away. My favorite two days were visiting the churches and the train trip to Machu Picchu.

Beautiful. You should probably pay for a guide to see the cathedral. Not a lot of information placards. The place was very nice and interesting. Its cool to see how the Quechuan people incorporate their Andean beliefs into Catholicism. I rated this site average (rather than very good) because my asthma was aggrevated by the dust and mildew in the place. At other sites, I could stay all day. Here, I found the place beautiful and interesting but was ready to go by the end of the tour.

Very baroc. The decorations are generally over the top, with more attention to quantity of features than quality. However, the wood carvings for the choir and some side room were very nice. Interesting are the depictions of local food and items on some of the painings.
Beautiful. Worth the few dollars to see the main cathedral. It's awe inspiring and even if your not Catholic this place has a holy feeling that really grabs your heart.

Lovely place. This is a beautiful cathedral and worthy of a visit. Personally I would prioritize the ruins first, but this gives some insight to the time after the Spanish conquest, and as a church, it is a beautiful piece of art.

Beautiful cathedral. Totally unexpected and each section were superb- enjoyed St. Peter's Rome but to us just as exciting exhibition of devotion- if you are half thinking of going do yourself a favour - you won't be disappointed to fill in a couple of hours.
colonial. Even if you don't like colonial and/or religious art, have a look at the interior of this amazing cathedral. You will see how the gold and silver of the Incas were used ...

Sad. This place is incredible. Jesus at the Last Supper with cuy is great. Unfortunately, the place ehoes with tragedy. All the finery and gold that decorated the cathedral was robbed from the Inca. Even today, there has not been a non-white Archbishop.
Big Cathedral. The Cusco Cathedral is a very big place. And the decoration is with lots and lots of gold and silver.
Fantastic. A great mix of Incan and Catholic cultures, it was a great addition to the holiday. The Earthquake Jesus is really interesting.

Nice, but no photos allowed.. Toured the inside of the Cathedral. It is nice Cathedral, with excellent workmanship. The policy is to not allow photgraphs. Our group had an excellent guide and he explained most of the chapels.
Beautiful. Pay your fee and see this beautiful old church. It is much larger that it appears from the outside. There are guides inside the doors that you can negotiate with for a tour price.

Wow. Gold & Silver!. This cathedral was so opulent! They could easily clothe, feed, and educate the entire country with the gold and silver adorning the altars and statues inside. Look for the Peruvian Last Supper painting with its guinea pig!
Awsome. Beautiful church with enourmous paintings and great detail. WIsh we had more time to explore here. Guided tour a little rushed.

beautiful cathederal. A gorgeous limestone cathederal overlooking Plaza de Armas. Inside this huge cathederal is ornately decorated with shining gold leaf and works of art that also are influenced by the blend of the Catholic and the Inca beliefs.Look at the paintings carefully and you will see some interesting surprises.
Go for the artwork. Lots of interesting paintings and religious sculptures. Worth having a guide explain the history and art to you.

A surprise. Having visited many cathedrals and churches during our trip to Peru, the cathedral in Cusco was a real surprise. Lots of interesting features, fantastic paintings and historical and ceremonial contexts specific to the region. Recommend getting a local guide to explain these, as it brings the place to life.
Spectacular. Located in one of the most stunning places this Cathedral is simply 'WOW' It looks even more spectacular at night time when lit up in the dark square.
Wow. Quite an amazing place, get a guide to get the whole story of the history of the art as times progressed, too bad photography is not allowed!

Opulence. Hard to believe the opulence of this place in a town in the middle of the Andies but wonderful to see. Our guide Hernandez was enthraled to tell us about the different saints for the different festivals, I found it fascinating

Breathtaking. The cathedral was amazing. It has one of the few "black" Jesus statues which was caused by the type of material (agave fiber) used to carve the Jesus and the effect from the soot on burning candles had on the fiberl. Fabulous artifacts to look at - simply stunning.

Beautiful architecture, but no photos allowed. It was three churches attached together, each one with beautiful statues, one with gold layers inside the church, another made with silver, very interesting. Its too bad they don't allow any pictures to be taken, you miss out on taking it home to show your friends how beautiful it was inside.

Splendid Spanish colonial cathedral. Went as part of a tour with a local guide. Charming Cathedral with original features and very well proportioned. Yes, no photo policy, but this is very common in churches in Peru. Much better than the rather sterile cathedral in Lima which has been over restored and lacks atmosphere. Cusco has the quirky Last Supper with roast guinea pig and meztiso Judas.

Great architecture, no-photos policy inside. The three-part cathedral is worth a visit. The architecture is stunning, as are the different carved oltars and other furnishings. It is possible to access spaces normally classiffied as off-limits, such as the crypt beneath the floor or the priests' dressing room.

Cost to get in and then no photography allowed inside?. I was ok with having to pay a kind of steep price to get into the cathedral then when you get inside you find out that you weren't allow to take photographs (and there were alot of enforcers of the policy inside) I so wanted to take a picture of the painting of the Last Supper with the cuy (guinea pig) but alas I have only my memories and a post card.

Amazing Cathedral!. I really enjoyed my visit. You can opt for a guide, headphones or solo. If opting for headphones, you need to bring your Passport because the employees will take it for the duration of the visit. I opted for the headphones and all was explained to my satisfaction. Early morning mass is open to the public and is performed in Quechua. This is another must for Cusco.

Ostentatious cathedral. The Cusco Cathedral is probably one of the most storied cathedral we've seen with so many altars (about 26), relics, paintings to view and appreciate. The cathedral integrates a building that was used by the Incas in olden days to venerate their gods, is now flanked by two churches and was built over 100 years. Situated in Plaza Armas, the city center, it is the site of many festivals each month, celebrating most of the saints dominating the altars. A truly fascinating integration of Incas beliefs and traditions with the Catholic religion.
pricey. I didn´t know we had to pay to get into this church. If you visit before 10 a.m. is free. 6 a.m. mass is in quechua. Must be interesting to attend...

It's like stepping back into colonial times.. Bring a jacket with you , it may get cold in there. No camera....you are not allowed to take pictures....just take in the experience of being in a very old and heavily decorated church.

Wonderful but you are not allowed to take pictures. I was fascinated by the history of this Cathedral and I daresay, there was a miracle that happened there. It makes you feel in awe of the place. The vastness of the cathedral rivals its european cousins. Take the tour, you will learn so much.

Beautiful and enormous church. Cusco cathedral is a must see in the city. There are many churches inside the church (capillas) and a lot of well preserved baroque art, with gold altars and detailed statues of saints. If you have no idea about catholic religion and barroque art, go with a guide.The entrance fee is expensive, but the place is well preserved.

Cuzco Cathedral Peru. The size and the vast wealth of the chapels within this Cathedral completely overwhelmed us. The Inca past and the revolutionary invasion of the Spanish in the 15 Century and afterwards is here for all to see. The whole City is of huge cultural importance for this great country of Peru. Its peoples whether Inca or Spanish are a generous proud nation. Their stoic resistance to change is both reflected in the ancient traditions of shepherding and farming still carried on today and portrayed in stonemason and art collections for all to see in the Cathedral and in the Museums in the City. We we stayed for 3 days but 3 months wouldn't have been enough time to take it all in.

Fascinating Opportunity to See Restoration in Progress. The artwork was wonderful. Parts of the church are undergoing restoration and there is an area where you can go and watch the restoration process. There is also an ap that will give you a guided tour on your cell phone. Wonderful blend of the very old and new.

Eh. Our guide was really into this place, but after seeing cathedrals in Italy, it was rather disappointing. We were further reminded of our disappointment with this cathedral after seeing the golden church in Quito. You really do need a guide to notice the unique details.

A Near Disappointment on the Corpus Christi Festival. We were very disappointed to be told that we could not visit the Cathedral, because it was the centre point of the Corpus Christi celebrations. All the religious floats from the various parishes around were being paraded around the cathedral and then taken inside.The main thing inside that we really wanted to see was a very famous picture of The Last Supper. This is notable because the Supper is a feast of roast guinea pigs, a Peruvian delicacy, and the depiction of Judas as the Spanish conqueror, Francisco Pissaro!We were told that if we got to the Cathedral at 6 am, before our flight to Ecuador, we would be able to visit the Cathedral.It eventually opened around 6:15 am and we got to see the painting. It was worth the effort on its own. No doubt the architecture is interesting inside and there are other items to see, but we still had a plane to catch. We just had time to see all the religious floats from the procession the previous day at close quarters and in peace and quiet. There is a no photography rule in the Cathedral. Even though there was no one around to stop us, we played by the rules.So don't miss the Last Supper and go and see the other aspects of the Cathedral that we were in too much of a rush to see.Worth getting up at 6 am for and missing breakfast.

Even if you are churched out, go! It has guinea pig last supper painting. By now you might have seen loads of churches but this has an amazing history and the art work is notableMadonna like a mountain in one painting, a concession to mountain worshipping Incas. The last supper with a typically peruvian feast including the pascal Gunea Pig.gold and silver and carved cedar and a mobile car altar which they drive out on special festivals - should be on Top Gear.good to have a guide or good guidebook, but fun experience

Beautiful colonial works. The Cathedral in Cusco has beautiful colonial paintings of great value. KORICANCHA which in quecua means Gold Room and according to historians the interior walls were covered in gold plates.

magnificant cathedral. This cathedral is the first church built in South America. It has since been expanded to include two additional churches, one on each side of the original cathedral making it one of the largest in the world and certainly one of the most ornate.

Lovely cathedral to visit. This is a must-see stop if in Cusco. Very interesting, and great views of the city. There were some lovely views within the cloisters, and seeing the amazing stonework of the Inca's was amazing

Beautiful site - a 'must visit' in Cusco. This cathedral is a beautiful site some incredible history and artwork (paintings, wood carvings, etc.). The architecture is interesting, but the highlight is a lot of the Christian artwork painted by local people. We enjoyed the painted of the Last Supper that included cuy (guinea pig) as the meal. The woodwork in cedar is intricate and incredible. You aren't allowed to take pictures, so the purchase of a book (less than $10) at the exit is a good idea.

Beautiful. The Cusco Cathedral you can go right in front of the main square up to 9am is free, after this you must pay for go. Unfortunatelly it is not allowed to take pictures inside. But in Cathedral in Lima you can.
You must visit. So full of history and artistic value. A gold and silver altar are a couple of things one must see to believe it.
Pity one has to pay to go to a church. Having to pay for going to church is a bit dissapointing for a christian person...but then again they have to ensure that the place stays nice...I guess.

BOLETO. I recommend buying the religious ticket; you can get an audio tour with it that is very interesting. You need at least 1 hour to see the cathedral. The ticket is also valid for the Religious Art museum in the Archbishop's palace (near the stone of 12 sides) and the audio tour.
Beautiful cathedral. Beautiful cathedral in Cusco, certainly worth visiting. Make certain to look at the painting of the last supper, which has guinea pig as main dish.

Sunday. Pleasant but wonderful on Sunday, which is market day. Give the market at least 2 hours with an upstairs lunch, followed by a hike up to the ruins which are not complicated but offer a lovely view.

Beautiful cathedral with Peruvian twist. A lovely cathedral both inside and outside - it is larger than it looks from the outside. Be sure to see the painting of The Last Supper where cuy is being served.There are also ornate wooden carvings and altars to gaze upon.

Gorgeous!. Beautiful Cathedral. Was spechless when we saw the inside.
Art is everywhere. It combines Catholic and Andean faith in their representation of art.
Worth the visit. We were really impressed. You learn a lot if you hire the right guide. Must see!
Breath Taking. My husband and I did a guided tour that included the cathedral. The art work inside is unbelievable, it's a must see!

Amazing view of mixture of Inca and Spanish culture. Definitely worth having a guide to explain what we saw. Saw about five different sites of interest including the cathedral, drove up into the mountains to about 3800 m, able to buy alpaca goods on one of the walks.

Very interesting cathedral. Great cathedral which includes a free audio tour. We didnt have our passports with us only photocopies so were only allowed one audio guide to share. Tip - take your passport so you can get one each. The audio guide was interesting and covered lots of the history of the cathedral and Catholicism in Peru. Well worth paying to get in to!

Beautiful. This is a must see in Cusco. Just a beautiful cathetral. No pictures were allowed, what a shame. There is a lot to see and take in. I always love visiting cathedrals all over the world. This one will not disappoint. You can go down into the catacombs. There are grand alters. Don't miss this.
Expensive. Fab views from outside which took my breath away. However thought entry fee was very expensive so didnt enter. Pity as would have loved to see if the inside was as magical as the outside
Very well maintained Cathedral. Very accessible. There was a small vendor fair that was held on the grounds of the Cathedral. You can get a tour in many languages if you wish. Peaceful

Don't photograph the outside, get inside!!. This has to be a must see. The inside of this building is flipping huge and the decoration would put many European cathedrals to shame. We had a guide which was worth it to explain the many private gold plated alerts around the sides, the last supper painting, the main silver alter, the 7th inca stone, and the truly amazing carved wooden choir stalls. It may be S/25 per person to get in, but well worth it. Its just a shame no photos at all are allowed.

Rendezvous with history. The cathedral is very rich in art that provides much insight to the period of cohabitation of Peruvians and Spaniards. Self guided tour with device providing information was excellent allowing for you to pace yourself and take in some fine insight about the country.

Expensive. At 25 sols each this is a pricy option. It is nice inside though and passes an 30mins or so. I've seen so many churches and cathedrals that it doesn't stand out too much and unless you want to pass the time could easily be skipped.

HUGE Cathedral!. This place is gigantic and majorly decorated on the inside. We saw so many things here that I made notes so I could remember it all later. The well known Peruvian Last Supper painting is here. (With guinea pig on Jesus' plate.) The only negative is they don't allow photography inside, but I can understand why.

beautiful cathedral best seen with guide. This was my first sightseeing stop in Cusco. Bought a Religious Ticket which covered the entrance into 3 other major Cusco sights. Then hired one of the local guides standing by the entrance door (for S30, as we were two people). She gave us a 45 minute tour, explaining history and significance of the place. Like most other very old and massive cathedrals, the place is awe-inspiring.
Cusco Cathedral - More Than I Expected. The cathedral in Cusco was more ornate than I expected. The artwork was stunning. Don't miss it if you are in Cusco.

Beautiful. Coming from Europe, looking at this cathedral was very interesting. The art depicts the religion in a different way, and it was very interesting to hear how the Inka beliefs were integrated in. The statues have real hair! That was kinda creepy

Must See!. You absolutely must visit the Cathedral if you are in Cusco. It rivals great churches and cathedrals in Europe! I would recommend seeing it with the assistance of a guide. However, I would try and make a return visit so you can really take your time. I had a wonderful guide but it was one stop on a tour of about 8 different sites so we basically ran through it. Make sure you check out the painting of the Last Supper.Not to be missed!

Lights during the early mass. Lights to watch with details canvasses and images during the early mass are off until 9:30 am when the tourist time begins, lack of direct lights focus on them make almost imposible to understand the symbols and history of the colonial arts.

Worth the price of admission. We almost missed this one because our tour guide called it expensive. The lure of The Last Supper featuring guinea pig pulled me in and we found it is so much more. A history of the area, wonderful religious artwork, humorous stories about the saint for women who want to get married and another for men who want to remain single, the Black Jesus, and so many more cultural stories and insights. An audio guide is included in the admission price. Lots of postcards available at the end of the tour, so don't worry about not being able to take photographs!
Go during early mass. Go early and the entrance is free. They ask that you not take pictures. But the music and service moves your spirit.

Interesting informative and sad. This is a major point of interest, no photos allowed inside but you will see how the many inca artisans who built the place and completed the works inside were able to insert "retributive art" to ge back at their Spanish conquerors.

Okay attraction, quite expensive. Considering many places in Cusco charge ~10sol entry, S25 to the cathedral is rather expensive. If you want a guide, there are touts(?) by the entrance, offering their services for a further S25. Inside, the Cusco Cathedral is like many other catholic cathedrals that you'll see. Paintings on every available wall space, altars decorated with vast amounts of gold, silver or mirrors. The side chapels are quite nice, as is the wooden choir area and the Cuscuenian "Last Supper" painting.I'd say it's worth visiting if it's part of an organised city tour, where you have a guide and several stop. Just not sure it's worth your S25 for a dedicated visit. If you're only going to visit one religious building in a Peru city, make sure you see San Fansisco church in Lima. Entry to the church is free and the 7 sol tour is fantastic!

Awe-inspiring. When we started our day long tour of Cusco and the surrounding area, I had no idea what to expect from the Cathedral. It really rivaled some of the best cathedrals I've visited in Europe and around the world, and had some incredible sights.
stunning. Stunning cathedral, it's a shame that photos are not allowed inside. Try to work your various angles outside for the best photographs.. many opportunities still. Amazing visit!

One Amazing Historic site. this Cathedral definitely defines the true artwork and architecture of the ancient peruvian/inca people! Its definitely one to check out located in the Plaza de Armas square! gorgeous red brick color stone and beautiful structure. only downside about this place is that you have to pay to go in since it has been much converted into a museum like!

This gets bigger when you go inside!. I didn't realize how huge this place is. It is very beautiful inside with lots of treasures. There were very large groups at times, making it hard to get to what you wanted to see. You just needed to skip an area and then come back later.
Beautiful. In the main square so a most to see beautiful building did go on a open air bus so we got to know a bit more about it

Don't miss this in Cusco!. Absolutely stunningly beautiful cathedral - the paintings! The statuary! The gold, silver, jewels everywhere! Loved, loved, Loved seeing this cathedral - go on a Tour so they tell you the history.

The Amazing churchin South America!!!!!!!!!!!. This amazing church shows the most important paintings of southamerica the best one is the Zapata's painting "the last dinner of Jesus Christ before his death"
cuzco cathedral. pretty and incredible place, sorry you can't take pictures, really a shame, especially for me that i like photography and to share with everybody.

Probably worth a stop if you are in Cusco. It's right on the main square so easy to see, but nothing particularly wonderful. The most interesting part is the Cusqueno art, where the local artists drew typical Catholic scenes like the Last Supper or Madonna and Child but stuck Peruvian items into them like cuy or maize beer. Worth a stop for a half hour or so.

A must see. It's not hard to miss the Cathedral, it's the centre piece with the Plaza De Armas. The cathedral just oozes grandeur and I wish we had been able to go to Sunday mass.The paintings, the architecture and artwork within the cathedral is beautiful - we didn't join a tour but wish we had so we could learn more about the paintings.Would recommend around 45mins - 1 hour here, and definitely try to get a guided tour. Note there are no photo's allowed and there are staff that do monitor this.

Not to be missed!!. Incan intepretations of the religion...you will understand once you enter here!!! Be it the statues or the paintings :) No wonder this is ranked the #6 cathedral in the world!!! It is unique in itself!!! (And I have seen quite a lot of cathedrals in Spain)

Very large Cathedral. Not my favourite church. While it is very big and spacious, at the same time with all the dark stone work it had a very heavy feel about it. Some fascinating Peruvian religious artwork like the cuy on the table of the last supper!
House1899. Not to be missed, but no photos allowed. One of South Americas most beautiful cathedrals. Visit during mass times to avoid the entance fee of $10.
Stunning. A must see, catholic or not, you breath peace and could appreciate the faith the people from Cusco have.

Weird. Not worth entrance fee. Maybe we should have done this catherdral with a guide but we found it just another church that was very gaudy and falling apart in certain places. The wood work was impressive but I have seen much nicer churches in Europe

Could have stayed for hours. We visited this with a tour and then went back for Sunday Mass. In both cases there was not enough time to see everything. I think that you could spend several hours there with a guide and not cover it all. So much to see.

The pride of Colonial Cusco - A shame for it's past. The Catholic Church's goal was to impose the Christian religion at all costs even death!! After the invasion along with the Spaniards who helped a lot both tried to destroyed as much as they could for the benefit of God and their believes. All of what they have seen was consider evil and profane. The Inka buildings fell in this category. After seeing how they were made, big stones cover with gold etc. they truly thought they were places of Satan. For them there wasn't any explanation how humans could have build such things... Forced labor was imposed onto the survivors and the stones of previous palaces, temples, houses of learning and prayers were used to build not only the Cathedral but many other churches. It was said that Cusco had more churches per capita then houses... Each stone carries the sweat of the defeated... some of them without eating or resting being forced to chew on coca leaves and drink the famous Spanish "aguardiente" The Spaniards found very quick the effects of the Coca leaves will do and of course they used to their advantage! The Cathedral in Cusco is the pride and joy of the Catholic Church as much it's now for all the Catholics in Cusco. It houses a lot history. There stood Inka Viracocha's palace.It started to be built in 1617 finished on 1668. It gathers various styles Gothic, Mannerist, Renaissance & Baroque fortify with two lateral towers on each side, the front portals are Mannerist style and the center is directly Baroque. It's altars are Renaissance style, Baroque and Neo'Clasic. They're the result of the incredible skill of indigenous Cusco artisans carved in solid wood cover with "24K gold ("Pan de oro") the same goes for all the frames and paintings done by also indigenous artists. It's amazing to think when you admire these works of art done by the survivors of the Inka invasion, the finery of their work resembles the finery of the works done in times of the Inkas, well done and perfect. These are the people whom they were called savages and ignorant. The cathedral still carries withing in it's walls a lot of drama and mystery. It's dark, the lighting is a bit poor. There is a little detail not to miss, closed to the entrance double doors there is a stone called by the locals THE FORGVINESS STONE is a piece of stone of the Waca that Inkas kept in the middle of the Plaza. Now when the festivities of Corpus Christy are being celebrated each patron Saint vows to it three times when they leave the Cathedral for the usual walk around the perimeter of the Hacaypata. They do the same when they leave after the celebrations to their own Parochial churches.The Corpus Christy is a christian celebration masking an old Inka festivity where just as much as now as the saints parade around the Plaza, in their time the Inkas took for parade their most precious Mommies all dressed in their most fancy garbs and jewels. It is curious now how the parochial saintsl compete against each other for whom is the best dressed of adorned!! If you get to see the "stone of forginess" vow to it and ask the blessings of the spirits of the Inkas... No shame on doing that!!

4 tons of gold. Outside this cathedral looks rather simple but inside it is amazing. Beautiful carvings and artwork, much of it covered in gold leaf. According to our guide from International Expeditions about 4 tons of gold decorations and many more tons of silver were used in this Cathedral. It gives you some perspective regarding the amount of gold and silver that were removed from Peru by the Spanish. No pictures allowed inside!!
Incredible Architecture & Sculpture. Spacious, well-light, colorful and very impressive Cathedral. A must do in Cusco. Plan 60-minutes to see!

Very interesting. The cathedral is amazingly beautiful. The history behind the art word and sculptures are quite interesting as well. I wish we would have had more time to explore, but we were with a group and didn't have the time. While I'm glad we did use the group because we were able to get a plethora of information from the tour guide, I think we only saw about 50% of the cathedral. I found it very interesting the subversive way the Quechuans were able to blend their symbols into Catholic art and still practice in secret.

Must Go. It is the 3rd best Cathedrals in South America. It is simply awesome. you have to take the tour that it will be for aprox. 30 minutes, it is great and you will learn all you may want to know.

whether you are religious or not, an important part of Cusco. The cathedral is a beautiful structure from the outside, but there is so much more to see inside. Because the Quechuan people did not have a written language, the Spanish conquerors taught them what their new religion would be through art. There are many important paintings in this cathedral, including one of The Last Supper that has indigenous foods (including cuy) as part of the meal. Self-guided audio tours are available if you desire. Or you can do a little reading ahead of time and figure out what to see. The entry fee is not part of the Boleto Turistico.

Beautiful, very ornate. Very ornate and built by the invading Spanish who seem to have converted the indigenous population to be Catholics. Hoards of fresh flowers adorn a multitude of alters to the Virgin Mary. Lots of opulence and extravagance within the church making the interior in danger of over gilding the lily. Worth a visit and right at the heart of Cusco in a beautiful square.

A Must Do if visiting Cuzco. The entrance fee was modest and it took us about 45 minutes to quietly enjoy the beauty and the interesting points of this cathedral. The black Messiah and the portrait of the Last Supper with the guinea pig are not to be missed.

No pics allowed. Very disapointed at the no pictures policy. I understand the need to protect paintings etc, which is why most places limit to no flash.I won't remember all I need to without them, rendering the visit something that will end up forgotten.

Once you have seen one colonial church. you have seen them all. It made me quite cross to see that the native culture is now subordinate to the colonial culture at least as regards religion. I thought that the cathedral was completely overblown and frankly tacky. Too ornate. I know that was the style of the time but when you see it now, in a way you cannot avoid looking at it with 21st century eyes and finding it all a bit too much.
A must see to do. Upon arrival to the township of Cusco, you can't miss this beautiful building n the middle of the main square. The cathedral is building, from the exterior and interior,

A must see!. This cathedral rivals any we've seen in Italy. Unbelievable carvings and paintings by local artists during the early years of Spanish rule. Beautiful silver altars and magnificent gold cross. Interior is absolutely breathtaking!

BEAUTIFUL!!!. The cathedral in Cusco was AMAZING!!! It was completely covered in gold, with a giant Lord Jesus Christ on the cross in the front. (It was hilarious, a cooked guinea pig was on the painting of the last supper!!!)

Toledo in Peru. This cathedral will remind you of the Cathedral in Toledo, it is so beautifully maintained. All the niches are perfect, the choir stall is one of the most intricately carved I have seen outside of Rome. A true masterpiece!
Amazing!. Tour was with our private guide, so I cannot rate any tours done by the cathedral. The altars were amazing, along with the artwork!

Beautiful cathedral. I visited this cathedral after having seen the one in Arequipa - I liked the Arequipa cathedral better, but that said, this was still well worth the entrance fee. I really liked being able to use the headphone guide, as that way I could take my time where I wanted to and hurry thru if I wanted. The security is very high here as there are many valuable and beautiful artifacts. I especially enjoyed finally seeing the Last Supper painting with the Cuy (guinea pig) as the main course.

4stars but be warned. This cathedral was amazing. The history, the art, and the "feel" are truly amazing. Here's the warning. So first off you can't take photos!?!?! I understand the need for security but it was ridiculous. I spent thousands of dollars to come on a trip of a lifetime to not even have a picture to show people. Second off pray you get a good guide. Our guide was very friendly but he was under a timeline and we had to skip certain parts cause he was in a rush. Thirdly don't expect any of them to have any real knowledge of the artwork. At one point he said a painting was of water paint when it was obviously a oil painting. I would recommend bringing you own tour book in with you and taking your time. I will be going back an doing just that.

Almost overwhelming gold decor!. Definitely worth seeing the opulence of this church. There is so much detail everywhere you look, and it seems most is covered in gold leaf! The craftsmanshup is beautiful. Your neck will ache after visiting from looking in all directions.The church us in a busy square. Definitely walk the surrounding area. We were amused to spot a Starbucks, KFC and McDonalds amid the old world architecture.
Historical place. If you want to know about history, art, and to meet people from all over the world. Do mo miss this place in your tour.

Impressive church. Worth to see for all the gold guild in the church and also the silver. Apparently looted from the Incans. Of course, highlight was the Last Supper painting with a guinea pig meal, & Judas painted with a darker face.
Absolutely Stunning. I think we spent about 2.1/2 hours here but could have spent so much longer looking at the magnificent shrines, carvings, and just enjoying the ambience.
Big Church. Another large church in the main square in a town in Peru. The church is very opulent with all the gold and all the surrounding building are owned by the church

Beautiful Building. I wanted to explore the building and was lucky enough to visit on Easter Sunday so didnt have to pay the usual 25 soles which i think is a bit steep for entry to a church. The building is huge and consists of many chapels. Its very opulant as you might expect. Take your time and wander, try to get in before or after a mass to avoid paying for the privalige.

Stunning. This cathedral is the first Catholic cathedral to built in all of South America. The architecture is amazing. Everything is 18-22 carat gold plated and very intricate. If you are a student and can present your ID you get half off otherwise it ends up being $25 USD per person, which seems like a lot but the amount of work that goes into the place to restore it is a lot. The only down side is that you can only take pictures of the outside-NO pictures inside at all!

Not such a fantastic Cathedral. Many Peruvians will tell you this is the best Cathedral in Peru and far better than Lima, and more attractive. It cost 25 Soles to get in (or free if you are going to mass at 7 / 8 / 9 am on sundays. By European standrs it just a large Church, noting spectacular, interesting and you are given your own headsets. However I returned 7 times to get one that actually worked and could hear (Im not deaf). Sad thing is there are many tour guides wisking people around quickly and they shout, so even with a headset that did work, I had to keep retracing my steps as it was impossable to hear over the screaching of the Tour Guides. Total time took 2 hours!

Cusco Cathedral. It was the week before Easter so the services included special tributes. A 600 kilo statue of Jesus was carried around the city square and many red flowers showered on it as it passed by.The cathedral itself was encrusted in gold and very opulent.

So over the top. Amazing number of oil paintings and so much gold and silver and stuff to attack the senses. However, it is what it is and the building is obviously very important to the people of Cuzco
Touching. Vry beautiful church, but the high point is the Nuestro Senor de los Temblores, the black Christ image. Touching, beautiful!

Beautiful building. Lovely building, but after seeing dozens of cathedrals in Latin America, my interest is weaning. But for enthusiasts of colonial architecture, it's great and stands with pride of place in the Plaza de Armas, one of the most beautiful I've seen in Latin America.

Seen one you've seen em all. Whatever ... just another big ole catholic church in my oppiniion but if you're in to that sort of thing , go . Once you have seen the mother ship in Rome ... what's the point really ?

No photographs, no cameras!. Once again a most beautiful place to visit and you will learn from the first enclave where most of the gold finished up. It is a shame that you are not allowed to take photographs even without flash and there are many spies around who threaten to delete all your flash card if you take a single picture.

Another One!. I'd like to say if you've seen one, you've seen them all, but that is absolutely not true. Each church and/or cathedral is more beautiful. Think about what it took to build them back in the day and you realize how wonderful they truly are.
Beautiful. I wasn't allowed inside the cathedral the day I visited because I was wearing shorts, but the outside view was gorgeous and the main entrance, from what I could see, was incredible.

Astonishing!. One of the biggest in the world, it is actually made of three churches. And is actually a Basilica, one of the few the Pope visited not long ago. A must see monument! Sit and enjoy the mess, it will give you something that you get every day. Well worth the time spent!

Amazing!. If you visit Cuzco, you must visit the cathedral. This is supposed to be one of the richest cathedrals in South America and the gold and silver, the paintings and the sheer size, combined with the history (including a rather interesting version of The Last Supper) will leave you in awe. We didn't get as much time as we would have liked on the city tour so make time to see this akin your own time.

Highly Recommended. I passed by the cathedral several times and avoided it since the price was pretty steep for the area (~25 soles?). One night, however, the huge wooden doors were open for a service and the public was welcomed inside for the price of a donation. Well, I gave 10 soles and went in. Needless to say I was amazed at the collection of art and enormous interior. On my way out, I gave the cathedral an some additional soles for the honor of coming inside. Well worth it.

Incas, Christians, Spaniards, Cuqueña, all here!. I work in a church for a living -- musician. It fascinates me how a people adapts Christianity in their art. Because Cusco is a painting town, it is so much fun to see in their painted art! High-altitude sickness kept us from some of the explanation, but we went to Mass twice, once on Sunday. Church music is about the same story as at other churches I've visited in Mexico, one organist services multiple churches in a town, if they have an organ at all, and if they do, usually most of the pipes are long gone, and they're actually using a 1980's electronic organ. Sunday Mass was in the Cusqueñan language -- new for me -- but the homily in Spanish. Even with my pathetic Spanish, I could understand it.Came back here everyday, free with Mass, grateful for the opportunity to see it. Had more fun seeing it for shorter periods multiple times.Go to the Masses, then you can sit while you look!

Amazing wealth in this "huge" beautiful cathedral. A must to see this enormous cathedral divided in seveal churches.Buy your ticket at the entrance and take your time to see it all.Amazing wealth in Cusco and something you don't see in Lima, the capital.

Wow - incredible history tour. Even with the guided audio tour, it didn't cover everything. It was quite amazing how this one building tells a story of so much history. Went by quick because it was so intriguing. The headsets are a must - no charge, and well narrated.
The main cathedral. Next to the Vatican this was the most impressive church we've ever been in! Too bad you couldn't take any photos, you can in St. Peter's.
serene.... had the pleasure and blessing of being their on Christmas eve...the entire neighborhood had descended from the mountains...an experience for the heart and soul...
Golden Masterpiece!. Wow. The Spanish didnt just do bad things in PEru!. this is up there with the best Cathedrals we have seen in Europe. The golden artwork behind the altar was spectacular!

Guinea Pigs at the Last Supper. Huge in size with many altars. No photos allowed. The art work is very interesting because it represents the inca-Catholic religion. You can see in them the three constants of the Incas. The Condor, the Puma and the Snake. The painting of the artists interpretation of the Last Supper is a representation of the Inca people. Delightful!

Ornate cathedral - not to my taste. The cathedral is designed in baroque style which is just too ornate for my taste. The ticket comes with an audio tour. However, I did not realise this until after I left. The staff giving out the headphones didn't bother to let me know. So, make sure you pick up your headphones! The ticket allows you access to the cathedral and the two smaller churches on either side.

A spectacular Cathedral. We were nearly Cathedral / Churched out by the time we reached Cusco Cathedral, but its spectacular grandeur and architectural beauty is to behold. We were greeted by a guide who spoke very good english and given a detailed tour through this wonderful cathedral which is a monument to the religious framework but also the determination of the people.Just a spectacular Church. We ll worth a visit
A Church is a Church. You see on church you have seen them all. Nice and clean but go during mass probably much more interesting. Entrrance fee is pricey.

When is a cathedral a church...and vice versa!. The cathedral seems to be in several buildings at once and can be confusing at first - because a church is joined to it and also it is a big cathedral with many families' separate altars (which I have not seen elsewhere). Lots to see but it can become a little samey going from altar to altar.
Spanish Catholic Christianity.. Another must to see location in the heart of the city of Cuzco . The word Huge is not enough to describe this church . Don't forget to visit the basement too .
Lovely. Excellent tour in and around the Cathedral. The tour guide did a great job of describing the history of the place. Just lovely inside.

Imposing Cathedral. A beautiful cathedral located right in the centre of historic cusco, in Plaza des armas square. Unfortunately did not gain entry to the church, but did admire it from outside. On a warm day with a few clouds, the cathedral looks amazing in photographs as well as in person.
Lovely Ornate Cathedral. Lovely cathedral to wander around. There is a small entry charge, unless you go on Sunday it's free during the mass

Sublime...wow!. Never seen anything like this in the Western Hemisphere. Allow enough time, as this is not a "walk through" stop. Every way you turn is another amazing altar, painting or fresco. Don't miss the last supper with guinea pig painting.
This is a must-see. Fab cathedral in three sections, and filled with some wonderful artworks. Don't miss 'The Last Supper' Cusco style (featuring a roast guinea pig!)

Expensive but Mandatory. With such over the top baroque gilded opulence you can begin to understand the immense power of the Catholic Church & the Spanish Inquisition. It definitely costs a fortune to maintain but my wife refused to go in due to the high admission cost. Unfortunately, our driver got a ticket while he waited for me on the Main Square.

Lovely cathedral in the main square. Impressive colonial cathedral dominating the main square and most of Cusco. The inside was much like any other cathedral, but it's hard not to be impressed by the place.
Interesting tour but too long. This was a great tour but too long in my opinion. Probably we were jet-lagged but I would have liked more time to wander on my own and felt a bit rushed.

Must See. Definitely take time to tour the Cathedral, it is fascinating and beautiful. There are no pictures allowed however, so please keep that in mind. I would have enjoyed more informational plaques that would enhance the experience.

Richard sees Garcilaso de la Vega de Inca. Many Inca temples were destroyed to make this beautiful 16th century Spanish Cathedral; rich in history, carvings the building is overwhelming when you see the interior wood carvings. In a lower room or vault are the remians of Garcilaso de la Vega de Inca, son of Garcilaso de la Vega Vargas, in an elaborate jewel encrusted box. This is a must visit South American cathedral.

Guided tour highly recommended.. Absolutely loved the local input of Inca vs Catholics views of our guide.His attention to details - clothings, face colours, last meal interpretation, architecture knowledge was so enriching.Can only recommend the visit of this amazing church-es...Enjoy!

What Opulence!. How the Catholic Church rolls in the money while the locals exist on a pittance. As with so many spanish countries, the decadence of this church is mind-boggling! So much gold, silver and fine linen in one place, plus Pizarro's crucifix from 1533 Spain.Too bad the church refuses to allow photos, and requires one to purchase their DVD, in addition to the entry fee (this church is NOT included in the Bolero Ciudad) to get the entire value of the experience. All-in-all, however, a must-stop on your trip to Cuzco.

Bad choice. If you want that in name of god people get your money go to visit this cathedral during the day time, the thing is why I have to pay 25 soles to visit a place that it can be easily visit it during the mass that this cathredal performs during early morning or late afternoon so go to mass and visit this place without paying extra
The New Bishop started to charge. an entrance fee which is too high!!!!!!Once the Cathedral was open to everyone and now it has become an empty tourist attraction!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Very interesting cultural site. Saw as part of the cusco half day city tour. The guide had a lot of knowledge and told very informative stories about the Mestizo, Spanish conquisdators, and subsequent transformation/integration of the European/Incan culture. The church itself is very unique as it blends architectural elements from different cultures. Well worth the trip.

Visit the chapel with the Famous "Last Supper" painting. The corner chapel features a large and well known oil painting depicting the last Supper of Christ - but the table is filled with local traditional Inka food, including guinea pig! I went to mass here one morning. The cathedral is awesome, full of treasures and wonderful art from the Conquistador period.

Three in One. While I am not one to usually get enthralled at pouring over churches this one was amazing. You simply have three churches in one side by side. The paintings, the timber work,the gold and silver work and other precious metals and artifacts. Wow! well worth the visit.
Beautiful. what else is there to say... I was even lucky enough to attend mass and experience what that was like as well. The architecture inside and out is breathtaking & overwhelmingly beautiful

Very interesting and nicest cathedral in Peru. Much more interesting than Cathedral in Lima.
Recommend to view with English speaking guide, including other site visits. We choose good tour and visits 5 sites around Cusco during 5 hours
Lots of loot to show. Amazing what the people are willing to donate to a church, when they barely have enough to get by.! The sheer wealth must be equal to anything found in Europe and then some ?!?

Interesting mix of Inca and Spanish art and construction. Make sure to take a tour if you go to the Cathedral. We just said yes to a western-dressed woman standing hear the entrance, and paid her a few dollars worth of soles. We learned so much more than if we had gone on our own or just with a guidebook. She described the Inca influence on the various sculptures and paintings, and re-told some legends about the "black Jesus". Well worth a visit
15th Century. Well, its been rebuilt a number of times. More interesting is that the Inca Temple that stood here befors still remains in part
three different churhes in one. with beatiful paintings and different styles in everyone of the three chambers. beautiful altars ect.

Don't miss it. A jaw-dropping display of opulence...and more opulence....and still more opulence. The life sized painting of the Last Supper with the thirteen of them tucking into a plate of cuy is pretty interesting as well.The one down side was the quality of the batteries in the audioguides. My wife's gave up the ghost maybe fifteen minutes into its talk. She returned to the desk where they gave her another one. At least that replacement lasted the rest of the tour. After my second replacement refused to behave for longer than one of the thirty or so stops on its tour I gave up on returning to the entrance and the two of us just used one earbud each from hers.
The choir sounded like angels singing.. Amazing building consisting of several cathedrals in the one building. Visited when a service had just finished and it was absolutely packed with people.
waouh. unbelievable. impressive and we were at mass, quite an experience, beautiful and a lot of people in attendance

Beautiful Cathedral. You should not miss this landmark in Cusco, it is a highly impressive Cathedral that is composed of many sections inside. There is intricate art and sculptures throughout and the sheer size of it will envelop you as you wander through it.No photos are allowed, but you can sneak a shot in while the plain clothed workers look away.I'd recommened allocating around 45mins for the visit, as this attraction won't take that long to complete depending on how much time you want to enjoy the atmosphere.
Wonderful old Cathedral. A beautiful and interesting Spanish Cathedral with lots of Incan influence. Look for the painting of the Last Supper done by a local artist.

Worth seeing beautiful art and church history. I went to the cathedral with a city tour group and would have liked to go at a slower pace to take in all the art in the church. Allthough a guide explains things, I think I would have enjoyed it more at a slower pace. The church has a lot of beautiful art and history to see. Worth seeing.
Faith. tour was fascinating, mass was better. Absolutely packed for Catholic mass Sunday at 5am, in Quechua! You will not get a seat no matter how early you go.

Cusco Cathedral. I hoop Cathedral's in all of the countries that I work in and I have to say that this is one of the most incredible Cathedrals that I have seen (second to the one's in London). Worth seeing.

Great Architecture In The Old City of Cusco. The building was huge and the architecture was beautiful. There was a lot of gilded articles it the cathedral. There were,also, alot of silver in forms of chalices, candle holder . No photography was allowed inside. There was a lot of paintings and side altars. The guide spent lots of time explaining the history of the paintings and other work of art.A great emphasis was given on the cathedral and saints at the altars that we were rushed when we saw the ruins later.

it's a paid entrance cathedral.... yes, to get there you either need a religious sites ticket or the single entry here costs 20soles. inside there are actually two connected with each other churches. there are packs of tourists inside, but the place is large so it is quite easy to get away from them. very nice paintings including the local version of Last Supper.
Very Good. Nothing to dislike. Pretty amazing building with plenty of interesting history. Can never get enough of places like this.

Best Cathedral in Peru. If you go to Lima first and you see the Cathedrals there, you will realize how impressive the Cusco Cathedral is. We took a guided tour, which I think is important because the history of the Cathedral is so interesting. Even though the price is not on the BTC (Cusco Tourist Ticket), it is worth the extra 25 soles
Pretty much your average cathedral. If you have seen the cathedral in Lima, I found this very similar to it. Nothing extraordinary but worth a visit if you are in Cusco

Didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would. Of course, the art is beautiful but really I think we needed a guide to better understand what we were looking at. It's quite expensive to enter as a church as well.

Wow!!. This church is huge !! Had a guide who knew his stuff learned a lot.Got a bit mad learning that the Spaniards destroyed the Inca pyramids and used the foundation for th church. But I guess that's the way it went.

Beautiful. There are many churches to visit in South America, and many of them are in Peru. However, the Cusco Cathedral has many aspects that will take your breath away. The art, statues, and structure of the cathedral will impress anyone - Catholic or not.

Unimpressive architecture, vulgar display of wealth. Architecturally, this cathedral does not compare to the ones in Europe, or even the national cathedral in Washington, D.C. The first thing I notice upon entering is the interior is painted (poorly) to look like marble. The Spanish invaders stole natural finished native stones from Incan holy sites, then painted them like marble to mimic the beautiful cathedrals in Rome.The other features of the cathedral are primarily silver and gold encrusted alters (also stolen from Inca sites), and freakishly vibrant statues of Jesus in various states of torture, Mary, and saints. The gold and silver seem to be a display of wealth and power - it lacks an artists touch. There are many paintings, mostly poorly lit and difficult to see.The one gem is the choir area - an enclosure in the middle of the third room, it's made almost entirely from intricately carved cedar. Amazingly detailed and artistic woodwork, and one of the few features that was truly inspiring.
Well worth a visit. Busy inside but we just took our time- the guinea pig Last Supper picture is a great draw- be patient and there will be a gap in the crowd.
got to see. Cathedral is in three parts if i remember, one of the best i have seen over many years and well kept

Gorgeous Cathedral. We had a guide in the Cathedral; I really like the details he pointed out that are Christian and Incan at the same time. I would not have seen the symbolism myself; it was fascinating.

Wow all that silver. Very interesting tour with loads of silver and gold. Extremely large cathedral. No pictures unfortunately were allowed. One of the largest cathedrals I have seen in South America. Do not skip this tour

great church but not at its full potential. its big and there are 3 sectiosn inside, its quite big, I know they are trying to raise funds to restore it and indeed this is really necessary, what i liked the most were the paintings depicting the early happenings in that square.

See and feel the (former) power of the Catholic Church!. Amazing! The wealth and power displayed in this church in the somewhat poor Cusco surroundings is really astonishing!
Beautiful displays, paintings, awesome architecture. Nice to stroll through.
I particularly liked to do the stations with the rented audio guide.
A must-visit in Cusco.

Must see in Cusco even if you're not religious. Amazing craftsman ship and detailed carvings. The cathedral itself is absolutely immense. If you take 1/2 day Cusco City tour then this should be included so you will get to learn a lot more about the impact that the Spanish had on the Incas.

Dismal. Dark, usually closed--It is suffused with the heavy energy of its history and the conquest. I have been in it several times, and cannot shake the sense of plunder and the damage that was wrought by the Church on the people of Peru

Looks Like the Ones in Spain. Cathedral prominently sits at the head of the central square. You have to pay to visit. When it is open for mass they have signs saying that it is closed to tourists so unless you are going to attend the full mass you will have to fork over the Soles to visit. Cathedral has four prominent main altars with very elaborate work. It greatly reminded me of the Cathedrals in Barcelona and Toledo. There are crypts under the main altar. Recommend you view the Last Supper Mural or painting behind the main altar with the guinea pig as the main meal and the Chicha (Purple Corn Drink) on the table. Tour guide told us that Judas is dressed like Pizzaro who as we know was the Spanish conqueror of the Incas. A must visit while in Cusco, preferably with a tour guide.

A majestic Cathedral. Built by the Spanish over ancient Incan ruins. Took many years to built but has the same charateristics as the Cathedral on the Zocola in Mexico City but with art work of the time, such as the depiction of the Last Supper serving up Cuy to the disciples, and with its it own small catacombs

Very beautiful cathedral. There are actually 3 churches under one roof. The decor is very ornate and everything is covered in gold leaf. There are numerous statues within the 3 areas that are dressed in beautiful finery. It is well worth paying the small entrance fee for. Take special note of the painting of the last supper, what they are eating and who all is in this large painting.
Fantastic. This cathedral is EXTREMELY wonderful?can not stop visiting. is one of the most impressive cathedrals I've seen in my life.

more funny then beautiful. Mirrors all over the walls and the picture of last supper with the Christ and Appostols eating guinea pig. Probably the best is the wooden part behind the main altar. And it's not allowed to take pictures inside.

Escaped from the rain for the student price. Visiting Cusco in the rainy season proved tolerable as there are many places to escape and avoid the chilly rain drops and incessant vendors hawking ponchos and water. The Cathedral proved to be one such retreat when we were a little too far from the hotel and didn't feel like going back anyway. We didn't get the audio tour nor did we have a tour guide, but the few overheard quips from other tour guides made it seem that such would have been desirable. However, it was fairly easy to just try to absorb all the art and gold leaf without the guides. My husband and I tested our Spanish and Latin by playfully attempting to decipher the captions. Overall, the visit to the Cathedral was a pleasant way to spend the afternoon inside the shelter of a church. I would recommend burning a couple of hours leisurely there.

The focus of the Plaza.. Impressive building inside and out. So many statues, altars - in gold, silver and wood - paintings, clothing, vestments it is a bit overwhelming. We saw 2 ceremonies with statues being carried to other churches, a large parade in front of the Cathedral, bands, dancing - over 4 days.
