Church of golden wonders!. Very close to Hotel Monasterio is the Cusco Cathedral. Give yourself extra time to see this one! No pictures or video is allowed and the sights inside will blow you away! There is a ticket charge but it is worth it! You will discover so much beauty and history within the church. Another MUST SEE in Cusco!

Save your $20 and take a photo outside. Tourists MUST purchase a tourist package that includes the Cathedral and two other religious sites in various parts of Cusco. In other words, you are forced to but tickets to 3 locations when you only want to visit one. The other two locations included in the mandatory ticket was a religious museum and another church on the other end of town. We wanted to visit the beautiful convent located right next door to the cathedral but that was a whole other package for sale. The Cusco tourism board would rather rip off tourists than make things convenient for visitors that keep the economy afloat. Also, there are no photos allowed anywhere in the cathedral, but apparently they allow large and extremely loud tour guides who shout throughout the cathedral. Again, they prefer the admission prices rather than let visitors take harmless photos and video without a flash. You would be much better off not going inside the cathedral and just take photos outside and spend your money elsewhere. The cathedral was a huge letdown.

Incredible!. Wow is all I could muster up as I was lead through the various parts of this cathedral. The architecture and many artifacts are beautiful and amazing but so is the rich history behind the building and people who resided over it....those were pretty wild times back then!Cliff- Ottawa, ON Canada
Wonderful for history buffs. While Catholic Cathedrals are not normally something we would tour, we found the $10 tour of the Cathedral a wonderful introduction to the art and history of Cusco.

Impressive and beautiful. The Cusco Cathedral is a must if you are in the city. Pay particular attention to the Inkan eye-winks in the Cathedral's version of The Last Supper, including Jesus' final meal of the Peruvian specialty, guinea pig.

Beautiful. We attended Sunday morning mass here as we'll as a visit with our group. Both experiences were amazing. The choir at the mass were exceptional. It was made up of 5 girls and an organist. They produced such a great sound. The Inka influences in the art works was very interesting

Over-priced with limited interest. The church is undoubtedly impressive - but that said there are equally impressive churches worldwide.Unfortunately it chooses not to differentiate itself from those by providing a dialogue of its role in subjugating the conquered Inca peoples.

Such richness should not be in a church. This palce was like a museum not a place of worship. Being catholic, I though I would go in a say a prayer but I could not. I was absolutely amazed at the paintings I saw, at the gold statues, the silver tabernacles, the intricate wood carving the amazing paintings that it made me angry. Angry to think that such richness was amassed in the name of Jesus who called on us to be humble. They do not allow picture-taking inside the cathedral . It is a must see whether you are catholic or not. Words cannot describe the content of this cathedral and do it justice.

Cusco Cathedral. Yes, the roast guinea pig (for 13!) is a quirky delight, but also a delight, but not quirky, is the portrait of Mary Magdalene with her delicate hands, sitting on Jesus' right. Other artists' representations of her are less definitive.

Gold, silver, old books and guinea pigs. Remarkable display of precious metals used in the alters, taken from the Incas by their Spanish conquerors for this church. While those alters are awesome, the old library maintained by the Jesuits(?) is just as remarkable, considering that it has not been temp/humidity controlled over the hundreds of years it has been in existence. Do also check out the large painting of the Last Supper by a Spanish artist in the 1700s (?) and take note of the special dish that is being served on that memorable occasion. Yes, it was (and remains) a Peruvian specialty for special occasions: Guinea Pig. The combination of the sacred and profane displayed at this cathedral is really worth the visit.. Use of a guide is essentail.P.S. I tried guinea pig at a buffet in Cusco. Yes, it does taste a bit like chicken but it has many small bones so that one has to be careful in chewing and swallowing. I found llama to be more edible.
Beautiful interior. Try Sunday early morning mass, there is no entry cost and when it is filled with locals voices it glorious. The alter is amazing and the famous Black Christ hangs in here.

Very interesting history. The artwork displayed here really illustrates the attempted assimilation of the Incas by the Spaniards. The way the art created by the Inca students changes as they learn the European techniques and they way they add some elements of their own culture into the European stories is fascinating to see.
Lovely cathedral. A guide took us around and explained everything about the catherderal. Without him, it would have been just another church to look around
Lovely cathedral!. Fantastic tour guides available for a donation...very nice, knowledgable young people eager to share their Peruvian culture and history...great experience
Worth a visit but very touristy.. Interesting visit, history behind it, beautiful inside but more tour groups than anything else. Maybe worthwhile attending a service to get a more authentic feel.

So much history!. I'm not a religious person but I can still appreciate history and culture. This place was quite beautiful! The wood and gold carvings are outstanding. You kind of feel like you are in another world! It blows your mind! You get to learn about the Inca and Spaniard influences in Cusco's religion and culture, which is quite interesting. I really enjoyed my visit to the Cathedral.

Looking for the Cuy?. Inside this prominent cathedral, located on the Plaza de Armas, you will find the painting of the last supper featuring the local delicacy, Guinea Pig. The ticket is 25 soles which seems steep for what you get. The niches seems a little dusty and uninspired. But since you have to see the Cuy if you are in Cusco, go ahead and pay the tariff.

Do not miss this. We had a short stay in Cusco, too short. I guess I didn't fully do my homework on what there was to do in Cusco. Anyways, after walking around town & taking pictures, I decided during our afternoon break to look up what all the ancient churches were called & some history on them. After I told my bf about them, we left our room quickly to check out the cathedral, and we are so glad we did. The place is absolutely breathtaking.
Very impressive. As the guide told us, this is the 3rd more important latin american cathedral. The 1st. is in Mexico and the 2nd in Lima. It worths the visit.
Gold!. Clear Spanish influence in this Cathedral shown through the amazing talent of the Quechua artisans and artist.

Underwhelming cathedral. It's a bit pricey compared to the rest of the attractions in cusco. Go get a beer at paddys pub instead, just across the square, or get alpaca or guinea pig served to you on the balcony of one of the restaurants.

Lovely~different from European Cathedrals.. I cringe when I hear people talking too loud ~it's a religious space, not a coffee shop. Outside the Cathedral is the square, be sure to spend time sitting there gazing at the shadows on and cast by the Cathedral and enjoy the human parade~traditional dress, modern, combinations, the tourists from all over the world, the dogs~they are a scene themselves.
Worth going shoping for gold!!. Definitely worth a guided tour. There is so much gold in there it makes you wonder why the Spanish left it behind!!!!
Beautiful interior. Beautiful interior, but even more than that I enjoyed watching a couple of processionals in front of the cathedral for First Communion celebrations and other Saint Day festivities
exploiting the Incas. Fascinating and enormous, but full of garish baroque effigies, covered in stolen Inca gold. Really quite shameful. NB "Last Supper" with guinea pigs on the table!
Quite impressive!. This cathedral was really something to see. The amount of silver and gold was astounding. Beautiful work by local artisans.

Don't Miss. A beautiful cathedral filled with gold and silver leaf throughout. and a beautful cedar wood carving and wonderful oil paintings including The Last Supper, and although Catholic, there are many Incan relics including the Waca stone so non Catholics are also welcome
huge. a facinating place with lots of gold and silver, beautifull artwork and craftmenship.................no photography!!!
Part of City Tour. Very very crowded as all the torus seem to start at 2pmIf not on a city tour go at a diff time and take the audio tour - superb catherdral

Don't miss the Last Supper. A bit bling-y for our taste, but we loved some of the paintings, especially the Last Supper, with Jesus and the Apostles sitting expectantly around a dish of roast guinea pig.

if you are going to see one church in Cuzco - this is the one. The cathedral is really enormous and has some unique artwork, including the most iconic picture of Christ, so I would absolutely recommend visiting it. I bought a ticket that included also St.Blas church and museum of religious art, in my view worthwhile. What I did not like was the fact that you could not take pictures, which was also the policy in most places in Cuzco - in contrast to other places in Peru. For me Cuzco in general had this overtone of greed - insistent selling, making sure that you paid for everything and did not get any extra without coughing up some more.

Not a must-to-do list. 25 soles to enter this church and two others. I am not into art is probably the reason I did not enjoy the visit. I am catholic. Seeing all the decorations to the church and the blessed virgin Mary and the poor people around Cusco made me feel uncomfortable and sad visiting this church. I decided not to see the other two churches.
Stunning. I guess the ticket is quite expensive at 25 soles, but it is definitely worth it. The Cathedral is huge inside, I easily spent over an hour wandering around. Highly recommended!

Need more access, less money grabbing. The entry ticket is expensive enough, but once inside you are not free to roam around and cannot take pictures as they want to sell you their book of photos. Either keep the ban on photos and allow free entry, or charge for entry and allow the taking of photos.
Much bigger inside!!. This doesn't look like much on the outside but absolutely stunning on the inside. Definitely worth a look
Very informative audio tour. Without the audio tour this would have been "just another cathedral." It does an excellent job of explaining what sets this location apart from others.

Artwork to appreciate. Look closely at how art in the church changed and also reflected the native culture here. The painting of the Last Supper was extremely unique showing Christ having Cuye for dinner. Have a guide point out the historic places in this cathedral which is still used for services

Spanish Baroque at its finest. There are a few things that must be seen in Cuzco, and this is one. Peru is a strongly Catholic country, yet syncretism is certainly present in the cathederal. The audio tour is excellent.

Very Impressive. I seen a few cathedrals in my day and not all of them are that remarkable. This one, however, is well worth the visit/cost. It is divided into three parts and it is very interesting to see the changes in the style and the wealth as the Spanish became more established in this past of the world. very beautiful

Great tour!. The tour we had of the cathedral was great! Our tour guide worked for the church and was waiting out front for visitors to take on a tour. Entrance to the cathedral seems a little steep at 25 soles a person, but it is an impressive building and actually 3 churches in one. The mix between indigenous Incan religion and Catholicism was quite interesting. Our guide did a great job explaining everything, but it wouldn't be necessary unless you want to know a lot (there were signs around both in English and Spanish). It was another 25 soles for the guide, but well worth it since he was very knowledgeable.
Beautiful cathedral in Cusco. The painting of the last supper with the cuy ( guinea pig) on the plate was a prime example of the SpanishCatholics integrating Peruvian culture into the religion!

Living History. There is a lot to see and so much information to process here. Really worth the entrance charge, which is a little pricey. It's worth getting the headset (it's free!), which I find much preferable than standing around with a guide, being lectured to like a crowd of lemmings. The Cathedral truly is thought provoking. Observing the various saints, different aspects of the Virgin, and even differing versions of Jesus... it is difficult to see how this account of Catholicism is any different than Hinduism, with its varying aspects of their deities. It's like a Wal-Mart of gods! I would have given the Cathedral five stars, but I had to hold one back because I kept thinking about how, in some sense, this place was the historical celebration of the ruthless destruction of a civilization and people whom the Spanish did not care to understand. And I'm not really buying the propaganda that the native descendants today are monotheists - they just adapted their beliefs enough to stop the slaughter. Oh well, it's still a great place to experience, to think, to philosophize... and then to go out and get a good pizza!
Unique. An amazingly historic cathedral, with a fantastic background, as churches go, this was one of the better ones on all our travels
see it for the Inca foundations. while the cathedral is typical of colonial Peru, the fact that it was built of and upon Inca palace foundations makes the visit worthwhile.

Pretty impressive, but not cheap. The Cusco Cathedral is the biggest church in town. The admission was 25 soles/person (~$10 USD), and no photography is allowed inside (I tried to snap a few pictures in secret, but was quickly busted). The main area is pretty grand, and the amount of gold and silver plating everything is hard to imagine. There's also a lot of cool old paintings, including one of everyone praying in the main square during the 1640 earthquake (I may have the date wrong). If you like seeing big old churches, I would definitely give this one a look. If that doesn't sound like your thing, maybe spend the $10 on some delicious saltenas.

Disappointed about pictures, but very beautiful inside. The Cathedral was beautiful and well-maintained. Our guide was very knowledgeable and showed the proper respect for the antiquity and modern uses of the cathedral. The disappointment comes from the inability to take any pictures inside. I recognize that this is a church, but I have been able to take pictures in a lot of churches in my travels so this was disappointing. The few postcards they had weren't of the things I wanted to photograph and I wasn't interested in the pictures in a book format as I can't do my digital scrapbooking with books!

Expensive - not very interesting. This was one of our most expensive sights that we visited and we were disappointed. It art inside is incredibly over-the-top. The best piece is the Last Supper featuring a guinea pig meal, but for the price I don't think this stop is worth it.

Quirky. Amazing to think how all this got here and lots of local variations to the theme. Just gets better the further in you go - although unfortunately couldn't get up the tower on a ticket bought at the door - but gathered some tour tickets allowed. Interesting to watch the restorers working on the paintings on site. We found out lots of new things eavesdropping on the (many) guided tours. Note entrance is just to the left of main doors into a side chapel (more signs would help)

interesting, but poor value for money. Visited and found to be very impressive, however if we had gone to the Inca Museum first would probably not have gone to the cathedral as cathedral less value for money compared with exhibits in the museum.
Early in the morning. Go to visit the Cathedral to assist the mess at 8.00, the entrance will be free and you must visit this amazing place
Impressive. The cathedral in the Plaza de Armas is impressive. Everything is so extravagant and perfect it's unbelievable. All the gold and silver is just crazy!
Main Cusco Church. Its a fantastic church and museum as it houses fantastic painting frm the times of the Spanish colony. A must visit in your plans.
great experience. One must go to main square when in Cusco and the Catherdral along the side is a must visit, it's a wonderful exerience inside the Cathedral, will recommend to anyone visiting Cusco

Grand!. It's a very lovel cathedral and has I think 5 chapels off of it that have fascinating stories. We thought it was cool how the dress of one of the scuptures keeps changing as different patrons offer their sponsorship and prayers. Afterwards we went to the star bucks across the way.
Wonderful historic landmark. Great building full of historic artifacts. art which mixes Spanish and Inka people. Very well preserved and worth of touring.

Unforgettable place. When you buy the city tour ticket the cathedral entrance is not included but you have to see anyway. It's the third biggest cathedral in south America. Despite the Spanish people made a huge massacre in the Inka's empire they also made beautiful things.

Cusco Cathedral. Again, without a guide, we would never have known the significance of the 3 churches, the paintings and the influence of the Cusco School of Painters. It was a stunning display of religious art.

Splendor. Majesty and history....the gold, silver, and intricacies in the art work was incredible. The artists did an amazing job and it was interesting to hear all the history. Get a guide who can inform you.
Fascinating glimpse of history. Get a guide so you can hear about all the design nuances that the Inca descendents included to keep the Incan beliefs represented in this Catholic cathedral.
amazing. I really wish we could have taken pictures, I cannot imagine how they ever did such a thing back in the 1500's. It is magnificent.
A Must See. Really interesting, but we had a guide and I think that made all the difference to the visit. Worth a good hour or so looking round.

Add to your must see list. Went to Sunday mass here with our guide. Big crowds, back to back masses in Spanish with outstanding choir singing in Quechua (language of the Inka).As in europe many magnificent paintings throughout but these were all done by local artists trained by the spanish. In baclk of main alter (covered in silver of course) is painting of last supper. On the table center is the local favorite Cuy (ginea pig) to us. Wonder how they slipped that by the Spanish.Also on Sundays stay for thy flag raising and parade in front of cathedral.

Attend Mass even if you are not Catholic. We went to mass on Sunday morning and it was a wonderful experience. The people of Cusco are very religious and all of the services were packed- standing room only. The Cathedral is open for mass from 6am -10 am with hourly services. Tourists are not supposed to enter the Cathedral until after 11am. The 6am mass is the Quechan service. The 7am appeared to be performed by the Bishop. The 8am was performed in Spanish b a Priest. Every Sunday is the Military Parade in the Plaza in front of the Cathedral. We went back later in the day as part of our city tour and enjoyed learning more about the Cathedral and the paintings within.

First Stop on the Usual City Tour. Like Qori'Kancha, this cathedral has a lot of interesting history. I only wish I hadn't gone with a guided tour but rather made my way there on my own with a proper guide book with details and history. It is a lot bigger than it looks from the outside and there is a lot to see in there. Our guide charged us through and we made about five stops...but the place is huge! There was so much left to see and learn about! I immediately felt jealous of all the people walking through on their own with books. I've said this about other sites around Cusco and the SV, and I'll say it again. This site is worth a visit, but I would recommend you go on your own armed with some literature to help you observe and learn on your own terms and in your town time. Thirty minutes (after paying a separate entrance fee because it's not included in the tourist ticket) simply isn't enough time to take in this beautiful cathedral.

Spectacular interior. The exterior of the cathedral is pretty but the real story is inside. Every part of the cathedral has an interesting story to tell - as evident from the audio tour. Highly recommended

Typical Spanish. The exterior was nice the interior did not impress me but I carfully heard the story of our guide that it was built on the grounds of an Inca Temple some remains of which still exist and that the cathedral was ruined by earthquakes and built again but the remains of the Inca Temple had no damage.There are still some walls of it incorporated in the structure of the catholic church and one can see how the stones tied with each other so not to fall.(visit July 2011)
Another Cathedral. I liked it better on the outside that I did on the inside. I have seen many Cathedrals, but this one did not impress me. It seemed too over the top with wealth!
Interesting visit. nice place, lots of tourists.Many exhibits cannot be photographed. Well worth exploring the outside grounds also, including the stair of death.
Magnificent. Beautiful space with lots of history. The anachronisms were fun to catch, like the painting of the last supper featuring guinea pig as the main course!

Beautiful! Worth the price to go in.. I am not religious, but I really enjoyed going inside this Cathedral. It was worth the price and the sights insides are beautiful. We took a tour of Cuzco via the travel company Llama Path and our tour guide brought us here and showed us the highlights. I would recommend the Cuzco city tour though them as a must-do. It Includes Sacsayhuaman as well, which is also must see.

Beautiful, with some unique history. It's a beautiful cathedral outside, but it's more unique inside. It looks like many other cathedrals in Europe, but the inside has art works that are unique and can only be found here. Our guide told us about the history of the cathedral and I think that's what made it more interesting. Be warned though, it gets crowded.

Unique among the many.. We visited maybe 6-8 churches during our time in Peru (Lima + Cusco + countryside) and to be honest they all began to look the same after a while. This one is a bit different. Located on the northeastern side of the main square, admission (again no pictures allowed) was separate from the Boleto Turistico ticket we used for most of our time in Cusco. The complex is just that: a central cathedral joined with two separate chapels (Iglesia del Triunfo and Iglesia de Jesus Maria) that together form an immense repository of decorative religious art and paintings. We toured the area with a local private guide for approximately an hour. Highlights included the oldest surviving painting Cusco and of course the famous “Last Supper” painting with the indigenous touches of guinea pig and chi-cha beer on the table. There are seemingly infinite side chapels, each with its own story and one even commemorating Pope John Paul’s visit in 1985.My sense after visiting here is that we barely scratched the surface of what the cathedral has to offer. Our guide spent 20 minutes on one painting alone reviewing the symbolism and interplay of Spanish and Inca viewpoints. If Lima is the political capitol of Peru then Cusco is the spiritual one; a visit here should be near the top of any itinerary when visiting the city and with the possible exception of Qorikancha is the most representative of the area’s history.

Beautiful cathedral inside and out but pity cannot take photos!. This was part of the city tour so i had a guide explain many of the altars and chapels inside. It is truly beautiful and all the gold and silver around. The interesting part was the Incan/Spanish version of the Last Supper which had guinea pig as the main meal and their version of Mona Lisa with eyes that follow you! Worth the visit.

Yes, it's the cathedral. Be prepared that your tourist ticket doesn't include this cathedral which is unfortunate. I think we paid about 12-15 soles. Can't remember. We got the audio which was part of the price--recommend it. The coolest part of the cathedral for me was the Lord's Supper painting which has the cuy as the main meal. Loved that! You will not be allowed to take pictures which was a bit of a bummer, but otherwise, it's worth the trip. It's a cathedral so you're there for paintings and architecture.

Ancient, Huge and Impressive!. I liked this Cathedral because I have traveled to many places in the world and being Catholic I always visit the holy sites. This is by far up there with the Sistine Chapel. All the saints are represented and the amazing woodwork and paintings from the Cusco school are second to none. The altar is enormous and adorned in gold, I have never seen anything like it. A must see while getting acclimated in Cusco.
Amazing. This provides a dramatic backdrop for an amazing story of conquest, and the recent restoration of pride that is evident in many Andean people today.
Beautiful. Such an amazing cathedral. It consists of 3 actual cathedrals. It has huge ornate alter pieces. It is very beautiful and worth the price of admission.

First church I encountered that CHARGES for admission.. I have to say that I was absolutely disgusted when I found out that this church charges more than what the average Peruvian makes in a month. I have traveled to almost 30 countries on 5 continents, and this was the first time I was asked to pay an entrance fee to go inside a church. This is a disgusting abuse of a historical site to keep a gold crown on the popes head.
Tour guide is worth it. Beautiful cathedral, I highy suggest a tour guide because the history is very interesting.

Worth a visit. The price is NOT $25US but 25 Nuevo Soles ( about $9)- still a little expensive. Make sure you ask about the free audio guide- they dont promote this service, hoping instead to con you into paying for a guide. The building- 3 separate churches in one, has enough "stuff" to keep one occupied for 1 to 2 hours if viewing at a reasonable pace. For those complaining about parts being original- hard to expect that when earthquakes are knocking stuff down every 50 years or so. Sadly, no cameras allowed- even the light from autofocus settings in subdued light can deteriorate old paintings.
Wow Amazing!. The church itself was wonderful full with images of the Lord and detailed art crafting on the walls. It was a nice great feeling just being inside the Cathedral.

Despite the cost, well worth a visit. The Cusco Cathedral is no longer part of the boletto turistico, the ticket that gets you into so many other Cusco/Sacred Valley attractions, so you have to pay an additional s/25 to visit. It's worth it, however, if only to see the fabulous "Last Supper" painting in which the main course is cuy. The cathedral's many chapels feature important art of all kinds, from paintings to carvings to silver and gold metalwork. Bonus during our visit: a team was restoring a large painting, so we were able to watch them work.

Skip the Cathedral. It was overpriced and crowded with tourists. Big inside and some things were mildly interesting, but most of it was reconstructed and not the authentic cathedral at all. It's about the only thing in the city center to see, so the city tours make you go there. Not worth it!
Massiv Stone Edifice. Lots ot artwork including the last supper with Pizarro depicted as Judas and guinea pigs on the table for dinner.

Expensive, we did not go inside.. For being such an important monument, we were disappointed that they were going to charge $25 USD per person ($125 for a family of 5). Although they have some important artwork/architecture & bits of history inside, I would put this on a lower priority list for those travelers on a budget.
Amasing Christian Art. The best inexpensive way to see the church is to attend a mass.Disliked that nonflash pictures are not permitted.

Very Baroque. This is a large and very impressive cathedral with large and impressive altar-pieces and very large amounts of gold. Unfortunately, I do not like this type of over-the-top decor and found it opressive, and was glad to leave.
The center of one world. among others. But pretty nice place to look at, throughout so many centuries.

ornate. cannot take pictures inside. such an ornate building. the pictures are amazing. the festival of the saints was taking place while we were there, so all the churches in cusco had taken their statues of their patron saints to the cathedral. fantastic!
3 churches in 1. Nice cathedral with 3 adjoined churches. Loved the andean last supper painting with the guinea pig.
Lovely!. It is a breath taking place. Amazing retablos and paintings. Love every single piece in this Cathedral.

A Must Visit. This is a "must see" stop ion Cusco, even if you have to pay to visit. I would suggest going to morning mass (no pictures allowed and no camera is sight is a requirement),when there is no charge. Let your eyes take in the strange beauty of the cathedral. It is located on the Plaza de Armas, where there is many other things to see, including a usual parade on SundaysNothing to really dislike. Crowds and no photos are to be expected..

Very much worth seeing!. I would not say that I usually love touring cathedrals ( I got a bit bored in Rome after seeing the big ones, for example), but this is a standout, mostly for the reason that there is a very interesting mix between the Incan religious and secular life and the Spanish Catholic religious motifs. To pick up on that mix, though, you need a tour guide or a written guide; I would have picked up on very little if I had not hired a guide.
Beautiful, old cathedral. As with many historic churches and cathedrals, the artwork and carvings are amazing. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful. One of my favorite picture of the trip. It was a full moon over the cathedral

Not just another cathedral. This Cathedral wa sbuilt over inca ruins, and leans a interesting blend of Inca and Spanish influences. It well worth having the guide because there i sso much interesting history and details. From teh statues to the gold to the paintings in the hallway in the open air, this is well worth the visit.
A quiet respite from the crowds. I enjoyed touring the cathedral, though not as much as the ruins. It is an interesting blend of the Inca and Spanish.

Pay for a guide to fully embrace the Cathedral. Well worth paying for a guide to better understand this place. So many little details that you would other wise miss out on. Like why does it have 3 altars. Pity not allow to take photos. The choir was practicing when I was there which added to the fact that this was a living place of worship.
beautiful. beautiful church full of history located in the plaza. they get upset if you take photos so beware!

Ornate and interesting. The Cathedral built by Spanish architect Juan Veramendi and Juan Correa is colonial architecture, baroque,at its most majestic. The stones used and the golden patina in the alters were taken from Inca structures all around. A fascinating medley of Inca and Catholic, It's interiors are rich with sculptures and paintings, specifically so the different chapels. It's here where Christ -"Saviour of Earthquakes " is worshipped.

Not just another Cathedral!. I couldn't help but think... here we go again another trip and another cathedral. We paid 20 soles to have a guide walk us through the cathedral. We learned about the difference between the Spanish and Inca influences. Some of the statues of Jesus had Spanish facial features versus European. The walls were covered with hundreds of paintings including the last supper. The main alter was both gold and sliver which is rare to see.I recommend seeing this Cathedral

Stunning gold and silver inside. The choir in here is outstanding - wonderful wood carvings. The gold altars stunning and the silver religious vessels are the most enormous I've seen. You can see how the Conquistadors had a real party with all of the Inca's precious metals. Interesting rooms with ornate Spanish furniture and an interesting picture of the earthquake from the 16th century showing the layout of Cusco.

This cathedral anchors the main square.. It was completed in the mid 1600s after a one hundred year construction. This building has the Zapata painting of the Last Supper depicting, I thought, a guinea pig. It turns out it may have been a chinchilla! Anyway, the building is magnificent. I was quite taken by the choir room and the two organs from the 1600s which have been restored. Don't miss it!
A must see!. Great example of colonial building.in the Spanish style.

Dont miss it, even if you have to do it quick. My husband and I are traveling a lot and were in Israel few weeks ago that trip (we saw a LOT of churches and cathedral). We didnt feel like visiting so much but we did and we were really surprised. We are not religious people at all but I suggest to visit it, even if you have to do it quickly. Its a really beautiful cathedral, you will be surprised! There is a lot to see inside, and a lot of story. It was very interesting.
Worth a visit!. Absolutely stunning old church, filled with gold and ornate decoration. It's a shame no photography is allowed!

Beautiful altars. Worth a look inside. Some very impressive gilded and silver altars. The "Lord of the Earthquakes" crucifix is beautifully decorated with fresh flowers. The Andean version of the "Last Supper" is tucked away behind the main altar, and depicts a cooked guinea pig as the chosen meal. Many silver artefacts on view still used in current day ceremonies. A very colourful attraction.

beautiful art. We went during mass on Mother's Day. It was packed. The rituals were fun to watch. Very old fashioned. The art was incredible. We did not have a guide, but I would have liked to have learned more about the art and the artists. This is one of the most decorated churches in Peru with a specific school of art. There is much to see and absorb.

Beautiful. Beautiful church, silver altar. There are many beautiful chapels on the sides. My one complaint is paying to enter a church! I think that is just wrong, but churches in Peru seem to do that. Not right!
Bad guide. We booked this through SAS and the guide, Marco Antonio rushed us through all of the sites. No time for pictures.

An Amazing church. I'v seen a great deal of churches in my time and I have to say, I was really impressed with the history and some of its amazing portraits and paintings. I was particularly amazed at the peruvian version of "The Last Supper", which depits the meal to be Cuy (Ginnie pig) and the drink was Chicha (Fermented corn). Once you hear the true history behind the painting from your guide, you'll be in awe.
Amazing..... This was a HUGE cathedral ! most of the alters were made with silver and gold leaf. The wood structures where the choir sat was really amazing as well. A lot of detail..check it out.
Overwhelming. The art work is fantastic, from the paintings to the carvings and everything else in between. Spectacular!

worth the cost of the ticket. We are not generally into museums and the like, but this is worth the time and money. You'll really learn so much about the culture and the role the catholic church played in this area. Not all good... Do take the audio things they offer (no charge) or you'll miss a lot.
Over the top. Too much to look at! Enjoyed the paintings, the altar, the choir stalls, and all the decorative metal work. Kind of pricey to get in, but worth a long visit.

Cavernous and magnificent. This is a lovely standout church off the Plaza de Armas so when you enter, it blows your socks off with its' size and beauty! there are several altars, lovely statues, magnificent paintings. I was disappointed they allowed no pictures and at the same time had large lights shining on paintings that were curling from their heat?? It is well worth the visit as it is amazing!
Stunning. Spectacular! Very interesting and beautiful. I was sad that we were not allowed to take pictures, but I understand why
Another big Catholic cathedral. I have visited a lot of cathedrals and there was nothing special about this one
Audio guide. Do get the audio guide ..... Really good! Included in the price of ticket
beautiful building but costly. We only viewed it on the outside. It is costly to go and view the large interior and it felt very touristy- not a Holy place to go into like other cathedrals.

A fascinating church. Seen one baroque church, seen them all? Perhaps, but this does not apply to Cusco cathedral. Between the many, many "Cusco school" paintings and the melding of Catholic and Andean indigenous influences, this is an absolutely fascinating church to visit. In addition, the audio guide, included in the entry price, is one of the best I have experienced anywhere in the world. Lamentably, the rule against photos (even without flash) is rigidly enforced. How will I show my friends?
Visit this place in the morning. this cathedral is better to visit in the morning so you want pay any entrance fees so it worth it.
Gorgeous. The Cathedral is simply gorgeous with the colorful paintings and statues inside

"Cheeky" Blend of Cultures. I absolutely LOVED the juxtaposition of Inca and Catholic in the artwork. Almost cheeky in its subtle presentation, I truly delighted in every discovery of something "not quite Catholic" in the carvings and adornments and even the large dominant oil paintings.... The cuy and the "Judas" of the Last Supper were priceless. My tourguide Adriel really added an important element of information to seeing all the special treasures here.This is NOT an everyday European Catholic Church :)

Little surprised at the magnificence of it all. We have toured in Cathedrals in France and Italy and were surprised that Cusco could hold its own. Sadly some of the artwork has suffered from paint drips and should be restored but it was amazing to walk through and be overwhelmed by the artwork. Really worth the price of admission.

Incas amazing - Spaniards were clods!. We loved seeing everything Inca and Indigenous - and suffered through some of the colonial Spaniard stuff. The best part of the cathedral was finding that the Inca artists had painted the face of Judas in the last supper as Pizzaro!! Go Incas!
Pretty but .... Its a church after all, they shouldn't charge to go in..particularly so much.
Amazing. This is an incredible building that gives lots about the history of Cusco.
Ornate. Surprisingly beautiful, despite the over-ornate decorations
Had a tour through it as well. I never knew that Cusco had such culture. I am italian norwegian and love my culture. But I fell in love with the history of Peru and its cathedrals and churches.
Beautiful. There's no shortage of cathedrals to enjoy in Peru, but this one is easy to get to, interesting to stroll around and great to photograph.

Amazing!. I recommend going during mass time. Better Sundays, early morning so as to see the locals in full religious activity. Very nice and inspiring!
Some parts of the mass were said in Quechua, one of the indigenous local languages.
Interesting. We had a private tour and found it very interesting including the different art style to European paintings.

Spanish catholic statement in the heartland of the Inca Empire.. Seen a lot Catholic Cathedral over the years and this church is not in most ways, any more special then most I have seen. However, the Spanish brought in artists and specialists from Europe to craft a statement on top of the former Inca buildings. What was interesting was to hear our guide explain the context of the church itself, the religious subjugation of the Andean people and the way the Peruvian people finally came to terms with reality and made their own version of Catholicism.

Beautiful Example of Where the Catholic Money Goes.... Whether you are Catholic or non-Catholic, the place is a must see if you path through Cusco (you just about have to path through Cusco to get to Machu Picchu). When you are there, be sure to check out the surrounding areas.
Inca-influenced R.C. art!. You need a tour guide to point out the oddities, like the Last Supper painting where guinea pig (an Ecuadorian delicacy) was the main course. Terrific cathedral tour!

spectacular. stunning; I'm not religious but have visited many other cathedrals - this is probably the most stunning. Being tight for time I declined a Guide and had a relatively quick wander around – bought a book to read later. The cathedral may be smaller than St Pauls or St Marks but inside the contents are certainly more impressive; a visual overload. In hindsight I’m not sure I spent sufficient time there but I only had 2 days available in Cusco.
Grand old Catholic church in a stunning town. Didn't get to go inside but the loved taking pictures of it from the main square.
Utterly beautiful!. Extravagant cathedral with lots of intricate artwork, wood carvings, gold and glitter. Absolutely well worth visiting!
A slice of history. Interesting, historic site. Well preserved. The guide was helpful. Juxtaposition of opposing cultures that came together.
amazing. Definitly the last supper. Great imagination on the part of the artist.
Magnificent Cathedral. Cusco cathedral offers tourists a full glimpse of the Spanish colonization as evidenced by the all the gold and silver used in the cathedral's other altars.
Paintings, woodwork. Very very impressive. Must visit, save with religious buildings ticket )one of 3 churches included). Solo adult ticket is S/.130
Three churches in one. Quite large, nice architecture, amazing gold covered altars.
special. love the paintings, and the atmosphere is different from other cathedrals i visit before
Interesting / free audio guide. Felt like I learned a lot before embarking on the Inca trail. It was a good segue for the mixture of cultures.
Inglesia. Very big very Old church. does not get much better.. enjoy!
A beautiful church. the church is beautiful but the history of the building is even more fascinating. It is part of an amazing plaza with tons of history and character.
See the cathedral. Get a guide & learn the history! For 20 soles, it is so worth the tour.

Lovely Place. A mixture of traditions and religion. You have to visit this place to learn were exactly you're. Beautiful inside, paintings. A must if you're catholic, but if not, a place full of energy. Take your time

A place for either the religious or those interested in art and architecture, or both.. Well worth a visit, be aware of the swarms of street vendors and shoe shine boys that frequent the plaza in front of the cathedral. Inside, there is a lot of art and architecture to look at, and this is a large cathedral, so its not a place where you can run in and run out quickly if you want to actually see something.

Wish we had more time to see it all. It has a huge collection of colonial art and showcases colonial craftsmanship. I do not know what was more impressive, the solid silver altar or the carved cedar choir. Allow enough time to see everything.
Beautiful. The cathedral is very beautiful inside and out! Incredible artwork and architecture. Definitely worth a visit!
Not just another cathedral. In our travels, my husband and me have seen many churches; but this one is worth the visit, especially to hear about its history.

Something everyone should see. This massive place is full of silver, gold leaf and carved wood. It is a magnificent edifice but one cannot help wondering if all the wealth spent on the building and contents could not have been better spent helping the citizens of the time. That said, it is worth visiting. Our guide was great at explaining the history involved.
beautiful. I love the history stored in every stone here, everything has something to say

Astonishing, a real historical treat.. I strongly suggest hiring a guide for a tour of the Cathedral. There is a ton of history to take in, and only a good local guide is going to make this trip worth your while.
Art in Cusco. there no to many Cathedrals in the world with so many frescos and painting from the xv century , don t miss it

It's like Narnia...bigger on the inside than the outside ;-). This Catholic Cathedral is a must see for those that appreciate the ornate craftsmanship, extravagance and grandeur of cultural architecture. You can take the tour (as a tourist) and listen to the history of this colossal structure or go to one of the regularly scheduled services. The tour is obviously more informative as you see the entire facility with its many chapels, fresco paintings, gold overlay, intricate wood carvings and images of every saint known to man. Knowing that this shrine was built on top of the most sacred temple of the Inca people should conjure up some mixed emotion (not all of which is pride)but never the less, now this spot is not just another Catholic Cathedral, it is essentially the Vatican of South America, the religious epicenter. Again, for a variety of reasons, it is a must see.

A must see. Skip the tour groups. I discovered that with your admission, you get an audio-guide to use at your convenience. It was so much better than a guide, as you could take your time as actually see things, instead of being rushed through. This place is incredible.

Worth it!. Although its in need of some loving conservation, the Cuzco cathedral offers so much! The silver alter, as well as the carved cedar choir section, and the assorted artwork - the Last Supper interpretation was great - is really worth the visit.

Good restoration so nice to see as nearly new. This is a prosaic building but the choir, the reredos (featuring Mary) and the restored clothing on the statues is exquisitely done. [The story goes that the Jesuits and the Archbishop competed for splendor and, while the issue was before the Pope, the Jesuits built out their church (to the east of the cathedral) and won. Oh, yes, Jesus is also there, off to one side on a cross opposite the ambo. The churches on either side are unremarkable --- why attach two churches to a cathedral? Personally, I found the "original" reredos, now hidden by the pean to Mary on the high altar, more interesting -- just walk around back of the high altar. Blessedly, the high altar is of plain stone, stark amid the grandeur around it.
Just liked the history. I liked the history about the construction of the church, but i was expecting more art, I don't like the comparisson but Quito -Ecuador Churches are more rich in detail, art.

Awfully expensive entrance fee.. The entrance fee costs USD 10 and you get no guide and no audio help. If you want the guide or audio you have to pay USD 10? extra or something like that. Is too much money for what you get. Non recommendable to visit.

So full of cultural references. We took advantage of the FREE audio tour. There will be locals or tour guides at the ticket area asking to guide you, but as soon as you actually enter the sanctuary, there is a free audio tour. This was very informative for us, we were glad that we did it this way.The cathedral is beautiful, between the paintings, carvings, metal work, statues, chapels....really there is so much to look at. I think we were there for 2 hours. the most fascinating part in my opinion is the way the indigenous people incorporated their own symbols into the religious art. Once you start looking for it, you see it everywhere!A great stop if you have a limited amount of time in Cusco.

Lima Plaza de Armas - the best Plaza de Armas preserves in Latin America. It is a MUST DO. Take your time, both at day time and night time. The Plaza de Armas is awesome, and the Catedral has the remains of Francisco Pizarro. Quite impresive.Walk the place, enjoy the people, smell the air.EnjioyMoro

Very interesting, some amazing art and architecture.. Don't go with a tour group, if you want to know stuff, just latch on to one of the large groups inside, or pay one of the locals to take your through.
Great piece of history. Definately worth the walk-through the cathedral. It costs 10 sols per person to get into the cathedral. It is a quick tour, but beautiful to see.

Amazing history, and not behind glass.. Look for the painting documenting the great earthquake, as well as the last supper Cuy painting. This was a pleasant suprise which we hadn't originally planned to walk through, but are now very glad that we did.
old. it was so big , and so old nothing like it in canada and the paintings were awesome
Amazing. I love churches and this one really knocked it out of the park. Not to be missed if you are in Cusco.

Tour takes almost 1 hour, too much for people who only want to enjoy views. Big Cathedral with good pieces of pictures from Cusquena School. If you like religious art and places this is for you. Tour takes almost 1 hour, too much for people who only want to enjoy views.
Awesome. Amazing cathedral for the times. The plaza where it is located is a beautiful setting.
really good. We found something exepcional for everything that is inside the facade even very good
It's beautiful, but in the end just another cathedral.. The Cathedral is pretty, but not necessarily top-five. Worth a visit, but it did not blow me away.

Focal point of the Plaza. The Plaza or square in the center of Cuzco has the Cathedral and of course is a must see as part of the culture of this wonderful place. Most are Catholic in Cuzco and this provides a part of their rich history. There is ALWAYS some parade or fireworks or activity going on in the Plaza. So fun and interesting.
Worth Seeing but a bit pricey. 25 soles is a lot, but well worth seeing, very impressive building but they could do with a bit more info on it being available
Jesus ate Cuy!. Pretty church with loads of great art, including the famous Guinea Pig at the Last Supper painting.

Very Impressive. If there's one fault with Peru, it's you see so many wonderful churches and cathedrals, and so many amazing Incan sites.The Plaza is very impressive and the Cathedral is a major contributor. It really imposes itself over the whole plaza, and impressively still a hub for so much activity on a day to day basis. Inside is equally as impressive and a must see even if you're only in Cusco for a day.

An Interesting Part Of An Interesting Day Trip. The Cathedral is an interesting slice of history. Our local guide Carlos was very knowledgeable, articulate and passionate about his subject, which was to point out where the Inca culture blended with the Spanish Catholic culture. The large Jesus on the Cross is very black, saints are brown, the Virgin Mary depiction contains Inca elements, the large painting of the last supper features a cuy, the grand architecture is built with stones acquired by tearing down Inca buildings, and in fact is built on top of the most important Inca era temple. I highly recommended this tour. I hope you think this review is helpful.

A must do!. I have been in many churches in my life, even the Vatican, and this is one of my top ten! the audio guide inside was extremely helpful, even more than a guide, because it allows me to go in my own rythm and enjoy the place deeply
City Cathedral with a bit of history. Stunning.....Loads of gold and silver and some interesting history

A unique blend between Native and Iberian cultures. The cathedral shows clearly how much richness the Spaniards found in South America once they started colonizing the continent. All the altars are covered with gold and silver. Architecture provides a unique blend between Native and Iberian cultures, which is also found throughout the artworks exposed in the Cathedral - saints are dark skinned and there is even a black Jesus. A beautiful choir room in engraved in mahogany also fills the room. You can enjoy your visit by taking one of the electronic guiding devices, which will talk you through the Cathedral in several languages.
Lovely Place. The cathedral is beautiful and full of information and history.
Impressive. Large cathedral, but not as fine as some other Latin American catholic churches.

Extremely beautiful place. Allocate a few hours at the minimum. We took an audio tour of the Cathedral and spent about 3-4 hours there. The roccocco style, the goth, the Andean Influence and the Classic Influence all made for an interesting viewing. The amount of craftsmanship,woodwork and details is amazing . The choir (woodwork) was especially mindblowing. I believe this place is as breathtaking as it is because of the confluence of various cultures which shows in the paintings and everywhere. An audio tour was great. We could pause, or go ahead at a pace we felt comfortable at . Some of the guides were running around trying to wrap it up real fast. If you feel sick during the visit there , they have medical services , oxygen tank, cocca tea at the end near the exit. Do allocate more than a few hours. This is a place to be seen at leisure and not hurried thru!
A good way to immerse yourself in the past and current religious Cusco. You'll probably see your first black Jesus. The use of both gold and silver is impressive.
Fascinating History. Well worth an extended visit preferably with a good guide.
Beautiful. A must see if you are in Cuzco. No tour guide is needed, the entrance fee pays for a free headset with plenty of detailed information to help you enjoy the Cathedral.
Did not disappoint. I do not usually seek out the tourist "must see" sites, but this one is worth a visit. I recommend the audio tour. The wood carving was quite impressive.
Mariano. It's a very well preserved Cathedral. You can learn a lot about sincretismo there

Interesting if you take your time. We (and most other people) were on a tour and were thus very rushed. The guide added significantly to the tour and I'm glad we had one, but at the same time it is the kind of place I would like to explore at my own pace.

Places to see in Cusco, Peru. Don't miss it. It's a great place to visit. They have a self guided audio tour you can take that takes you room by room and gives lots of history about the city and the artifacts. No photos or video allowed inside. They are watching you.

Do not go with a guide-go alone and get an audio guide. Because we did not like going around churches etc. in a party we went to the cathedral alone. Once inside, an attendant asked if we wanted an audio guide-even though there were no signs saying that one was available when buying the ticket. The audio guide is free and is probably the best, most professionally produced, audio guide I have ever listened to in any similar place, anywhere in the world. The cathedral is lovely, and the guide puts it into context with Peru's history and culture. Even if you do not normally like going to churches etc go to this one.
interesting paintings. worth taking a guided tour (or an audio tour) as there are some interesting paitings with an indian twist
A must see. The history and sights of the cathedral are worth the price of admission. It is unfortunate that they do not allow photography.
Gorgeous monument with art treasures within.. If you visit between 6 and 8AM, you avoid having to pay an entrance fee, which is in my opinion, out of place. Just be respectful and discreet.
extremely interesting, especially with a paid guide. Loved the old cathedral and found it very interesting how the Inka managed to incorporate their own religion into catholicism.

Amazing!. Maybe it is the catholic in me , but i love visiting cathedrals/churches outside of the states. This cathedral was very large and lots to see. I did not feel the cost was too much especially since they give you headphones which give you an audio tour for free. We did not hire a guide, but definitely recommend the audio tour. After all, how often do you get to step inside of a 16th century cathedral!
A place to visit. We enjoyed the audio guide and spent a good hour there. There is much to see

Cusco Cathedral. I overheard a guide telling his client that the Black Christ statue was stuffed with chuno, dried potatoe and that's why they had to recently deal with bugs in the statue. Interesting folklore in the homeland of the potato.

Best with a guide. We had a fantastic guide - Percy Avendano - who brought the place to life. Interesting Inca history.
No photos allowed. Great views over the city from the balcony.
Magnificent. Too bad the Spanish had not left more of the original Inca temple. Still a magnificent place of repose and reflection surrouned by a City oozing history.

Beautiful. An incredible cathedral, well worth a look. A wealth of artwork, sculptures and religious artifacts on show - including the painting of 'The Last Supper' complete with Jesus and the gang with a feast of Chinchilla! Only downside is the entry fee of 25 soles, which I feel is a little high for a religious building.
Interesting place.. Interesting part of my city tour with Ernesto, and outstanding guide. Too bad photos are not allowed.
Interesting cathedral. Make sure you go round with a guide - who can point out all the details you might otherwise miss

Amazing building from the outside. Would not bother to pay to go into the Cathedral - much more impressive from the outside and if you were to pay to see the inside of all the Cathedrals it would be a very expensive day

quite elaborate. I don't think I have seen this much gold and silver in a church, to include Rome. Possibly the most ornate church I have seen in all of South or Central America (tho I did not visit the cathedral in Lima....)
Intreging architecture. Beautifully decorated. Amazing preservation. I am not catholic, but I did very much enjoy the cathedral for it's history and beauty.
It's Unbelieable. This is a must see jewel!!! It tell us the great fusion of spanish and indian cultures.
beautiful place. beautiful place with a lot of nice decorations and paintings
Main Cathedral. Get a guide! It's worth to know the history and details.
On the city tour. No photos allowed inside, but this cathedral is a must-see.
Worth the entry price. This is a must. Make sure u get the free audio guide then take your time walking around the 3 churchs that make up the cathedral site.
Beautiful and in excellent condition. Well worth seeing. Hire a guide to get the best out of it.

The most beautiful cathedral I have every seen. I have traveled extensively in Europe but this is the most stunning cathedral I have ever seen. I went on a half day city tour and unfortunately was whipped through here - I learned a lot but was not able to walk through at my leisure. I didn't have the time to come back. You need a week in Cusco it is so amazing. I will definitely come back. It is a breathtaking cathedral - truly the most beautiful I have every seen.

The cathedral is like a tardis - theres so much in there. The cathedral is beautiful on the outside, but is a bit of a surprise inside. Firstly its very big and has lots of fantastic art. Worth a visit.

An Interesting Introspective into Early Catholicism in Peru. While the cathedral isn't really a must-see, I think it's quite interesting. There are huge altars with lavish gold decoration, and the paintings in particular are quite interesting.Your tour guide (do bring one for the best experience) will tell you about how in the beginning the newly formed Peruvian Catholic Church artists copied the Spanish versions because they didn't know how European people looked and behaved. You can see that in some cases the copies are good, others they are not very good, which is interesting in itself. Later, as they realized that it was going to be easier to convert the local people to Catholicism if they made it something they could relate to, they gave the artists more leeway and you can see the result - for example, a Guinea Pig on the table at the Last Supper. You can also see a copy of the famous "Black Christ" statue - this is not the original one, it's a copy, our guide told us. Supposedly it got black from soot, but this clearly was not the case regarding this statue, you can tell that by looking at it. There are catacombs you can explore, many beautiful altars, it's quite an interesting church to see, and it's huge!
huge!. Beautiful church, lots to see inside..the audio is a great help. Way bigger inside than what I thought ..loved it

Very interesting. The Cathederal was built as a form of enticement for the Incas to convert to Catholicism. It was built with a blend in Inca believes, as well as Catholic ones.We loved the Last Supper painting with a guinea pig on the platter. Jesus is also drinking a glass of local Inca brew.

Fantastic, tons of stuff inside. I really wasn't expecting this church to be this good. You should not miss it if you'r into architechture. There are tons of different old and impressive alters throughout the church. 20 Soles entrance fee well worth it.

One of the most beautiful churches in the world. I would say that if you were going to visit one place in Cusco, La Catedral complex (which is three churches joined together) should be it. The star of the show is the cathedral (located in the middle). It's mind-blowing. The craftsmanship, the art, the architecture, the opulence, I could go on but I'm sure you get the picture. Entrance fee includes a self-guided audio tour in the language of your choice which is very well done. It definitely makes the experience knowing some of the history of the building and the art. Went to La Campania de Jesus the next day and after seeing the Catedral it paled by comparison (although the main alter in that church is truly amazing).
Audio tour is fun. Very big church, good audio tour, lot of interesting art work.

Great Cathedral and audioguide. We thoroughly enjoyed the visit. The entrance fee 25 Soles or 8US$ is expensive for Peru, but it was worth it. After entering a guide will offer his services, but if you decline you are told you can get an excellent audio guide for free.

Fascinating place. This has to be one of the oldest Catholic churches in the Americas. Incredible art done on paintings and sculptures.Several fascinating things we spotted inside:"Black Christ". According to Wikipedia this is a crucifix that has turned black over the years due to smoke and dirt, but that's not what it looked like to me. The sign in front seems to indicate that it represents either an Incan god or somebody from the area that lived in the 16th century.At the exit from the main cathedral to the adjacent church (I think it's El Triunfo, the one to the right of the altar), there's a painting that appeared to us to depict the life and death of Socrates. Maybe we misinterpreted it.And right after entering El Triunfo, there's a statue of a man who appears to be dressed like a pirate riding a horse. There's no sign explaining this status so I haven't a clue as to what it's supposed to be.And of course there's the famous painting of the Last Supper which shows Jesus and the Apostles dining on some sort of Andean animal (I think the sign says it's not cuy but it kind of looks like it).All in all a worthwhile trip. It was one of the few main tourist sites available on a rainy Sunday afternoon. The S/.25 does seem a bit steep as the entire 3-church complex isn't really that big.

Beautiful and Interesting. I very much enjoyed my tour of La Catedral, which is actually 3 churches in one. We were given an audio tour in English that we could control and tailor to our own interests. The tour focuses on the most interesting aspects of the cathedral, such as the blending of the indigenous and Catholic beliefs as well as specifics about the Cusco school of painting (the Last Supper with the cuy is here) and things that occurred at the church. The price is a little steeper than at some of the other sites because it actually allows entrance to other local churches for the same price, which we didn't use or need, but given the thoroughness of the tour here it was still a bargain.

Worth a look. All these cathedrals are a bit of a sad experience because they are built on top of the Inca palaces and temples as a way to fully destroy the Inca culture. The church is very ornate inside as you would expect. Most of it is very standard and pretty Catholic church stuff, but a few things are very interesting with regard to the mixture of Inca beliefs and the psychological warfare used to convert them. Be sure to notice the guinea pig on the last supper plate, the pachumama on chair arms, and the painting of a Saint destroying the Arabs. Be sure to ask for an English-speaking guide that is included in the admission fee. They do not offer it so you could miss out otherwise. It is critical to understanding anything about what you are seeing.
